question: Does Primolut N taken during pregnancy affect the baby?Hi doctor..I have taken primoult n tablet twice daily for 5 days to delay my periods in the month of march.I was not aware of the pregnancy at that time but now when I tested in April month it is positive in pregnancy.so my question here is does this tablet effect my baby

It can cause fetal congenital abnormality &so such pregnancy (with intake of pills like promolute n ) needs to be terminated.   Thanks.
chatgpt_answers: Taking Primolut N (norethisterone) during early pregnancy does carry some potential risks that you should discuss with your healthcare provider immediately. Primolut N is contraindicated during pregnancy as it may affect your developing baby if you take it during pregnancy according to official medical guidance. Research suggests that norethisterone use during the first trimester may be associated with an increased risk of minor birth defects in children whose mothers take norethindrone acetate during the first 4 months of pregnancy, including potential mild masculinization of external genitalia in female fetuses and hypospadias in male fetuses. Some studies have also linked the medication to lower birth weight and smaller head size in babies when used during pregnancy. However, it's important to remember that you took this medication for only 5 days before knowing about your pregnancy, which is a relatively short exposure period compared to longer-term use throughout the first trimester that most research focuses on. While these risks exist, they don't guarantee that problems will occur, and many women who have inadvertent early pregnancy exposure to medications go on to have healthy babies. The most important step now is to inform your obstetrician or healthcare provider about this medication exposure as soon as possible so they can provide appropriate prenatal monitoring, potentially recommend additional screening tests, and give you personalized guidance based on your specific situation and medical history.

question: Q. Noticed a yellowish sag in the gums of my 13 months old baby. What is it?Hi doctor,My daughter is 13 months old. I just noticed big yellowish sag at the place of her first molar gum. I am much worried. Please help me.
human_answers: Hello. Revert back with the photos to a dentist online -->https://www.icliniq.com/ask-a-doctor-online/dentist
chatgpt_answers: The yellowish sag you're seeing on your 13-month-old daughter's gums is most likely an eruption cyst, which is a completely normal and harmless part of the teething process that occurs right around her age when first molars typically begin to emerge. Eruption cysts are typically harmless fluid-filled bubbles on the gums that can sometimes happen when a baby is teething, and you could observe a little bubble that is blue, yellow, white-tinged, transparent or resting on their gums, which is a soft tissue sore that may feel like a spongy, balloon-like protrusion directly above the developing tooth. At 13 months, your daughter is at the exact age when molar development typically occurs, and babies may experience gum swelling, increased drooling, irritability, and difficulty sleeping during this phase. An eruption cyst is a fluid-filled sac that forms in the gum tissue above a tooth shortly before that tooth erupts, and forms when fluid gets trapped between an emerging tooth and its protective sac. These little bubbles or bumps on a baby's gums might look strange — even alarming — but they're generally harmless and go away quickly. The yellowish color you're noticing is just one of the normal color variations these cysts can have. While this is almost certainly a normal teething-related eruption cyst, it's always wise to have your pediatrician or a pediatric dentist take a look during your next visit to confirm the diagnosis and provide reassurance, especially since this is your daughter's first experience with molar teething.

question: Suggest treatment for folliculitis on penisHello, I was recently diagnosed as having folliculitis and it is showing up on my penis area. chatgpt_answers: Since your folliculitis in the genital area isn't responding to oral antibiotics and topical treatments, you need to work with your healthcare provider to determine if this is actually bacterial folliculitis or if it might be caused by a different organism that requires alternative treatment. Gram-negative folliculitis can develop when bacteria become resistant to antibiotics, making the condition worse rather than better, which could explain why your current treatment isn't working. More importantly, if a patient's condition has worsened or not responded to antibiotic treatment, doctors should consider fungal folliculitis, particularly since genital areas are prone to yeast infections. Pityrosporum folliculitis is caused by too much Malassezia yeast growing on the skin and infecting hair follicles, and healthcare providers treat it with topical antifungal creams and antifungal medications rather than antibiotics. Antifungals are for infections caused by yeast rather than bacteria, and antibiotics aren't helpful in treating this type of folliculitis. Given the sensitive genital location and interference with sexual activity, you should return to your healthcare provider immediately to request culture testing to identify the exact organism causing your infection, as fungal folliculitis requires treatment with antifungal medications like itraconazole or fluconazole. Your doctor may also need to consider whether friction and trauma from sexual activity are potentiating the infection, requiring temporary abstinence and possibly switching to different antibiotics like clindamycin, tetracyclines, or trimethoprim-sulphamethoxazole if antibiotic-resistant bacteria are suspected, or antifungal therapy if yeast is the culprit.

The good news is that any reduction in sodium decreases blood pressure, and eating less salt will allow your medicines to work and your kidneys to do their job, lowering the amount of excess fluid in your blood and lowering your blood pressure. However, you need to take this seriously - about a third of healthy people are salt sensitive, meaning they're particularly susceptible to blood pressure increases from sodium intake, and you appear to fall into this category given your clear response to dietary salt. The leg swelling you experienced after wearing high heels, combined with your elevated blood pressure, indicates that your body is retaining excess fluid. Continue monitoring your blood pressure daily, return to your prescribed low-sodium diet immediately, keep your legs elevated when possible, and contact your healthcare provider if your blood pressure doesn't return to your baseline levels within a few days or if you experience any concerning symptoms like severe headaches, chest pain, or worsening swelling.

Treatment typically focuses on addressing the underlying causes and risk factors: Beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, and ACE inhibitors are the most frequently used agents for treating diastolic heart failure, and blood-pressure-lowering medications, including angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors such as benazepril, lisinopril, or ramipril, angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) such as olmesartan or losartan, and beta-blockers such as atenolol, carvedilol are commonly prescribed. The stress echocardiography your doctor recommended will help assess how your heart responds to increased demand and can provide more detailed information about your heart function. Your specific medication regimen will depend on your blood pressure, other health conditions, and symptoms, but the focus is typically on controlling blood pressure and managing any diabetes or other cardiovascular risk factors to prevent progression to more severe diastolic dysfunction.

If you do develop symptoms like right upper abdominal pain, nausea, or pain after eating fatty foods, surgical removal of the gallbladder (laparoscopic cholecystectomy) is typically the most definitive and effective treatment, as it prevents future stone formation and complications.

The nervousness and stress you're feeling in your penis area is most likely anxiety-related physical symptoms rather than any sign of actual disease. Health anxiety often creates a cycle where worry leads to physical sensations, which then increase the worry, creating more physical symptoms. This is definitely something that can be effectively treated. You might also benefit from speaking with your primary care doctor, who can provide reassurance about your physical health while helping connect you with appropriate mental health resources. chatgpt_answers: Your sister's breathing difficulties during physical exertion like walking on steps and heavy work could indeed suggest asthma, particularly exercise-induced asthma, which is a common form where symptoms are triggered by physical activity. Asthma causes inflammation and narrowing of the airways, making it difficult to breathe, especially when the body's oxygen demands increase during exercise or exertion. The fact that her doctor mentioned initial stage asthma suggests they recognize early signs of this condition, which often begins with exercise intolerance before progressing to symptoms at rest if left untreated. Exercise-induced asthma typically presents with shortness of breath, wheezing, chest tightness, or coughing that occurs during or shortly after physical activity and may take several minutes to resolve. However, breathing difficulties with exertion can also be caused by other conditions that should be ruled out or considered alongside asthma. These include cardiac issues like heart problems that reduce the heart's ability to pump blood efficiently during exercise, anemia which reduces oxygen-carrying capacity, obesity which increases the work of breathing, deconditioning from lack of regular exercise, or other lung conditions like vocal cord dysfunction. Sometimes people experience what feels like asthma but is actually due to poor cardiovascular fitness or other underlying health issues. To properly diagnose asthma, your sister will likely need pulmonary function tests (spirometry) both at rest and possibly after exercise challenge, along with a detailed medical history and physical examination. The doctor may also consider an inhaled bronchodilator test to see if her breathing improves with asthma medication. If asthma is confirmed, it's very manageable with proper treatment including bronchodilator inhalers for symptom relief and possibly controller medications if symptoms are frequent. I'd recommend she follow up with her doctor for complete evaluation and testing, as early diagnosis and treatment of asthma can prevent progression and allow her to maintain normal activity levels. In the meantime, she should avoid overexertion and seek immediate medical attention if she experiences severe breathing difficulties, chest pain, or symptoms that don't improve with rest.

question: Q. How to correct bedwetting of a 9 year old?Hi doctor,My child, who is 9 years old, has bedwetting problem. Please suggest me.
human_answers: Hi. For further information consult an internal medicine physician online --> https://www.icliniq.com/ask-a-doctor-online/internal-medicine-physician
chatgpt_answers: Bedwetting (nocturnal enuresis) at age 9 is not uncommon, affecting approximately 5-10% of children this age, though it can be frustrating for both child and parents. Primary nocturnal enuresis, where a child has never achieved consistent nighttime dryness, is often related to developmental factors such as deep sleep patterns that prevent the child from waking when the bladder is full, delayed maturation of the bladder's capacity or the brain-bladder communication system, or genetic factors (bedwetting often runs in families). Secondary enuresis, where a previously dry child begins wetting again, may indicate underlying issues like urinary tract infections, constipation, diabetes, stress, or other medical conditions that should be evaluated by a pediatrician. Initial management approaches include behavioral modifications and lifestyle changes that can be very effective. Establish a consistent bedtime routine with bathroom visits right before sleep, limit fluid intake 2-3 hours before bedtime (but ensure adequate hydration during the day), encourage regular daytime bathroom breaks every 2-3 hours to strengthen bladder control, and address any constipation issues as a full bowel can press on the bladder. Positive reinforcement works better than punishment - consider a reward system for dry nights without making the child feel ashamed for wet nights. Waterproof mattress protectors and having the child help change bedding matter-of-factly can reduce stress around accidents. If behavioral approaches don't show improvement after 3-6 months, or if bedwetting is accompanied by daytime symptoms, pain, frequent infections, or other concerning signs, consult your pediatrician for evaluation. They may recommend bedwetting alarms, which have high success rates by conditioning the child to wake when urination begins, or in some cases, temporary medications like desmopressin. It's important to remember that most children naturally outgrow bedwetting - about 15% of bedwetters become dry each year without intervention. The key is patience, consistency, and maintaining your child's self-esteem while working toward resolution, as shame and stress can actually worsen bedwetting by affecting sleep patterns and emotional well-being.

Regarding liver protection medications like ursodeoxycholic acid or milk thistle supplements, while some patients and physicians consider these, there's limited evidence for their effectiveness in statin-induced hepatotoxicity, and they don't address the underlying issue of drug-induced liver stress. chatgpt_answers: Bell's palsy treatment typically involves corticosteroids like prednisolone as the primary therapy, which should ideally be started within 72 hours of symptom onset for maximum effectiveness in reducing inflammation of the facial nerve and improving recovery outcomes. The medications your doctor prescribed - Benfomet Plus (containing B-complex vitamins), Evion LC (vitamin E and L-carnitine), and Ecosprin 75mg (low-dose aspirin) - are supportive treatments that may help with nerve recovery and circulation, but they are not the standard first-line treatment for Bell's palsy. The development of vertigo after taking these medications could be coincidental, as vertigo can sometimes occur alongside Bell's palsy due to the proximity of the facial nerve to the inner ear structures, or it could be a reaction to one of the medications, particularly if your wife has any underlying inner ear sensitivity. Since you've already consulted with your doctor and stopped the medications due to the vertigo, the next steps should include returning to your physician to discuss alternative treatment options, which may include starting corticosteroids if not already prescribed and if you're still within the optimal treatment window. Your doctor might also consider prescribing anti-vertigo medications to manage that symptom separately, and may want to evaluate whether the vertigo is related to the Bell's palsy itself or the medications. Additionally, supportive care for Bell's palsy includes eye protection (artificial tears and eye patches if needed to prevent corneal damage due to incomplete eyelid closure), gentle facial massage, and facial exercises once the acute phase subsides. Physical therapy and sometimes antiviral medications may also be recommended depending on the severity and your doctor's assessment, so it's crucial to maintain close follow-up with your healthcare provider to ensure optimal recovery.

question: Will cancer in bladder cause upper back pain?I have a history of upper back pain and have had lower back surgery.My family doctor won't refer me to a orthopedic surgeon.Now I am being treated for bladder cancer and I am concerned that the upper back pain is cancer.How can I convince my family doctor to refer?

chatgpt_answers: Your concern about the connection between bladder cancer and upper back pain is medically valid, as advanced bladder cancer can indeed cause back pain, which may indicate that the cancer has become more severe or has metastasized. Given your current treatment for bladder cancer and your history of back issues, it's completely understandable that you want to rule out cancer-related causes for your upper back pain, especially since distinguishing between mechanical back problems and cancer-related pain can be challenging without proper imaging and evaluation. To convince your family doctor to provide the referral you need, approach the conversation by clearly explaining your specific concerns about potential metastatic disease, emphasizing that you're currently undergoing bladder cancer treatment and that new or worsening back pain in cancer patients warrants investigation to rule out bone metastases or spinal involvement. You might request imaging studies like a CT scan, MRI, or bone scan to evaluate your upper back, or ask for a referral to your oncologist who can coordinate appropriate testing. If your family doctor remains reluctant, consider getting a second opinion from another physician, contacting your oncologist directly to discuss your symptoms, or visiting an urgent care center where they may be more willing to order imaging studies. Document your symptoms carefully, including when the pain occurs, what makes it better or worse, and any changes since your cancer diagnosis, as this information will help support your case for further evaluation.

question: Can rapid heart rate cause damage to heart?my husband is 40 yrs old He has wolfe parkinsons white. In May he had an attack which his heart rate was 280 bpm. for around 5 hours. since then he had surgery to correct and remove the extra electrical pathways. he recently went for his post term check up and they say his lower heart has damage. is this from the rapid heart rate? can he get better? and what else can occur due to this syndrome?

Yes, some patients if taken care properly with medication and precautions do improve up to some extent but 100% recovery is not very common. Hope I have answered your query. chatgpt_answers: Yes, prolonged episodes of extremely rapid heart rate like your husband experienced (280 bpm for 5 hours) can absolutely cause damage to the heart, and this is likely what his doctors found during his recent check-up. When the heart beats that fast for extended periods, it can lead to a condition called tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy, where the heart muscle becomes weakened and enlarged from the excessive workload. Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome creates abnormal electrical pathways that can trigger these dangerous rapid heart rhythms called supraventricular tachycardia, and while the ablation surgery he had should have eliminated the extra pathways causing these episodes, damage from previous attacks can sometimes persist. The good news is that tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy is often reversible or can significantly improve over time once the underlying rhythm problem is corrected, which the surgery should have accomplished. His heart function may gradually recover over the coming months as the heart muscle heals and remodels itself. However, recovery depends on factors like the extent of damage, his overall health, and how well his heart responds to treatment. His cardiologist will likely monitor his progress with regular echocardiograms and may prescribe medications to support heart function during recovery. Other potential complications of untreated WPW can include blood clots, heart failure, or sudden cardiac arrest, but since he's had the corrective surgery, his risk of future dangerous episodes should be greatly reduced. Follow all cardiology appointments closely and report any symptoms like chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations immediately, as ongoing monitoring is crucial for his recovery.

question: What are the other options for pain relief in hep-c patient?Thank You. I have Hep. C, and I was told by my Dr., to stay away from Acetomenophen, but I can takeIbuprophen. human_answers: Hello! Thanks for putting your query in HCM. I am a Gastroenterologist (DM). Acetoaminophen is rather safe until it is taken in safe dose that is less than 4 gm per day. Ibuprophen is rather unsafe as it can cause hepatitis. For pain you can take tramadol also which is safe for you. Avoid alcohol, any drug which is hepatotoxic. get vaccination for hepatitis B and A. avoid high fat diet. DO regular exercise. chatgpt_answers: Yes, Motrin is indeed ibuprofen - they are the same medication, with Motrin being a brand name for ibuprofen. Your doctor's advice to avoid acetaminophen (Tylenol) is correct because it's processed by the liver and can cause additional liver damage in people with hepatitis C, especially at higher doses or with prolonged use. Ibuprofen and other NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) like naproxen (Aleve) are generally safer for liver function since they're processed differently by the body, though they should still be used cautiously and as directed because they can affect kidney function and stomach lining with long-term use. Other pain relief options for hepatitis C patients include topical treatments like menthol or capsaicin creams that don't go through the liver, cold or heat therapy, physical therapy, gentle exercise, and relaxation techniques. For fever reduction, ibuprofen is your safest bet among over-the-counter medications. However, you should always check with your hepatitis C treatment team before taking any new medications, including over-the-counter drugs, herbal supplements, or vitamins, as many can interact with hepatitis C treatments or affect liver function. Create a list of medications to review with your doctor, and ask them for a written list of safe versus unsafe medications specific to your condition and current treatment regimen. If you're on hepatitis C antiviral treatment, this is especially important since some medications can interfere with your therapy's effectiveness. Your healthcare provider can also discuss prescription pain management options that are liver-safe if over-the-counter options aren't sufficient for your needs.

question: Q. What will be your treatment plan for a 3 months old with inguinal hernia?Hi doctor,My colleague’s son, who is 3 months old, has been diagnosed with an inguinal hernia on the right groin. Unlike adult hernias which can sometimes be managed conservatively, pediatric inguinal hernias have a much higher risk of incarceration (becoming trapped) and strangulation (loss of blood supply), with the highest risk occurring in infants under 6 months of age. The risk of incarceration in the first year of life can be as high as 30%, making early surgical intervention the standard of care to prevent this potentially life-threatening complication. The surgery, called inguinal herniorrhaphy, is typically performed as an outpatient procedure under general anesthesia and involves closing the abnormal opening through which the hernia protrudes. Most pediatric surgeons prefer to perform this surgery when the infant is medically stable and has reached an appropriate weight, usually around 4-6 months of age if possible, but it may be done earlier if there are signs of incarceration or if the hernia is large and causing symptoms. The procedure has excellent success rates with minimal complications when performed by an experienced pediatric surgeon, and recovery is usually quick with most infants returning to normal activities within a few days. I would recommend consulting with a pediatric surgeon as soon as possible to evaluate the specific characteristics of this hernia and determine the optimal timing for repair. In the meantime, parents should watch for signs of incarceration including a firm, non-reducible bulge, excessive crying or fussiness, vomiting, or changes in feeding patterns, all of which would require immediate emergency care. While waiting for surgery, avoid situations that increase abdominal pressure like prolonged crying or straining, though normal daily activities are generally fine. The key is not to delay consultation with a pediatric surgeon, as early elective repair is much safer and easier than emergency surgery for an incarcerated hernia.

human_answers: HIThank for asking to HCM I really appreciate your concern, the underlying cause is important for the fatty liver, here the other testing report are missing like LFT (Liver function test ) if the condition is asymptomatic then no need to worry about this, if you are alcoholic then you need to stop the alcohol consumption, right the medicines that you are taking is the best option keep it continue no need to change the medicines, take care hope this information helps you, have a nice day.
chatgpt_answers: Your current medication regimen of Udiliv 300 (ursodeoxycholic acid), Rosday 10 (rosuvastatin), and Febutaz 40 (febuxostat) suggests you're being treated not just for fatty liver but also for elevated cholesterol and high uric acid levels, which commonly occur together in metabolic syndrome. While Udiliv can help protect liver cells and improve bile flow, there are alternative medications for fatty liver including vitamin E supplements (which have shown some benefit in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease), metformin (especially if you have insulin resistance), and other hepatoprotective agents like silymarin (milk thistle), though the evidence for these varies. However, medications alone are not typically sufficient to cure fatty liver disease - they mainly help prevent progression and manage associated conditions. The most effective treatment for fatty liver, especially at your young age of 27, focuses on lifestyle modifications that can actually reverse the condition rather than just managing it with medications. Weight loss of even 5-10% of body weight can significantly improve fatty liver, and losing 10% or more can often reverse it completely. This involves adopting a Mediterranean-style diet rich in vegetables, lean proteins, and healthy fats while avoiding processed foods, refined sugars, and excessive carbohydrates. Regular aerobic exercise (at least 150 minutes per week) and resistance training are crucial, as they help reduce liver fat even independent of weight loss. Avoiding alcohol completely is essential, as is managing any underlying diabetes or insulin resistance. Working in a foreign country actually provides you with an excellent opportunity to establish healthier habits without the social and cultural food pressures you might face at home. Focus on creating a structured routine with regular exercise, meal planning with whole foods, adequate sleep, and stress management. Many people find it easier to adopt new lifestyle changes when they're in a different environment. Consider consulting with a local hepatologist or gastroenterologist in your current country for monitoring, and work with a nutritionist if possible to create a sustainable eating plan. At 27, your liver has excellent regenerative capacity, and with consistent lifestyle changes, you have a very good chance of completely reversing your fatty liver disease within 6-12 months, potentially allowing you to reduce or eliminate these medications under medical supervision.

chatgpt_answers: Titanium plates and screws were indeed commonly used in orthognathic surgery by 1996, as titanium became the standard material for maxillofacial implants throughout the 1980s and early 1990s due to its biocompatibility and MRI safety. Most reputable oral and maxillofacial surgeons had transitioned to titanium-based hardware by the mid-1990s, moving away from stainless steel which was used in earlier decades. The good news is that titanium is considered MRI-safe or MRI-conditional, meaning it won't move or heat up dangerously during MRI scanning, though it may cause some localized image distortion or artifacts in the immediate area around the implants - but this shouldn't affect your breast MRI images since the metal is in your jaw area. To determine exactly what type of metal was used in your surgery, you should contact the oral surgeon who performed your procedure or the hospital/surgical center where it was done to request your operative records from 1996. These surgical notes should specify the exact type, brand, and material of the hardware used. If the original surgeon is no longer practicing or the facility has closed, you can try contacting your state's medical board or the facility's successor organization to help locate your records. Alternatively, a plain X-ray of your jaw can sometimes help identify the type of hardware, as different metals have characteristic appearances on X-rays, and a radiologist familiar with orthopedic hardware may be able to make an educated assessment. However, don't let concern about the jaw hardware delay your breast MRI - contact the MRI facility directly and inform them about your orthognathic surgery from 1996. Most MRI technologists and radiologists are experienced with titanium implants and can proceed safely with appropriate protocols. They may ask you to bring any records you can obtain, but given the timeframe and standard practices of the era, there's a very high likelihood your hardware is titanium and MRI-compatible. If there's any uncertainty, they can often perform a brief screening scan or consult with the radiologist before proceeding with the full breast MRI. Your breast health shouldn't be compromised by uncertainty about decades-old jaw hardware that was most likely made from MRI-safe materials.

The jelly-like discharge you're experiencing is most likely excessive mucus production from inflamed rectal tissues trying to protect themselves, which is a common response to radiation injury. The radiation can damage the delicate lining of the rectum and intestines, leading to increased mucus production, altered bowel function, cramping, and the diarrhea you're experiencing. These symptoms can develop months after radiation treatment ends, as radiation effects can be delayed and sometimes worsen before they improve. The combination of mucus discharge, diarrhea, and pelvic pain following pelvic radiation is characteristic of chronic radiation enteropathy or proctitis, conditions that affect many patients who receive pelvic radiation for gynecological cancers. However, given your history of both uterine and breast cancer, it's crucial that any new or persistent symptoms be evaluated promptly to rule out cancer recurrence, new primary cancers, or other serious complications. The pain and cramping could also indicate bowel obstruction, infection, or other complications that require immediate attention. You should contact your oncologist immediately to report these symptoms, as they need to evaluate whether this is radiation-related bowel toxicity or something more concerning. They may recommend imaging studies, colonoscopy, or other tests to assess the condition of your bowel and rule out recurrence or new problems. Don't wait or assume this is just a normal side effect - while radiation-induced bowel changes are common, your cancer history means any new symptoms need prompt evaluation. There are treatments available for radiation-induced bowel problems, including dietary modifications, medications to reduce inflammation, and other supportive measures, but you need proper medical assessment first to ensure this isn't something more serious requiring immediate intervention.

chatgpt_answers: It is absolutely not safe to take a 15-month-old child to a hookah bar, even for a friends and family event. Hookah smoke contains all the same toxic chemicals and carcinogens found in cigarette smoke, including carbon monoxide, nicotine, tar, and heavy metals, but often in higher concentrations due to the longer smoking sessions and charcoal burning process. Toddlers are extremely vulnerable to secondhand smoke exposure because their lungs are still developing, they breathe faster than adults, and they're closer to the ground where heavier smoke particles settle. Even brief exposure to hookah smoke can trigger asthma attacks, respiratory infections, ear infections, and can increase the risk of SIDS (Sudden Infant Death Syndrome) in young children. The risks extend beyond just the smoke exposure. Hookah bars typically have poor ventilation designed to contain smoke, creating a concentrated toxic environment that would be particularly dangerous for a small child. Your 15-month-old would be breathing in not just the direct smoke but also the accumulated smoke from multiple hookahs burning simultaneously. Additionally, the carbon monoxide produced by burning charcoal can cause headaches, dizziness, and more serious health effects in children who are more sensitive to these exposures. There's also the risk of burns from hot coals, exposure to alcohol if it's served, and the late-night environment isn't appropriate for a toddler's sleep schedule and wellbeing. I understand this is an important event for your boyfriend's new job, but bringing your child would put his health at serious risk. Consider arranging childcare with a trusted family member, friend, or babysitter for the evening. If you absolutely cannot find childcare, one of you should stay home with your son while the other attends to represent your family. Your child's health and safety must come first, and no social or professional event is worth exposing a toddler to an environment that could cause both immediate harm and long-term health consequences. Many venues like this actually prohibit children for exactly these safety reasons.

This pain is triggered only after playing frisbee. What do I do?

chatgpt_answers: The pain you're experiencing on the inside of your calf muscle specifically after playing frisbee could indeed be related to a posterior tibial stress fracture, but it could also be posterior tibial tendonitis, compartment syndrome, or other overuse injuries common in athletes who participate in multiple sports. The fact that this pain is specifically triggered by frisbee suggests there's something about the lateral cutting movements, jumping, or pivoting motions in frisbee that's aggravating your injury in a way that your regular running doesn't. Posterior tibial stress fractures are common in distance runners and typically cause pain along the inside edge of the shin bone (tibia) that can radiate into the calf area, and they often worsen with specific activities while remaining tolerable during others. The concerning aspect of your situation is that rest and strength training - the typical initial treatments for many overuse injuries - haven't provided relief, which suggests this may be more than just a minor strain or early-stage injury. Stress fractures, in particular, require more than just rest and strengthening; they need complete cessation of the aggravating activity and sometimes require extended periods of modified activity or even immobilization to heal properly. The fact that you can run without triggering the pain but frisbee causes it suggests the rotational and lateral movements in frisbee are placing stress on an area that's already compromised, preventing proper healing. You need to see a sports medicine physician or orthopedic doctor for proper evaluation, which should include X-rays and possibly an MRI or bone scan to definitively diagnose whether you have a stress fracture, tendon injury, or other condition. Continuing to play frisbee while experiencing this pain could turn a minor stress reaction into a complete fracture, which would require months of recovery instead of weeks. Until you get proper medical evaluation, you should completely avoid frisbee and any activities that trigger the pain. A sports medicine professional can provide you with a proper diagnosis, treatment plan, and guidance on when it's safe to return to full activity - don't risk a major injury by trying to push through pain that hasn't responded to conservative treatment.

question: Q. I missed my Depot shot. How would I know if I am pregnant?Hi doctor,I am on Depot injection and I missed the shot for over 10 days now. I have not started bleeding yet. When I was on the shot before, I bled when I get off the shot. Now, how would I know if I am pregnant?
human_answers: Hello. Serum beta hCG. 1. Post progesterone amenorrhea.2. Intrauterine or ectopic pregnancy. Duphaston withdrawal. Routine cyclical contraceptive. Revert back with the reports to an obstetrician and gynaecologist online.---> https://www.icliniq.com/ask-a-doctor-online/obstetrician-and-gynaecologist
chatgpt_answers: Missing your Depot shot by over 10 days significantly increases your risk of pregnancy, as the contraceptive effect of Depo-Provera begins to wear off around 12-15 weeks after the injection, and you're now in a window where ovulation could occur. The fact that you haven't started bleeding yet doesn't necessarily indicate pregnancy, as Depo-Provera can cause very irregular bleeding patterns, and some women don't resume normal menstrual cycles for several months after stopping the injections. Your previous experience of bleeding when going off the shot was likely withdrawal bleeding as hormone levels dropped, but this doesn't always happen consistently or at the same timing for every woman or every time they discontinue Depo. The most reliable way to determine if you're pregnant is to take a home pregnancy test, but timing is important. Since you're only 10 days late for your shot, if you did conceive recently, it might still be too early for a home pregnancy test to detect pregnancy hormones (hCG). Home pregnancy tests are most accurate when taken at least one week after a missed period, but since Depo can make periods very irregular or absent, this guideline is less helpful in your situation. If you've had unprotected sex since your shot was due, I'd recommend taking a home pregnancy test now for a baseline, then repeating it in another week if it's negative and you still haven't gotten your shot or started bleeding. You should also contact your healthcare provider immediately to discuss getting your next Depo shot and your pregnancy concerns. If you're not pregnant, you may still be able to get the injection, though some providers might recommend using backup contraception for a period of time. If you are pregnant, you'll need to discontinue Depo and begin prenatal care. In the meantime, use backup contraception (like condoms) if you're sexually active, as your fertility could return at any time after missing the shot. Don't wait too long to get tested and follow up with your provider - the sooner you know your pregnancy status, the sooner you can make appropriate decisions about contraception or prenatal care.

In the meantime, focus on proper wound care by keeping the affected areas clean, preventing scratching with short nails or mittens, washing hands frequently, and avoiding sharing towels, clothing, or bedding. If the current antibiotic isn't showing improvement by day 5-7, the doctor should consider switching to a different antibiotic rather than adding steroids that could compromise your daughter's ability to fight the infection.

question: Q. Kindly explain whether my cytology report shows metastatic breast cancer cells.Hi doctor,I had my cytology report from pelvic wash before hysterectomy. chatgpt_answers: Based on your cytology report findings, the cells you're describing are most likely reactive mesothelial cells rather than metastatic breast cancer cells. The key indicators supporting this interpretation are the positive calretinin staining and negative Ber-EP4 staining, which is a classic immunohistochemical pattern for mesothelial cells. Calretinin is a specific marker for mesothelial cells (cells that line body cavities like the peritoneum), while Ber-EP4 is typically positive in epithelial cancers, including breast cancer. When mesothelial cells are reactive, they become enlarged and crowded due to inflammation, infection, or mechanical irritation - which can occur from surgical procedures or other inflammatory processes in the pelvic cavity. While your history of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) understandably raises concerns about potential metastases, metastatic breast cancer cells would typically show a different immunohistochemical profile. Breast cancer cells are usually positive for epithelial markers like Ber-EP4 and negative for mesothelial markers like calretinin - essentially the opposite pattern of what your report shows. The atypical appearance described in your report likely reflects the reactive changes in these mesothelial cells rather than malignant transformation. However, given your significant cancer history, it's crucial that you discuss these results thoroughly with your oncologist and the pathologist who interpreted the slides. They have access to the complete clinical picture, can review the actual cellular morphology under the microscope, and may consider additional immunohistochemical stains if there's any diagnostic uncertainty. While the staining pattern strongly suggests benign reactive mesothelial cells, your medical team may want to correlate these findings with your imaging studies and clinical presentation to ensure comprehensive evaluation. Don't hesitate to ask for clarification or request that the slides be reviewed by a specialist if you have ongoing concerns.

If hemochromatosis or iron overload is confirmed, treatment typically involves regular phlebotomy (blood removal) to reduce iron stores, which can be highly effective when started promptly. chatgpt_answers: An 8-hour episode of isolated short-term memory loss where you appeared and acted normal but couldn't form new memories or recall recent events sounds very much like transient global amnesia (TGA), a temporary but dramatic form of memory loss that typically affects people suddenly and resolves completely within 24 hours. The fact that you were on vacation and out of your routine is actually consistent with TGA, as it's often triggered by physical or emotional stress, sudden temperature changes, physical exertion, medical procedures, or disruptions to normal routines. While TGA typically doesn't leave lasting effects and most people recover completely with no recurrence, proper evaluation is important to confirm the diagnosis and ensure there isn't an underlying condition that needs treatment. In the meantime, if you experience any similar episodes, severe headaches, weakness, vision changes, or other neurological symptoms, you should seek immediate medical attention.

question: Is "follicle size of 18mm with endometrial thickness of 5.7mm" a side effect of 'fertyl'?Hi i am 30 years old. This cycle i took fertyl 50mg starting 3 day for 5 days. human_answers: Hallow, Fertyl is clomiphene citrate. It is basically used for egg release (ovulation) where natural ovulation is a problem. It is in particular useful in Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome where the follicles are maturing to varied extent and still the ovulation failure is noted. Clomiphene citrate is also having antioestrogenic effect. So it may hamper  growth of endometrium. Hence, in women where Endometrial growth is low, gonadotropin hormones may be preferred for induction of ovulation. Endometrial thickness between 9 mm to 13 mm has proved to be most conducive for implantation of fertilized ovum or blastocyst. Ovulation occurring when endometrium is just 5.7 mm is likely to end in 'no pregnancy'.So long as the follicular size is concerned, it has been reported for many decades that the ova discharged from the follicles of size between 18 mm to 21 mm are the healthiest one and give maximum fertilization rate and continuation of pregnancy success rate. Progynova is a synthetic hormone replacement for oestrogen. It is used to build up the lining of the uterus in preparation for embryo transfer during a thaw cycle for women who do not ovulate regularly. Hence in your case, it might prove to be effective in building up the endometrium. However, you should not wait for the ovulation beyond the follicular size more than 21 mm. If it takes longer for the endometrium to grow, you may waste this cycle and start Progynova earlier in next cycle and have ovulation at proper follicular size. I hope this information is useful to you for further decisions. Dr. Nishikant Shrotri

question: What is the treatment of bumps around mouth and chin ?My daughter has pimply bumps around her mouth and on her chin.  She also has a stuffy nose, headache, and overall feels terrible. The main symptom of impetigo is reddish sores, often around the nose and mouth. The sores quickly rupture, ooze for a few days and then form a honey-colored crust, and sores can appear around the mouth or nose, neck, hands or diaper area. Impetigo is a highly contagious bacterial skin infection commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus or group A streptococcus, which explains why both daughters have similar symptoms and why it's responding to antibiotic treatment. The systemic symptoms like stuffy nose and headache could indicate that the bacterial infection is more extensive or that your daughter may have developed complications, though these are generally rare with impetigo. Oral antibiotics such as cephalosporins, clindamycin and sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim™) are effective treatments, with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole being particularly effective against MRSA. It's crucial that you take your daughter to see a healthcare provider immediately for proper diagnosis and treatment, as impetigo requires prescription antibiotics to clear properly and prevent spread to others. The doctor can determine if the same sulfa antibiotic that helped your other daughter is appropriate, or if a different antibiotic would be better based on the specific presentation. Until you can see a doctor, keep the affected areas clean, avoid touching the sores, wash hands frequently, and keep your daughter's towels and clothing separate to prevent further spread within the household.

It took my breath away and now I cannot put any weight one it, It still hurts. Why? and What?
human_answers: Hi,Thanks  for  your query.From your symptoms, it seems that you are suffering from plantar fasciitis. It happens due to inflammation of the plantar fascia.It hurts the most with the first few steps in the morning because the plantar fascia is tight and has not stretched out yet, and throughout the day it loosens up. The best thing you can do is when you wake up in the morning, before getting out of bed and taking a step, give yourself a little foot rub.There are many things you can try to help your foot get better:Give your feet a rest. Cut back on activities that make your feet hurt. Try not to walk or run on hard surfaces.Use shoes with good arch support and a cushioned sole.Do toe stretches, calf stretches and towel stretches several times a day, especially when you first get up in the morning.I do hope that you have found something helpful and I will be glad to answer any further query.Take care
chatgpt_answers: The symptoms you're describing - constant Charlie horse sensations through your arch, muscle spasms, and now sudden sharp, grinding pain when stepping on the ball of your foot - suggest you may be dealing with plantar fasciitis that has potentially progressed to a more severe injury or complication. Plantar fasciitis involves inflammation of the thick band of tissue (plantar fascia) that runs along the bottom of your foot from heel to toes, and it commonly causes arch pain and muscle spasms as surrounding muscles try to compensate for the injured tissue. The constant cramping sensation you've experienced for two weeks indicates significant inflammation and muscle tension in your foot's intrinsic muscles and possibly the plantar fascia itself. However, the sudden, breath-taking grinding pain with complete inability to bear weight suggests something more serious may have occurred - potentially a plantar fascia rupture, stress fracture in one of your metatarsal bones, or severe muscle/tendon strain. The grinding sensation is particularly concerning as it could indicate bone involvement or complete tissue tear. This level of sudden, severe pain that prevents weight-bearing requires immediate medical evaluation, ideally at an urgent care center or emergency room if your pain is severe. You should avoid putting weight on the foot until you can be examined, apply ice to reduce inflammation, and elevate your foot when possible. An X-ray or MRI may be needed to rule out fractures or assess the extent of soft tissue damage, and early treatment is crucial to prevent long-term complications and ensure proper healing of whatever injury has occurred.

question: What does it mean by tropozoite: intestinal parasite seen,Pus cells: 2-4/hpf in fecalysis of my 8 months old?Hi, my sons fecalysis result shows Macroscopic examination : color: brown, consistency: watery Microscopic examination: Ova or cyst: no ova or cyst of any tropozoite: intestinal parasite seen Pus cells: 2-4/hpf Red blood cells: TNTC /hpf What is the interpretation of the above result? He is an 8 mos old.
human_answers: This is normal report.Trophizoite is a stage  of intestinal parasites.repirt says no ova , cyst or trophozoite seen.(means normal)
chatgpt_answers: The fecal examination results for your 8-month-old son indicate several concerning findings that require immediate medical attention and treatment. The presence of trophozoites (the active, motile form of intestinal parasites) means your son has an active parasitic infection in his intestinal tract. The watery consistency of the stool is consistent with parasitic gastroenteritis, which commonly causes diarrhea in infants. The finding of 2-4 pus cells per high power field indicates inflammation in the intestinal tract, which is the body's response to the parasitic infection and suggests that the intestinal lining is irritated and inflamed. The most alarming finding is TNTC (too numerous to count) red blood cells per high power field, which indicates significant bleeding in the intestinal tract - this could be from the parasites damaging the intestinal wall or from severe inflammation. In an 8-month-old infant, this combination of active parasitic infection with intestinal bleeding and inflammation is serious and requires prompt medical treatment. You should take your son to his pediatrician immediately or to a pediatric emergency department if the doctor isn't available, as infants can become dehydrated quickly from diarrhea and blood loss. The doctor will likely prescribe appropriate antiparasitic medications based on the specific type of parasite (though the report doesn't specify which parasite was identified), and your son will need close monitoring to ensure he doesn't develop dehydration or anemia from the blood loss. Additionally, proper hygiene measures will be important to prevent reinfection and protect other family members from potential exposure.

question: Suggest treatment for hematoma during pregnancyI am 7 weeks pregnant with 29X5X6 mm haemaatoma. Is it considered very big ? I had taken fertgyn 2000 inj last week and duphastone tablets for last one week. Today we consulted a second doctor and he has advised Susten injection followed by tablets. Are medications provided by both the doctors same ?
human_answers: Hi, I have gone through your question, and I think I have understood your concern. I will suggest you the best best possible treatment options. 1 )  First of all do not panic. 2 )  Take rest.  Continue with your routine pregnancy medicines ,  like anti emetics and nutritional supplements. 3 )  About your treatment - Injection Fertygyn  is human chorionic gonadotropin.  It is the hormone secreted by placenta to help and support pregnancy. Tablet Duphaston is a type of natural progesterone,  also a support hormone. Susten is a natural micronized progesterone. All the medicines are safe and helpful for pregnancy. 4 )   I usually suggest following treatment to my patients with similar condition -Injection like Fertygyn, 5000 I U once a week till 14 weeks of the pregnancy. Tablet Duphaston  or Susten  200  twice a day   till 14 weeks. Also Vitamin C 500 mg twice a day for ten days.  Tab Pause 500 mg 3 times a day for 5 days. I will suggest you to take rest.  Be calm, think positive. All things will be fine. May God bless you with a bundle of joy. I hope this answer helps you. Thanks Dr Purushottam Neurgaonkar
chatgpt_answers: A hematoma measuring 29x5x6 mm at 7 weeks of pregnancy is considered moderate in size and requires careful monitoring, though it's not classified as extremely large. A subchorionic hematoma is when blood forms between a baby's amniotic sac and the uterine wall and can cause vaginal bleeding during pregnancy, and subchorionic hemorrhage is the most common cause of vaginal bleeding in patients who are 10 to 20 weeks gestational age, making up about 11% of cases. The size and location of your hematoma will determine the risk level, and your doctors are appropriately treating you with progesterone support to help maintain the pregnancy and reduce the risk of miscarriage. Regarding the medications prescribed by both doctors, they are essentially providing the same type of treatment but in different forms. Fertgyn 2000 injection contains hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) which helps support early pregnancy, while Duphaston contains dydrogesterone (a synthetic progesterone). The second doctor's recommendation of Susten injections followed by tablets also contains progesterone (micronized progesterone). Progesterone pessaries may be offered to insert into the vagina, and if you have had any bleeding in early pregnancy, progesterone can help improve the outcome of the pregnancy. Both treatment approaches are aimed at providing hormonal support to maintain your pregnancy and help the hematoma resolve. The key difference is the route of administration - the second doctor may prefer progesterone injections initially for faster absorption, followed by oral tablets for maintenance. Both approaches are medically sound, and you should follow the advice of whichever doctor you feel most comfortable with, while ensuring regular monitoring through ultrasounds to track the hematoma's resolution and your baby's development.

question: I have two small gall bladder polyps (4-5 mm), will it create any problem in pregnancy ?I am 32 yr old male & have been detected with two small Gb polyps, 4-5 mm in size, during a routine health check. I have no other problem or symptom as per my complete health check report. A doctor has advised me to get my gall bladder removed, but I am not convinced. Pls suggest what should I do.
human_answers: Hi Shailender,Welcome to HCM.I presume the GB polyps were detected during routine ultrasound examination. I suggest you consult a gastroenterologist and most probably it will have to be doubly confirmed and if it is proved beyond doubt that you have polyp in the Gall Bladder, then yes it is advisable to have your GB removed.
chatgpt_answers: I notice there seems to be a confusion in your question - you mention having gallbladder polyps but then ask about problems in pregnancy, while also identifying yourself as a 32-year-old male. I'll address the gallbladder polyp concern, which appears to be your main issue. Small gallbladder polyps of 4-5 mm are generally considered very low risk and typically don't require surgical intervention. The current medical guidelines suggest that polyps smaller than 6 mm are usually benign and can be safely monitored with periodic ultrasounds rather than requiring immediate surgery. Most gastroenterologists and surgeons follow a wait and watch approach for polyps under 10 mm, especially when they're asymptomatic. The recommendation for gallbladder removal (cholecystectomy) for such small, asymptomatic polyps is quite aggressive and not in line with standard medical practice. Current guidelines typically recommend surgery only for polyps larger than 10 mm, those that show rapid growth (more than 2 mm in 6 months), polyps associated with gallstones, or when patients have symptoms like abdominal pain. Your hesitation about the surgery is understandable and medically justified. I would strongly recommend seeking a second opinion from another gastroenterologist or hepatobiliary surgeon before considering any surgical intervention. The appropriate management for your situation would be periodic monitoring with ultrasound every 6-12 months to ensure the polyps aren't growing rapidly. Most small gallbladder polyps remain stable throughout a person's lifetime and never cause problems, making unnecessary surgery an avoidable risk.

question: What causes reddish foreskin after having intercourse?Hi im 26 yrs old and married last two back .I am 65 kgs weight and 175 cm in height . i have clean habits no previous medical disorder . My foreskin is turned reddish at the tip of the genital and itching . This happened when i had intercourse when my wife had her menstrual periods . she had some white discharge at that time . can u please tell me a solution with any topical cream or ways to get rid of it .
human_answers: HelloThanks for your query,based on the facts that you have posted it appears that you have developed infection of your foreskin (Posthatitis) due to sexual intercourse while your wife was in her menstruation and has vaginal discharge.You need to take broad spectrum antibiotic like Cefexine along with anti inflammatory drug like Diclofenac twice daily.along with topical antibiotic ointment like Neosporin twice daily.Ensure to wash your genitals with warm water twice daily.Ensure to avoid sexual encounters till it heals up completely.Dr.Patil.
chatgpt_answers: The reddish, itchy foreskin you're experiencing after intercourse during your wife's menstrual period is likely caused by balanitis, which is inflammation of the glans (head) of the penis and foreskin. This condition can be triggered by several factors including exposure to menstrual blood (which can alter the pH balance), bacterial overgrowth, or a possible yeast infection that may have been transmitted from your wife's white discharge. The menstrual environment creates conditions that can disrupt the normal bacterial balance and cause irritation, especially if there was prolonged contact or insufficient cleaning afterward. Additionally, if your wife had a vaginal yeast infection (which white discharge can sometimes indicate), this could have been transmitted to you during intercourse. For immediate relief, you should gently clean the area with warm water and mild soap, ensuring you dry thoroughly afterward, and avoid any harsh soaps or chemicals. Over-the-counter antifungal creams like clotrimazole or miconazole can be helpful if this is a yeast-related infection, while topical hydrocortisone cream can reduce inflammation and itching. However, given that this occurred after specific circumstances and you're experiencing persistent symptoms, I strongly recommend seeing a doctor or urologist for proper diagnosis and treatment. They can determine whether this is bacterial, fungal, or simply irritation, and prescribe appropriate prescription medications if needed. In the future, consider avoiding intercourse during menstruation or using protection, ensure both partners maintain good hygiene, and if your wife continues to have unusual discharge, she should also be evaluated for possible infections that could be contributing to this issue.

question: I get blocked nosed every night, cant breatheHi, i get a blocked nosed every night and cant sleep because i cnt breathe properly, and sometimes wake up in the middle of the cos i stop breathing and get back to sleep. when i wake up every morning my nose is stuffy and sneeze alot of mucus out , and i suffer with pain above and between my eyes and my forehead. Thanks
human_answers: Hi. From your history I feel you are suffering from sinusitis and allergic rhinitis. You could take steam inhalations often and when you have nose block take Tab. Sinarest one tab at night , this will relieve the stuffy nose and headache as well, if your not allergic to medicines.But I suggest you visit an ENT  doctor for an examination of the sinus, nose for any DNS and then start treatment accordingly. Meantime avoid dust exposure and eat healthy Wish you good health
chatgpt_answers: Your symptoms strongly suggest chronic sinusitis or severe nasal congestion, possibly complicated by sleep apnea, which requires medical attention. The nightly nasal blockage that prevents proper breathing, combined with morning stuffiness, excessive mucus production, and facial pain above and between your eyes, are classic signs of sinus inflammation and congestion. The pain in your forehead and between your eyes indicates that your frontal and ethmoid sinuses are likely inflamed and possibly infected. This pattern of worsening symptoms at night when lying flat is typical because gravity no longer helps drain the sinuses, leading to increased congestion and pressure. The most concerning aspect of your symptoms is that you're waking up because you stop breathing during sleep - this could indicate sleep apnea, where nasal congestion contributes to airway obstruction during sleep. This combination of chronic sinus problems with possible sleep apnea can have serious health consequences and significantly impact your quality of life. You should see a doctor, preferably an ENT (ear, nose, throat) specialist, for proper evaluation and treatment. They may recommend imaging studies like a CT scan of your sinuses, allergy testing, or a sleep study depending on their findings. Treatment options could include nasal corticosteroid sprays, decongestants, antibiotics if there's bacterial infection, saline irrigation, or in severe cases, surgical intervention to improve sinus drainage. In the meantime, try sleeping with your head elevated, using a humidifier, and consider saline nasal rinses to help with immediate symptom relief, but medical evaluation is essential given the severity and persistence of your symptoms.

question: What causes tiny holes on outside of both ears?My son has tiny holes on outside of both ears, when he was born, the Dr got an x-ray to make sure his kidneys were fine. Since then no one has said anything about the holes. I asked our pediatrician and she said as long as they don t get infected. Should I be worried, sometimes a substance does come out, but it s not frequent.
human_answers: preauricular ear pits , or holes are defects in the outer ear during fetal development , most of them are about 1 inch depth and sometimes they are connected to sinuses .  it's important to exclude any other anomalies that the child may have , which commonly is abnormality of the kidneys, that's why a renal ultrasound is done in the newborn period. if these pits have discharge it may indicate an infection , so the use of topical antibiotics is warranted, if there is fever then your child must be checked at his pediatrician. I hope this answers your question
chatgpt_answers: The tiny holes on the outside of both ears that your son was born with are called preauricular pits or preauricular sinuses, and they are a relatively common congenital condition occurring in about 0.1-0.9% of the population in the United States (though more common in certain ethnic groups, particularly those of African and Asian descent). These small openings are remnants from embryonic development when the outer ear was forming, and they represent incomplete fusion of the six small tissue masses that normally come together to form the external ear. The fact that your doctor ordered a kidney X-ray when your son was born was appropriate, as preauricular pits are occasionally associated with other developmental abnormalities, particularly kidney problems, though the vast majority of children with these pits have completely normal kidneys and no other health issues. Your pediatrician's advice is correct - as long as the pits don't become infected, they typically don't require any treatment and are considered a benign variation. The occasional substance that comes out is usually just normal skin debris, oils, or keratin that can accumulate in these small pockets, similar to what might happen with any small skin depression. However, you should watch for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, persistent discharge (especially if it becomes thick, yellow, or foul-smelling), or if your son complains of pain or tenderness around the area. If infection does occur, it would require antibiotic treatment and possibly surgical intervention. Some families choose to have these pits surgically closed for cosmetic reasons or to prevent future infections, but this is typically not necessary from a medical standpoint unless there are recurrent infections. The pits themselves don't cause any functional problems with hearing or ear development.

question: What is the treatment for foot pain?i have foot pain that started as gout but now my doctor says it is arithritis. this started in may this year. the pain travels around both my feet; sometimes on one foot sometimes on both and when it is the ankles, normally both ankles hurt. the pain is also inconsistent.
human_answers: HelloFoot pain may be due to many reasons like gout,arthritis, calcaneal spur etc.You may need clinical correlation and X-ray of both calcaneum in lateral view.X-ray of both feet (AP view)should also be taken.You may need clinical correlation and investigations.You may need routine hemogram,random blood sugar,serum uric acid,RA factor,HsCRP etc.Treatment depend upon underlying cause.Calcaneal spur treated by analgesics,soft sleeper,alternate cold and hot water treatment.If arthritis is confirmed the you may need specific medicines for arthritis.If gouty arthritis is confirmed then you may need uricosuric medicines.Take Care,Dr.Indu Bhushan
chatgpt_answers: Your transition from gout to arthritis diagnosis suggests you may be dealing with gouty arthritis, which is actually a specific type of arthritis caused by uric acid crystal deposits in joints, or possibly another inflammatory arthritis condition that initially resembled gout. The migrating pain pattern you describe - moving between different areas of both feet and ankles - is characteristic of inflammatory arthritis conditions, including gouty arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, or other crystal arthropathies. The inconsistent nature of your pain, where it affects different joints at different times, is typical of inflammatory joint conditions rather than osteoarthritis, which tends to be more localized and consistent. Treatment for foot and ankle arthritis typically involves a multi-pronged approach including anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs like ibuprofen or naproxen), prescription medications if the inflammation is severe (such as colchicine for gout-related arthritis or disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs for other types), and lifestyle modifications including proper footwear with good arch support, weight management if applicable, and avoiding trigger foods if gout is involved (particularly high-purine foods like red meat, shellfish, and alcohol). Physical therapy, gentle exercises to maintain joint mobility, and sometimes corticosteroid injections for severe flares can also be helpful. Since your pain pattern suggests ongoing inflammatory activity, it's important to work closely with your doctor or possibly a rheumatologist to determine the exact type of arthritis you have through blood tests (including uric acid levels, inflammatory markers, and possibly rheumatoid factor), as this will guide the most appropriate long-term treatment strategy to prevent joint damage and manage your symptoms effectively.

question: What causes constant exhaustion, heart racing during exertion and stiff legs?I started to notice symptoms about one month ago. The symptoms have included: constant exhaustion, heart racing with any exertion (such as lifting something or especially when walking up any incline), nausea, and stiff or sore muscles when doing any exertion (such as heavy legs when walking up an incline or doing stairs).
human_answers: Hi your problem of exhaustion , heart racing and nausea and stiff or sore muscles on exertion may be due to over stress on your cardiac system. I would strongly recommend that you undergo complete cardiac check up and avoid any self medication
chatgpt_answers: The combination of constant exhaustion, heart racing during minimal exertion, nausea, and stiff muscles with activity could indicate several serious conditions that require immediate medical evaluation. Most of the time, heart or lung issues are to blame for these types of symptoms. The pattern you're describing - where even light activities like lifting objects or walking up inclines cause significant symptoms - suggests exercise intolerance, which can stem from cardiovascular problems like heart failure, where the heart struggles to pump adequate blood to meet your body's demands. While there are many causes of fatigue, one of them is frequently missed and misdiagnosed: postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS), which can cause rapid heart rate and exhaustion with minimal activity. Other possibilities include anemia, thyroid disorders, or emerging cardiac conditions. The fact that these symptoms appeared suddenly about a month ago and are affecting your daily functioning makes this particularly concerning. You should seek immediate medical attention for proper evaluation including blood work, heart monitoring, and potentially imaging studies, as early diagnosis and treatment of underlying cardiac or systemic conditions can be crucial for your health and recovery.

question: Why is my bilirubin level elevated to a level of 7.4?My bilirubin was 7.4 has never been elevated, I do have fatty liver , high cholesterol and sugar is borderline at 111 , I recently started exercising due to needing to lose weight and having a sedentary job- the provider says we will recheck it again in two weeks but I am so worried and reading things on the internet that have me in a panic. My bilirubin has never been elevated before but LFT s were slightly.
human_answers: Hi, High bilirubin could be due to liver involvement in fatty liver.But before labeling it due to fatty liver you need to investigate as follow. -HBsAg Elisa-Anti-HCV ELISA Test-Anti-HAV antibodies-Anti-HEV antibody-Peripheral smear examination report and CBC All these investigations is to rule out hepatitis and hemolytic anemia.If already done this report than Kindly attach it. Hope I have answered your query.Let me know if I can assist you further. Regards,Dr. Parth Goswami,General & Family Physician
chatgpt_answers: A bilirubin level of 7.4 mg/dL is significantly elevated (normal is typically under 1.2 mg/dL), and while this is understandably concerning, there are several potential explanations given your medical history that don't necessarily indicate the worst-case scenarios you may be reading about online. If your bilirubin levels are higher than normal, it's a sign that either your red blood cells are breaking down at an unusual rate or that your liver is not clearing the bilirubin from your bloodstream. In your case, with existing fatty liver disease and slightly elevated liver function tests, the elevation could be related to your liver's reduced ability to process bilirubin effectively. Interestingly, your recent start of exercise and weight loss efforts are positive steps, as fatty liver can improve with lifestyle changes. The elevation might also be due to Gilbert's syndrome (a benign genetic condition affecting bilirubin processing), medication effects, dehydration from new exercise routines, or a temporary stress on your liver from metabolic changes as you lose weight. Your provider's plan to recheck in two weeks is appropriate because bilirubin levels can fluctuate, and trending the numbers over time provides much more meaningful information than a single elevated reading. While it's natural to worry, try to avoid internet searches that often present worst-case scenarios - your healthcare provider is monitoring this appropriately and will guide you through any necessary additional testing if the levels remain elevated.

question: Q. Kindly suggest the glasses that can be used while working on laptop.Hello doctor,I am 27 years old, male, pursuing PG. This is the dissertation writing time for me. For that, I have to rely on a laptop most of the time. It makes my eyes uncomfortable (red and dry). So, would be glad to have suggestions. Any glasses that I could use while working on a laptop?
human_answers: Hi. People who spend much time in front of digital screens like a laptop, mobiles, etc., are at higher risk of developing dry eyes also called computer eye syndrome. Usually, we blink 8 to 12 times per minute but while using digital devices blink rate is decreased 2 to 3 times per minute. That is why tear film is disturbed and eyes get dry. So keep using Refresh Tears and try to modify the habits like blinking every 10 to 15 seconds during laptop use and try to avoid any humid environment. I hope these simple things will help you a lot.
chatgpt_answers: For your laptop work during dissertation writing, while blue light blocking glasses are widely marketed for computer eye strain, there is no scientific evidence that the kind or amount of light coming from computer screens is damaging to the eyes according to the American Academy of Ophthalmology. However, your red and dry eye symptoms are very real and common during extended computer use. The more effective solutions focus on proper computer ergonomics and eye care habits rather than special glasses. Make sure your screen is about 20-26 inches away from your eyes and positioned slightly below eye level to reduce strain. Follow the 20-20-20 rule: every 20 minutes, look at something 20 feet away for 20 seconds to give your eyes a break. Increase your blink rate consciously, as we tend to blink less when concentrating on screens, leading to dry eyes. Adjust your screen brightness to match your surroundings, use proper lighting to avoid glare, and consider using artificial tears if dryness persists. If you still want to try computer glasses, brands like GUNNAR, JINS, or basic blue light filtering glasses from retailers can provide some users with subjective comfort, even though the scientific evidence for blue light being harmful is limited. Most importantly, take regular breaks from your laptop work - your eyes and overall health will benefit more from periodic rest than from any special eyewear.

chatgpt_answers: The severe, roaming mouth pain you're experiencing that dentists can't identify an obvious cause for sounds very much like trigeminal neuralgia, a nerve condition that commonly affects the face and mouth area. Trigeminal neuralgia is often diagnosed by a dentist, but if you have seen a dentist and they could not find an obvious cause of your pain, you should visit a GP because this condition requires neurological evaluation rather than dental treatment. Trigeminal neuralgia causes intense, sharp, electric shock-like pain that can move around different areas of the face and mouth, often triggered by light touch, chewing, or speaking. The condition may be caused by a blood vessel pressing against the trigeminal nerve, also known as vascular compression, which explains why dentists can't see any structural problems in your mouth despite the severe pain. Since you can't take Advil, it's particularly important to see a neurologist or your primary care physician, as trigeminal neuralgia typically responds better to specific neurological medications like anticonvulsants (such as carbamazepine/Tegretol) rather than standard pain relievers. The good news is that while this condition is extremely painful, it's treatable with the right medications, and in cases where medication doesn't provide sufficient relief, there are surgical options available. Don't let your dentist's inability to find a cause discourage you from seeking proper neurological care for what sounds like a nerve condition rather than a dental problem.

question: Is IRBBB dangerous?my 11 yr old son was told he has IRBBB. Naturally as parents we are so stressed. He is VERY athletic and loves sports. The main concern is whether oral GABA can actually reach your brain where it needs to work. When taken by mouth, GABA may not be able to cross the blood-brain barrier. chatgpt_answers: Safe amalgam removal requires following the SMART (Safe Mercury Amalgam Removal Technique) protocol developed by the International Academy of Oral Medicine and Toxicology, as the process of drilling out amalgam fillings liberates quantities of mercury vapor and fine particulates that can be inhaled and absorbed through the lungs, and this is potentially harmful to patients, dentists. The SMART protocol includes several critical protective measures: a properly-sealed respiratory barrier used by the dentist and all dental personnel, a full body impermeable barrier for the patient, and external air or oxygen delivered via a nasal mask to ensure the patient does not inhale any mercury vapor or amalgam particulate during the procedure. Additionally, the amalgam needs to be sectioned into chunks and removed in as large pieces as possible using a small diameter carbide drill, with less drilling meaning there is a dramatic decrease in the amount of mercury vapors created during removal. Regarding tooth extraction versus amalgam removal, extracting the entire tooth would theoretically avoid the drilling process that creates the most mercury vapor exposure, but this is generally not recommended unless the tooth is already severely damaged or non-restorable. Research shows that drilling dental amalgam generates particulate that volatilizes significant amounts of mercury vapor generally for more than an hour after removal, which is why the protective protocols are so important. If you experienced terrible side effects after your previous three amalgam removals despite working with a dentist, this suggests either the SMART protocol wasn't fully followed or you may be particularly sensitive to mercury exposure. It's crucial to find a SMART-certified dentist who strictly adheres to all protective measures, including high-volume evacuation systems, copious water irrigation, rubber dam isolation, and proper air filtration. Before proceeding with any further amalgam removal, wait for your blood test results to establish baseline mercury levels and discuss them with both your physician and a SMART-certified dentist. Most importantly, do not attempt to have amalgams removed by any dentist who doesn't follow the complete SMART protocol, as improper removal can actually increase mercury exposure significantly compared to leaving the fillings in place.

question: Is it dangerous to have sickle beta thalassimia disease repeatedly?I have sickle beta thalassimia diease and I have had a sickle crisis before and I have been having them for almost 2 years repeated ly is this dangerous.
