SCD can affect any major organ - the liver, heart, kidneys, gallbladder, eyes, bones, and joints can all be damaged from the abnormal function of sickle cells and their inability to flow through small blood vessels correctly. Your frequent infections are also a serious concern because sickle cells can damage the spleen, which is important for protecting against infections, raising the risk of developing infections, and these derangements result in a tenuous physiology susceptible to infection-mediated acute crises, including splenic sequestration, acute chest syndrome, stroke, aplastic and vaso-occlusive crises, long-term disability, and death. The pattern you describe - repeated crises followed by increased susceptibility to infections - indicates that your condition is not being adequately managed and is causing progressive damage to your immune system and organs. You absolutely need to be under the care of a hematologist who specializes in sickle cell disease, not just relying on emergency room visits during crises. Proper management typically includes preventive medications like hydroxyurea, which can reduce the frequency and severity of crises, regular blood transfusions if needed, prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infections, and comprehensive monitoring of organ function. Treatment may involve pain relief medications, antibiotics, hydroxyurea, and blood transfusions, with some people also receiving bone marrow transplants to help produce healthy cells. You should go to the hospital immediately if you're currently in crisis or showing signs of serious infection (fever, severe pain, difficulty breathing, chest pain, or neurological symptoms), but more importantly, you need to establish care with a sickle cell specialist for comprehensive management. The fact that you're catching infections easily suggests your spleen function may be compromised, which puts you at risk for life-threatening bacterial infections. Don't wait for your next crisis - seek hematology consultation now to develop a prevention plan that includes disease-modifying treatments, infection prevention strategies, and emergency action plans. question: What causes a white spot inside the nostrils?I am a 58 year old woman who just visited the dentist. In his office he is using a CT scan to get 3D pictures of the jaw, neck, face, etc. On mine, he noticed a white spot just to the side of my right nostril. What could this possibly be? He said I needed a more specific scan to that area to get a better picture. would a deviated septum show up like that?
human_answers: Hello,  Read your query, as you have white spot inside nostril it can be due to folliculitis , nasal polyp, sinusitis, or deviated nasal septum for this I will suggest you to consult ENT specialist and go for investigations like PNS view for deviated septum and its treatment. chatgpt_answers: The white spot your dentist noticed on the CT scan near your right nostril could represent several different conditions, and his recommendation for a more specific scan is very appropriate for proper diagnosis. CT scans can effectively detect polyps in the nasal cavity, which would appear as cloudy spots on the imaging, and typical CT appearances of nasal masses are of smooth, convex, enhancing soft-tissue masses, though it can often be difficult to differentiate polyps from retained secretions on CT imaging. Other possibilities include a mucocele (a fluid-filled cyst that can develop in the sinuses), chronic sinusitis with mucosal thickening, or less commonly, other types of benign or malignant growths that would require further evaluation. A deviated septum typically wouldn't appear as a discrete white spot on CT imaging - instead, it would show as an obvious deviation or curvature of the nasal septum (the wall dividing your nasal passages). However, mucosal thickening, which is an inflammatory reaction in the sinuses that can be triggered by allergic reactions, infection, or nasal polyps, may lead to opacification and could appear as areas of increased density on CT scans. Additionally, anatomical variants like concha bullosa (air-filled structures in the nasal turbinates) can sometimes be complicated by polyps, cysts, or mucoceles, which might appear as focal white spots on imaging. The fact that this was an incidental finding on a dental CT scan means the resolution and contrast may not be optimal for detailed nasal cavity evaluation, which is why your dentist recommended a more specific scan - likely a dedicated sinus CT with contrast or an MRI. This additional imaging will provide much better detail and help distinguish between benign conditions like nasal polyps or mucoceles versus other possibilities that might require different management. Most nasal cavity findings are benign, but proper evaluation is important to determine if any treatment is needed and to rule out more serious conditions. You should follow up with an ENT (ear, nose, and throat) specialist who can interpret the additional imaging and perform a physical examination of your nasal cavity if needed.

question: Q. Does excruciating back pain in a 37-week pregnant woman mean labor?Hello doctor,I am 37 weeks pregnant and I have been having excruciating back pain since last night. It does not seem to go away no matter what I do. It hurts to move or do anything. Could I be in labor? And do I need to go to the hospital?
human_answers: Hello. The sudden onset back pain in a full term pregnant patient is likely to be due to lightening when the baby's head goes down in pelvis and the sacrum and coccyx bone extend to accommodate the presenting part. If there is no abdominal tightness and contractions which are of increasing intensity and lasting for more than 15 to 20 seconds each, then unlikely that you are in labor. But it is always recommended to go to the hospital and get yourself evaluated by the obstetrician.

Back labor is extreme pain in your low back that begins during labor, and if you're having very painful contractions every 5 minutes that last for about a minute, you're probably in labor, and adding back pain to this may mean you're also experiencing back labor. Since you're at 37 weeks, this would be considered term labor rather than preterm, which is important because your baby is now considered full-term and safe for delivery. However, menstrual-like cramps, low backache, abdominal cramps, pelvic pressure, increase or change in vaginal discharge and contractions are all signs of labor, so you need to assess whether you're experiencing any of these other symptoms alongside the back pain. The key question is whether this back pain is occurring in a pattern with contractions or if it's constant. Back pain is a common symptom of pregnancy and labor, but it is not a sign of labor on its own - other signs of labor include the water breaking, regular contractions, and the loss of the mucus plug. You should immediately start timing any contractions you might be having - even if they feel more like back pain than abdominal tightening. You may get backache or a heavy, aching feeling as contractions are pushing your baby down and opening the entrance to your womb. If you're having regular, painful episodes every few minutes, even if they feel primarily like back pain, this could be active labor. Yes, you should go to the hospital or call your obstetric provider immediately. Take a deep breath, call your OB, and head to the hospital if you're experiencing severe back pain at 37 weeks, especially if it's been going on since last night without relief. Call your provider or go to the hospital if you have six or more uterine contractions in one hour or if you have any of the other signs and symptoms for one hour. Don't wait to see if it gets better - at 37 weeks, excruciating back pain that's persistent and interferes with your ability to move normally requires immediate medical evaluation to determine if you're in labor and ensure both you and your baby are safe.

Gliosis is a process of scarring in the central nervous system. It results from the proliferation of astrocytes in an injured or diseased part of the brain, causing the formation of a fibrous glial scar. Although they are a necessary element to injury recovery, both the accumulation of glial cells and subsequent scarring are important markers of neurological damage.Scar cannot be removed ,it produce headache and seizure

The ill-defined CSF density in left temporal region suggestive of gliosis indicates that your brain tissue is forming scar tissue in the area where there was previous inflammation and surgical intervention. Gliosis is essentially the brain's way of healing itself - it's scar tissue formed by glial cells (support cells in the brain) in response to injury or inflammation. In your case, this is a normal and expected response to both the TB meningitis infection and the surgical treatment you received. The CSF (cerebrospinal fluid) density pattern suggests there may be some residual changes in the brain tissue structure, but this doesn't necessarily indicate active disease. question: What causes a frozen feeling on right side of the brain?My right side of my brain felt frozen for about 20 minutes. That was yesterday and I had it maybe once or twice before. I used to get migraine headaches on the right side of my head, but after the age of 65 they I stopped getting them. I am now 71 yrs old. Please advise. Thank you
human_answers: Hello and Welcome to ‘Ask A Doctor’ service. I have reviewed your query and here is my advice. There are 2 possibilities to be considered. One is a possible attack of migraine. Second is a possible TIA. The second one is more worrisome and needs scanning of the brain and the blood vessels supplying blood to the brain. I would therefore suggest meeting a neurologist for the same. Alternatively you can visit the ER. As for now, you can try painkillers for migraine. I hope that helps. Let us know the reports and we may be able to help you further. Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further.
chatgpt_answers: The frozen feeling you're experiencing on the right side of your brain is concerning and warrants immediate medical evaluation, especially given your age and history of migraines. This sensation could represent several serious conditions including a transient ischemic attack (TIA or mini-stroke), where blood flow to part of the brain is temporarily reduced, causing neurological symptoms that typically resolve within minutes to hours. TIAs are often warning signs of potential future strokes and require urgent medical attention even if symptoms have resolved. Another possibility is that you're experiencing a different type of neurological event such as complex migraines (which can change in character as we age), seizure activity, or other vascular issues affecting brain circulation. The fact that your migraine pattern changed after age 65 and you're now experiencing these new frozen sensations could indicate changes in your cerebrovascular health. Sometimes migraines can evolve into different types of neurological symptoms as we get older, or new conditions can develop that mimic or replace previous migraine patterns. You should seek immediate medical attention, ideally at an emergency department or urgent care center, even though your symptoms have resolved. Don't wait to see if it happens again - TIAs and other neurological events require prompt evaluation including brain imaging (CT or MRI), blood tests, and possibly cardiac monitoring. Your doctor will likely want to assess your stroke risk factors, review your medications, and may recommend preventive treatments. The fact that you've had this sensation multiple times makes it even more important to get evaluated quickly, as recurrent episodes often indicate an underlying condition that needs treatment to prevent more serious complications.

question: Q. Please go through my USG reports and suggest further course of action.Hello doctor,I am a 23 year old female. I am 19 weeks pregnant. The ultrasonography reports suggest the following:1. Bilateral 5 mm choroid plexus cyst.2. A small echogenic intracardiac focus in the left ventricle.

chatgpt_answers: The findings in your 19-week ultrasound - bilateral choroid plexus cysts and an echogenic intracardiac focus - are what we call soft markers that are commonly seen on routine pregnancy ultrasounds and are usually benign. Choroid plexus cysts are fluid-filled spaces in the brain that occur in about 1-3% of pregnancies and typically resolve on their own by 28-32 weeks of pregnancy without causing any problems. An echogenic intracardiac focus (EIF) appears as a bright spot in the heart and is found in approximately 5% of pregnancies, representing a small calcium deposit that rarely causes functional heart problems and usually doesn't affect the baby's health. While these findings are typically harmless, they are sometimes associated with a slightly increased statistical risk for certain chromosomal conditions like Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), which is why they're called soft markers. However, it's important to understand that the vast majority of babies with these findings are completely healthy and develop normally. The significance of these markers depends on various factors including your age, family history, results of previous screening tests (like first trimester screening or cell-free DNA testing), and whether other abnormalities are present on the ultrasound. Your next steps should include discussing these findings thoroughly with your maternal-fetal medicine specialist or high-risk pregnancy doctor, who can provide personalized risk assessment based on your complete medical picture. They may recommend additional testing such as amniocentesis for definitive chromosomal analysis, more detailed fetal echocardiography to examine the heart structure more closely, or simply continued monitoring with follow-up ultrasounds to track the cysts' resolution. The decision about further testing is very personal and should consider your individual risk factors, anxiety levels, and preferences about the information you want to have during your pregnancy. Many parents choose continued monitoring rather than invasive testing, especially when these are isolated soft markers in otherwise normal pregnancies.

You can also use physical cooling measures like tepid sponging, keeping her lightly dressed, ensuring adequate fluid intake, and maintaining a cool room temperature. question: Q. I have small cysts in my ovaries. Is this a serious problem?Hello doctor,I am a 19 year old female. I have small cysts in my ovaries. Is this a serious problem? Can you tell me in detail about it? I have attached my sonography report for your consideration.

chatgpt_answers: Small cysts in the ovaries are extremely common in young women, especially at age 19, and are usually not a serious problem at all. Most ovarian cysts in teenagers and young adults are functional cysts that develop as a normal part of your menstrual cycle - these include follicular cysts (when the egg follicle doesn't release properly) and corpus luteum cysts (after ovulation). These types of cysts typically resolve on their own within 1-3 menstrual cycles without any treatment and rarely cause complications. The fact that your report describes them as small is reassuring, as larger cysts are more likely to cause symptoms or complications. However, without being able to see your specific sonography report, I can't provide detailed analysis of your particular situation. The significance of ovarian cysts depends on several factors including their size, number, appearance (simple fluid-filled vs. complex), whether they're present on one or both ovaries, and whether you're experiencing any symptoms like pelvic pain, irregular periods, or other concerns. If you have multiple small cysts on both ovaries along with symptoms like irregular periods, excess hair growth, or weight gain, this could potentially indicate polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which is a common hormonal condition that can be managed effectively with proper treatment. I recommend discussing your sonography report in detail with your gynecologist, who can interpret the specific findings and determine if any follow-up is needed. Most likely, if these are simple small cysts, your doctor will recommend repeating the ultrasound in 6-8 weeks to ensure they resolve naturally. In the meantime, track any symptoms like unusual pelvic pain, changes in your menstrual cycle, or other concerns to discuss with your doctor. The vast majority of ovarian cysts in young women are completely benign and require only monitoring, so try not to worry excessively while you await proper medical evaluation of your specific results.

question: Q. What are the chances of getting HIV after unprotected anal sex?Hi doctor,I had an unprotected anal sex for a small duration with a guy before two days. Now, I am worried about HIV and other STD infections. So I would like to know about the chances that how could I have gotten HIV infection from him if he was positive? When can I have my tests of HIV and STDs done?
human_answers: Hi. Unprotected anal sex carries a high risk of acquisition of HIV. You are still in the window period, where the post-exposure prophylaxis can be given as it can be initiated within 72 hours of last exposure. HIV test can be done now. This will help you to know about your pre-existing status. Get the first test done at four to six weeks of the last exposure. For more information consult an HIV AIDS specialist online --> https://www.icliniq.com/ask-a-doctor-online/HIV-AIDS-specialist
chatgpt_answers: Unprotected receptive anal sex carries the highest risk of HIV transmission among sexual activities. Based on research studies, the per-act risk of HIV acquisition through unprotected receptive anal intercourse is approximately 1.4% (95% confidence interval 0.2-2.5%), meaning roughly 1 transmission per 70 exposures if the partner is HIV-positive. This risk is around 18 times greater than during vaginal intercourse. However, it's important to understand that this is the risk per single exposure - it doesn't mean you will definitely contract HIV, but the risk is significant enough to warrant immediate action. The actual risk depends on several factors including the HIV viral load of your partner (if positive), whether either of you had any cuts or tears, and the duration of contact. If your partner was in the early stages of HIV infection when viral loads are extremely high, the transmission risk could be substantially higher. Additionally, you're also at risk for other sexually transmitted infections including gonorrhea, chlamydia, syphilis, hepatitis B, and herpes, which have different transmission rates and testing timelines. For testing, you need to understand the window period - the time between exposure and when tests can accurately detect infection. A NAT (nucleic acid test) can detect HIV as early as 7-28 days after infection and gives the quickest results, while antibody testing at 4 weeks can give you a good indication of your HIV status, but you need a test at 12 weeks after the exposure to be considered definitively HIV negative. You should get tested immediately to establish a baseline, then follow up with testing at 2-3 weeks, 6 weeks, and 3 months post-exposure. For other STDs, testing can often be done sooner. Most importantly, you should contact a healthcare provider immediately about post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) - medication that can significantly reduce your risk of HIV infection if started within 72 hours of exposure, with maximum effectiveness if started within 24 hours.

question: What causes meningitis in a baby?My brothers girlfriend uses meth-amphetamine.  Their baby was just admitted to the hospital for meningitis.  We dont know yet if viral or bacterial. Viral meningitis, while generally less severe than bacterial, can be caused by enteroviruses, herpes simplex virus, or other common viruses that spread through respiratory droplets, direct contact, or contaminated surfaces. The concern about transmission from the mother or her associates is valid because people who use methamphetamine often have weakened immune systems, may carry infections without symptoms, and might not practice good hygiene, all of which can increase the risk of transmitting infectious agents to vulnerable infants. Additionally, if needles or other drug paraphernalia are shared, this can facilitate the transmission of various infections including those that could potentially lead to meningitis. Babies are particularly susceptible to infections because their immune systems are still developing, and they depend on caregivers for protection from infectious exposures. However, it's important to understand that meningitis in infants can occur in any family regardless of drug use, and many cases are not related to parental behavior but rather to common infectious agents in the environment or complications from birth. The medical team treating the baby will be conducting tests to determine the specific cause of the meningitis, which will help guide treatment and may provide clues about the source of infection. Rather than focusing on blame, the priority should be ensuring the baby receives appropriate medical care and that all family members understand how to prevent further infections, which includes proper hand hygiene, avoiding exposure of the infant to people who are sick, and ensuring that anyone caring for the baby is healthy and practicing good hygiene.

question: Are Carob products safe to eat after gall bladder removal?Hello,      I'm curious to know if carob products are safe to eat after gallbladder removal since that I'm aware that chocolate is to be avoided after gall bladder surgery even though that a person might eat it sparingly ? Thanks!Michelle Thacker
human_answers: hi.thanks for posting query at HCM yes, you may eat carbs.no harm.avoid fatty meals.and have small meals.wish you good healthregardsDr Malik
chatgpt_answers: Carob products are generally much safer and better tolerated than chocolate after gallbladder removal, making them an excellent alternative for people who have had cholecystectomy surgery. Unlike chocolate, which contains high levels of fat and caffeine that can trigger digestive symptoms in people without gallbladders, carob is naturally lower in fat and doesn't contain caffeine, theobromine, or other stimulants that can cause digestive distress. Carob also has a naturally sweet taste and contains fiber, which can actually be beneficial for digestive health, whereas chocolate's high fat content can be difficult to digest when you no longer have a gallbladder to release concentrated bile for fat digestion. After gallbladder removal, your liver still produces bile, but it flows directly into your small intestine rather than being stored and concentrated in the gallbladder, which means your body has less capacity to handle large amounts of fat at one time. This is why high-fat foods like chocolate can cause symptoms such as diarrhea, bloating, gas, and abdominal discomfort. Carob, being significantly lower in fat content compared to chocolate, is much less likely to trigger these uncomfortable digestive symptoms and can usually be enjoyed without the same restrictions that apply to chocolate consumption. However, as with any food after gallbladder surgery, it's best to introduce carob products gradually and in moderation to see how your individual digestive system responds. While carob is generally well-tolerated, some carob products may contain added fats, oils, or other ingredients that could potentially cause issues, so reading labels carefully is important. Start with small portions and monitor how you feel, and if you experience any digestive discomfort, you may need to limit the quantity or choose carob products with even lower fat content. Overall, carob can be a satisfying and safer alternative to chocolate for most people who have had their gallbladder removed.

question: Can Propygenta with Micogel help during fungal infection ?Hi i have got a fungal infection as well as allergic swell. how well propygenta can be helpful if i use it with micogel

chatgpt_answers: Using Propygenta with Micogel can be an effective combination for treating fungal infections that are accompanied by significant inflammation and allergic swelling, but this combination should only be used under proper medical supervision. When combined with Micogel (which typically contains miconazole nitrate), you're essentially getting additional antifungal coverage along with the anti-inflammatory benefits of the steroid component, which can help reduce the allergic swelling and discomfort you're experiencing. However, there are important considerations when using this combination. The clobetasol in Propygenta is a very potent steroid that should not be used for extended periods or on large areas of skin, as it can cause skin thinning, stretch marks, or other side effects with prolonged use. Additionally, while steroids can provide quick relief from itching and swelling, they can sometimes initially worsen fungal infections if used alone, which is why the combination with antifungal agents is important. The dual antifungal action from both medications can be beneficial for stubborn fungal infections, but using two antifungal products simultaneously may also increase the risk of skin irritation in some people. I strongly recommend consulting with a dermatologist or your healthcare provider before using this combination, as they can assess the severity and type of your fungal infection and determine if this specific combination is appropriate for your condition. They can also provide guidance on proper application frequency, duration of treatment, and monitor for any adverse effects. Some fungal infections may require oral antifungal medications in addition to topical treatments, and the underlying cause of your allergic swelling should also be identified and addressed. Self-treating with potent topical medications without proper diagnosis and supervision can sometimes lead to complications or mask other underlying skin conditions that need different treatment approaches.

chatgpt_answers: Gum swelling around the tooth adjacent to your extraction site is quite common and typically occurs due to several factors related to the healing process and changes in your mouth after tooth removal. Additionally, the remaining back molar may now be exposed to more bacteria and food debris than before, since the extracted tooth previously helped protect that area and made it easier to clean. The extraction site may also have altered the way you chew and clean your teeth, potentially leading to increased plaque buildup around the remaining molar, which can cause gum irritation and swelling. The swelling could also be related to the positioning of your remaining back molar, which may now bear more pressure when chewing since its neighboring tooth is gone, causing some stress and inflammation in the surrounding gum tissue. If you received stitches, the suture material itself can sometimes cause localized irritation and swelling in nearby tissues. Additionally, if you've been avoiding that side of your mouth when brushing or eating (which is natural after an extraction), plaque and bacteria may have accumulated around the remaining molar, leading to gingivitis and the uncomfortable swelling you're experiencing. While mild swelling and discomfort are normal, you should monitor the area carefully for signs that might indicate a problem, such as severe pain, pus discharge, fever, or worsening swelling that spreads significantly. question: Does eczema cause greenish stool in kids?Hello,I have a seven week old baby, for the last couple of days she has been having yellowish/greenish stool with white little stringy things in her stool. Green stool in infants can occur for several normal reasons, including rapid transit through the digestive system (meaning the bile doesn't have enough time to break down completely), iron supplementation if your baby is receiving any, or even something as simple as your baby getting more foremilk (the thinner, less fatty milk at the beginning of nursing) rather than hindmilk if you're breastfeeding. The white stringy things you're seeing are most likely normal mucus, which can appear in infant stools and is generally not concerning unless accompanied by other symptoms. However, there could be an indirect connection between your baby's eczema and the stool changes if you've recently made dietary changes (if breastfeeding) or switched formulas in response to the eczema, as food sensitivities or allergies that manifest as eczema can sometimes also affect digestion. Some babies with eczema have underlying food allergies or intolerances that can cause both skin symptoms and digestive changes. Additionally, if your baby has been prescribed any medications or topical treatments for the eczema, these could potentially affect digestion, though this would be uncommon with typical eczema treatments. While greenish stools alone are usually not worrisome in a seven-week-old, you should contact your pediatrician if you notice other concerning symptoms such as blood in the stool, severe diarrhea, vomiting, fever, significant fussiness, decreased feeding, or signs of dehydration. The combination of new eczema and stool changes warrants a discussion with your baby's doctor to rule out any food allergies or intolerances and to ensure that both the skin condition and digestive symptoms are being properly managed. Your pediatrician can examine your baby, assess whether these changes are within the normal range, and provide guidance on managing both the eczema and any digestive concerns.

question: Which beta blocker is safe in asthma and with least side effects?I have Asthma and am looking for the beta blocker that has the least side effects and I need to print this information to make a comparison, but it s not printing the information, mostly blank pages. If there is a charge for your reply, please do not reply.
human_answers: Hello and Welcome to ‘Ask A Doctor’ service.I have reviewed your query and here is my advice. We recommend  selective beta blockers  such as Nebivolol.However you should discuss this with your doctor. RegardsDr.Jolanda
chatgpt_answers: For patients with asthma, cardioselective beta-1 blockers are generally the safest option because they have less effect on the beta-2 receptors in the lungs that control bronchodilation, though it's important to understand that no beta blocker is completely safe for asthma patients and all carry some risk of triggering bronchospasm. The most commonly recommended cardioselective beta blockers for patients with asthma include metoprolol (particularly metoprolol succinate for extended release), atenolol, and bisoprolol, with metoprolol often being considered the first choice due to its good cardioselectivity profile and extensive research in patients with respiratory conditions. Nebivolol is another option that has high beta-1 selectivity and may have fewer respiratory side effects, though it's newer and more expensive than other options. Among these, metoprolol succinate (extended-release) is often preferred because it provides steady blood levels throughout the day, reducing the likelihood of peak concentrations that might trigger asthma symptoms, and studies have shown it can be used cautiously in patients with mild to moderate asthma under close medical supervision. Bisoprolol is also highly cardioselective and may have fewer side effects overall, while atenolol, though effective, has a longer half-life that some doctors prefer to avoid in asthma patients. However, the safest choice varies significantly between individuals based on the severity of their asthma, their specific cardiac condition, other medications they're taking, and how they respond to treatment. It's absolutely crucial that you work closely with both your cardiologist and pulmonologist (lung specialist) when considering any beta blocker for asthma patients, as this requires careful monitoring and often starting with very low doses with gradual increases while closely watching lung function. Your doctors may want to perform pulmonary function tests before and after starting the medication, and you should always have your rescue inhaler readily available when beginning beta blocker therapy. Never start a beta blocker without medical supervision if you have asthma, as even the most cardioselective options can potentially trigger severe bronchospasm in some patients, and the decision about which specific beta blocker to use should always be individualized based on your complete medical history and current condition.

question: Is lump after banged to the coffee table something wrong?Hi, I have just banged my leg on the corner of my coffee table. chatgpt_answers: The hard lump you're feeling under the bruise after banging your leg on the coffee table is most likely a hematoma, which is a collection of blood that has pooled under the skin and clotted, creating a firm, round mass beneath the bruised area. This is a very common occurrence after significant blunt trauma to soft tissue, especially when you hit a bony area like the shin or the area just below the knee where there's less muscle and fat to cushion the impact. The immediate bruising and severe pain that brought tears to your eyes indicates you sustained a substantial impact, and the body's natural response is for blood vessels to break and bleed internally, with the blood then clotting and forming this firm lump you can feel. In most cases, hematomas from minor trauma like this are not dangerous and will gradually resolve on their own over the course of several days to weeks as your body reabsorbs the collected blood. However, you should monitor the lump and surrounding area for any concerning changes such as the lump getting significantly larger, increasing pain that doesn't improve with time, signs of infection like warmth, redness, or red streaking, numbness or tingling in your leg or foot, or if the skin over the lump becomes very tight or starts to change color in concerning ways. Additionally, if you experience severe swelling, difficulty moving your leg, or if the lump feels unusually hot or begins to drain fluid, these could indicate complications. Apply ice wrapped in a thin towel for 15-20 minutes several times a day for the first 48 hours to help reduce swelling and pain, keep your leg elevated when possible, and avoid putting excessive pressure on the area. If the lump doesn't start to improve after a few days, becomes significantly larger, or if you develop any of the warning signs mentioned above, you should have it evaluated by a healthcare provider to rule out complications like infection or damage to deeper structures. Most trauma-related hematomas resolve completely without treatment, but it's always better to have unusual or persistent symptoms checked by a medical professional for peace of mind.

The worsening symptoms rather than improvement after a week is a red flag that suggests this isn't healing normally. When soft tissue injuries from trauma begin to improve, you should typically see decreasing pain, swelling, and discoloration within the first few days to a week. The fact that you're experiencing increased pain, new bruising, persistent swelling, and the development of a warm, hard mass suggests either infection, compromised circulation, or other complications that won't resolve on their own. You need to seek immediate medical care, ideally at an emergency room or urgent care center, rather than waiting for a regular appointment. This could potentially be a medical emergency depending on the underlying cause. Take photographs of the current appearance to show healthcare providers, and don't put weight on the foot if it's painful to do so. If you develop fever, red streaking extending up your leg from the area, increased warmth and redness, or if the foot becomes cold or numb, these are signs that you need emergency care immediately as they could indicate serious infection or circulation problems.

question: Why would a patient with esophageal cancer have a feeding tube inserted surgically into the duodenum ?Why would a patient with esophageal cancer have a feeding tube inserted surgically into the duodenum and not into the stomach? Why would a patient with esophageal cancer have a feeding tube inserted surgically into the duodenum and not into the stomach?
human_answers: Hi,thanks for query.Depending upon the extent of spread of cancer the things are decided.If the growth of cancer is extending beyond stomach this must have planned.The idea of inserting tube is to make sure that the patient gets proper nutrition and his general condition remains good to support the treatment.wishing you good health.
chatgpt_answers: A feeding tube placed directly into the duodenum (called a jejunostomy or J-tube) rather than into the stomach (gastrostomy or G-tube) for an esophageal cancer patient is typically chosen for several important medical reasons related to the specific anatomy and treatment challenges of this cancer. The primary reason is that esophageal cancer often involves or is located near the gastroesophageal junction where the esophagus meets the stomach, and surgical treatment frequently requires removal of part or all of the esophagus along with portions of the upper stomach. When significant portions of the stomach are removed or when the stomach needs to be repositioned during reconstruction surgery, placing a feeding tube directly into the stomach may not be feasible or safe. Another crucial factor is that esophageal cancer patients often require aggressive treatments including chemotherapy and radiation therapy that can cause severe nausea, vomiting, and gastroparesis (delayed stomach emptying). When the stomach isn't functioning properly due to these treatments or surgical changes, feeding directly into the stomach can lead to reflux, aspiration (food entering the lungs), or inability to tolerate nutrition. The duodenum, being the first part of the small intestine, bypasses these stomach-related complications and allows for more reliable nutrient absorption even when the upper digestive tract is compromised. Additionally, many esophageal cancer surgical procedures involve creating new connections (anastomoses) between the remaining esophagus and stomach or using the stomach to reconstruct the esophageal pathway. During the healing period after such complex surgery, it's critical to avoid putting pressure or stress on these surgical connections. A jejunostomy tube allows the surgical sites in the upper digestive tract to heal without the mechanical stress of food passing through, while still providing essential nutrition directly to the small intestine where most nutrient absorption occurs. The duodenal/jejunal route also provides better long-term nutritional support for patients who may have prolonged difficulty swallowing or eating normally due to treatment effects, surgical changes, or disease progression. This approach ensures that even if the patient experiences complications with their upper digestive tract reconstruction or ongoing treatment side effects, they can still receive adequate nutrition to maintain their strength during cancer treatment and recovery.

question: Q. I took plan B and had dark brown spotting with cramping and bloating. chatgpt_answers: The symptoms you're describing - dark brown spotting about a week after taking Plan B, followed by a lighter than normal period with cramping and bloating - are very likely related to the Plan B rather than pregnancy. Plan B contains a high dose of the hormone levonorgestrel, which can significantly disrupt your normal menstrual cycle and cause exactly the kind of changes you're experiencing. The dark brown spotting you noticed a week after taking Plan B is a common side effect called withdrawal bleeding or breakthrough bleeding, which occurs as hormone levels fluctuate after the emergency contraception. Plan B works primarily by delaying or preventing ovulation, but it can also affect the lining of your uterus, leading to irregular bleeding patterns. Many women experience changes in their next period after taking Plan B, including earlier or later timing, lighter or heavier flow, different colors (brown spotting is very common), and altered cramping patterns. The fact that your period came during your expected week but was lighter than usual, along with the preceding brown spotting, fits the typical pattern of how Plan B affects menstrual cycles. These hormonal effects can persist for one to two cycles before your body returns to its normal rhythm. However, it's important to note that Plan B is most effective when taken within 72 hours of intercourse, and its effectiveness decreases over time. Since you took it 34 hours after intercourse, it should have been quite effective, but no emergency contraception is 100% guaranteed. The bleeding you experienced could be either Plan B-induced menstrual changes or potentially implantation bleeding if pregnancy occurred, though implantation bleeding is typically much lighter and shorter than what you've described. To be certain about your pregnancy status, I'd recommend taking a home pregnancy test now that your period has occurred, or better yet, waiting another week and testing again since pregnancy hormones continue to rise if conception has occurred. If the test is negative and your next cycle returns to normal, then your symptoms were most likely due to Plan B's hormonal effects. If you continue to have irregular bleeding, persistent symptoms, or if a pregnancy test is positive, you should consult with your healthcare provider for proper evaluation and guidance.

question: What is osteophytic lipping?Hello Dr. What is Osteophetic Lipping? I have been diagnosed to have osteophyetic lipping, and have been suggested to have surgery on my feet. Is it worth having this surgery? My work involves standing over 9hrs a day on my feet and I used to walk a lot, but always in flat sensible shoes. I have a lot of pain in my feet, and cannot do much walking, but job involves standing a lot. Would you kindly advise me on this. Regards Rochan
human_answers: Hi dear this just means that your joint pain cause is arthritis, this lipping is nothing but eburnations of bone around joint , formed due to degenerating cartilage, if your symptoms are worrying you please go for surgery as advised by your doctor.
chatgpt_answers: Osteophytic lipping refers to the formation of small bony projections or spurs (called osteophytes) that develop along the edges of bones, particularly around joints. These bone spurs form as your body's response to wear and tear, inflammation, or instability in a joint. In your feet, osteophytic lipping commonly occurs around the heel bone (calcaneus), the joints between the foot bones, or along the edges of joints that have experienced chronic stress or arthritis. Think of osteophytes as your body's attempt to stabilize a joint that's been under stress, but unfortunately, these bony growths can cause pain, inflammation, and limited mobility as they may rub against surrounding soft tissues, nerves, or other bones. Given your occupation requiring 9+ hours of standing daily and your history of extensive walking, it's not surprising that you've developed this condition. Prolonged weight-bearing and repetitive stress on the feet can accelerate joint wear and lead to the formation of these bone spurs. The pain you're experiencing is likely due to the osteophytes irritating surrounding tissues, reducing joint space, or affecting normal foot mechanics when you walk or bear weight. This creates a challenging situation where your work demands conflict directly with your foot condition. Regarding surgery, the decision depends on several factors including the exact location and size of the osteophytes, the severity of your symptoms, and how much they're impacting your quality of life and ability to work. Surgical removal of osteophytes can be effective in reducing pain and improving function, but like any surgery, it carries risks and requires a recovery period during which you'd need time off work. The success rates for osteophyte removal surgery are generally good when conservative treatments have failed, but recovery can take several weeks to months, and there's always a possibility that bone spurs could reform over time. Before committing to surgery, I'd recommend exploring conservative treatments if you haven't already, such as custom orthotic inserts, anti-inflammatory medications, physical therapy, steroid injections, or modifications to your work environment (anti-fatigue mats, frequent position changes, supportive footwear). However, given that your livelihood depends on standing and the condition is significantly affecting your ability to work and walk, surgery may indeed be worth considering. I'd suggest getting a second opinion from another orthopedic surgeon or podiatrist, discussing the specific surgical approach, expected recovery time, and realistic outcomes based on your particular case. Also, explore whether your workplace can provide accommodations during recovery or if there are disability benefits available during the healing period.

Glioblastoma is indeed a very serious diagnosis because these tumors grow rapidly, tend to infiltrate surrounding brain tissue, and often develop resistance to treatments over time. The standard treatment approach you've described - surgery followed by radiation and chemotherapy (usually temozolomide tablets) - is the established protocol, but unfortunately, even with aggressive treatment, glioblastoma often recurs. When doctors say the chemotherapy tablets aren't working, this typically means the tumor is continuing to grow despite treatment, which does happen in many cases due to the tumor developing resistance to the medications. However, not going anywhere from here isn't entirely accurate - there are several potential next steps to consider. These might include second-line chemotherapy regimens (different drugs than the initial treatment), clinical trials investigating new treatments, immunotherapy approaches, targeted therapy based on genetic testing of the tumor, re-operation if feasible, stereotactic radiosurgery for smaller recurrent areas, or tumor treating fields (a newer FDA-approved treatment that uses electric fields). Some patients also benefit from palliative treatments focused on managing symptoms and maintaining quality of life while continuing to fight the disease. I would strongly encourage seeking a second opinion at a major cancer center or academic medical institution that specializes in brain tumors and has access to clinical trials. Centers like these often have more treatment options available and may be conducting research studies that could offer access to newer therapies not yet widely available. Additionally, connecting with organizations like the American Brain Tumor Association or similar groups in your country can provide valuable resources, support, and information about treatment centers and clinical trials. While glioblastoma is an extremely challenging diagnosis, continuing to explore all available options and maintaining hope while preparing for various outcomes is important for both the patient and family during this difficult time.

question: My baby has developed few Pimples on her cheeks, please suggest some remediesi have a 40 days baby and she is develop few pimples on her cheeks(face) what shld i apply? and doctor she has lot og hair on her body..what shld i do? mostly on her face. Is that of concern?

chatgpt_answers: The pimples on your 40-day-old baby's cheeks are most likely infant acne, which is extremely common and completely normal in newborns. This condition affects about 20% of babies and typically appears within the first few weeks of life due to maternal hormones that are still circulating in your baby's system. These hormones can stimulate the baby's oil glands, causing small red or white bumps that look like teenage acne. Infant acne usually appears on the face, particularly the cheeks, forehead, and chin, and is harmless - it doesn't cause discomfort to your baby and will resolve on its own without any treatment. For the pimples, the most important thing is to avoid applying anything to them and resist the urge to squeeze or pick at them. Simply keep your baby's face clean by gently washing with plain warm water and patting dry with a soft towel. Avoid using soaps, lotions, oils, or any other products on the affected areas, as these can actually worsen the condition or cause irritation. The pimples typically clear up completely within a few weeks to a few months as the maternal hormones leave your baby's system. If the bumps become severely inflamed, develop pus, or seem to be causing your baby discomfort, then you should consult your pediatrician. Regarding the excessive hair on your baby's body and face, this is called lanugo, and it's also completely normal and not a cause for concern. Many babies are born with fine, soft hair covering various parts of their body, including the face, shoulders, back, and limbs. This hair develops in the womb and serves as protection for the developing baby. Most of this hair naturally falls out within the first few weeks to months of life as your baby's skin matures and the hair follicles develop properly. You should never attempt to remove this hair by shaving, waxing, or using any hair removal products, as baby's skin is extremely delicate and sensitive. The hair will shed naturally and gradually - you might notice it on your baby's clothes or bedding as it falls out. Both the infant acne and the excess body hair are temporary conditions related to your baby's natural development and hormone levels. However, if you have any concerns or if either condition seems to be worsening rather than improving over the next few weeks, don't hesitate to discuss it with your pediatrician during your regular check-ups.

I mentioned it to the Interventional Cardiologist who did the procedure but he did not think it was related to the ASD closure. I m female and age 56. chatgpt_answers: Chronic pain near the last rib following ASD (atrial septal defect) closure is more common than many cardiologists initially recognize, and there are several potential connections between your procedure and the pain you're experiencing. During percutaneous ASD closure, the procedure involves threading catheters and devices through blood vessels and positioning an occluder device in the heart, which can sometimes cause inflammation or irritation that extends beyond the immediate cardiac area. Additionally, the positioning required during the procedure, the use of imaging guidance, or post-procedural changes in heart size and function can sometimes affect nearby structures. One possibility is that you may have developed intercostal neuralgia, which is irritation or inflammation of the nerves that run along the ribs. This can sometimes occur after cardiac procedures due to positioning during the procedure, inflammation, or changes in chest wall mechanics. Another consideration is costochondritis, which is inflammation of the cartilage that connects the ribs to the breastbone - this can develop after any procedure that involves chest positioning or manipulation. Some patients also experience referred pain from cardiac procedures, where inflammation or changes in the heart area are felt in other locations due to shared nerve pathways. The timing of your pain onset directly correlating with your ASD closure procedure is significant and suggests a connection, even if the mechanism isn't immediately obvious to your interventional cardiologist. Sometimes post-procedural complications or side effects don't become apparent until weeks or months later, and different specialists may have varying levels of familiarity with less common post-procedural symptoms. It's also possible that changes in your heart's size or function after successful ASD closure have altered the positioning or pressure on surrounding structures in subtle ways that contribute to your discomfort. Given the chronic nature of your pain and its impact on your quality of life, I would recommend seeking evaluation from a pain management specialist or a pulmonologist who might have more experience with chest wall pain syndromes. You might also consider getting a second opinion from another cardiologist, particularly one who specializes in structural heart disease and has extensive experience with ASD closures. Additional imaging studies like a chest CT or MRI might help identify any structural changes or inflammation in the chest wall area. In the meantime, anti-inflammatory medications, gentle stretching, or physical therapy focused on chest wall mobility might provide some relief, but it's important to get a proper diagnosis to guide appropriate treatment.

chatgpt_answers: Liver inflammation detected through blood work (elevated liver enzymes like ALT, AST, or other markers) can indeed be reversible in many cases, especially when it's caused by medications or other identifiable factors that can be eliminated. The fact that your liver function was normal in February and became abnormal by September, coinciding with your use of multiple prescription drugs and regular Tylenol, strongly suggests that medication-induced liver injury could be the cause. The liver has remarkable regenerative capacity and can often heal itself once the offending substances are removed, but this process requires time and proper monitoring. Both prescription medications and over-the-counter drugs like Tylenol (acetaminophen) can cause liver inflammation and damage, particularly when taken frequently, in high doses, or in combination with other medications. The good news is that stopping these medications often allows the liver to recover, though the timeline varies depending on the extent of inflammation and individual factors. However, liver inflammation doesn't always heal completely on its own, and there are other potential causes beyond medications that need to be ruled out. These could include viral hepatitis, autoimmune liver disease, fatty liver disease, alcohol-related damage (even if not obvious), or other metabolic conditions. Some people may have underlying liver conditions that were unmasked or worsened by the medications. Additionally, even if the inflammation was medication-induced, some cases can progress to more serious liver damage if not properly monitored and managed. You absolutely need follow-up care and shouldn't assume your liver will heal without medical supervision. I'd recommend scheduling an appointment with your doctor or a gastroenterologist as soon as possible to discuss your results and develop a monitoring plan. They'll likely want to repeat your blood work in 2-4 weeks to see if the numbers are improving now that you've stopped the medications, and they may recommend additional tests to rule out other causes of liver inflammation. In the meantime, avoid all unnecessary medications, alcohol, and supplements, maintain a healthy diet, stay hydrated, and watch for symptoms like abdominal pain, yellowing of eyes or skin, dark urine, or unusual fatigue that could indicate worsening liver function.

question: Q. What are the chances of HIV transmission through mosquitoes?Hello doctor,Regarding the transmission of HIV by mosquitoes, I have following query. I know the virus does not survive in insects, but what if some mosquito bites a very high viral load HIV-infected person and then bites an uninfected person on his wound, who crushes it on his wound. If the above situation happens at three or four places on his body simultaneously by an HIV-infected mosquito, what is the possibility of HIV transmission by this method?
human_answers: Hi. It is good that you have an interest in HIV transmission. Hope your query is answered, but if you have any other question, please do not hesitate to ask or call anytime. For more information consult an HIV AIDS specialist online --> https://icliniq.com./ask-a-doctor-online/HIV-AIDS-specialist
chatgpt_answers: I understand your concern about this potential transmission route, but I can provide reassurance based on extensive scientific research: HIV cannot be transmitted through mosquito bites, even in the scenario you've described with high viral loads and multiple simultaneous exposures. This has been thoroughly studied by researchers worldwide, and there are several biological reasons why mosquito transmission is impossible, even under the specific circumstances you've outlined. First, when a mosquito feeds on blood, HIV particles that might be present are completely destroyed within the mosquito's digestive system within 1-2 days. Unlike diseases such as malaria or Zika virus, which have evolved specifically to survive and replicate within mosquito hosts, HIV cannot survive or reproduce in mosquitoes - it's simply digested and broken down like any other protein. Additionally, mosquitoes don't inject blood from previous victims when they bite; instead, they inject saliva containing anticoagulants to prevent blood clotting. The blood they consume goes directly to their stomach for digestion, not to their salivary glands where it could be re-injected. Even in the extreme scenario you've described - where an infected mosquito with high viral load blood is crushed on open wounds simultaneously at multiple body sites - transmission still wouldn't occur. The amount of blood that remains in a mosquito after feeding is incredibly tiny (typically less than 0.001-0.01 milliliters), and any HIV particles in that minuscule amount would be non-viable. Studies have calculated that even if HIV could survive in mosquitoes (which it cannot), you would need to be bitten by approximately 10 million mosquitoes that had previously fed on HIV-positive individuals to receive enough viable virus for potential transmission. This is why HIV has never been documented as being transmitted by mosquitoes anywhere in the world, despite decades of research and millions of cases studied globally. Areas with high mosquito populations and high HIV prevalence don't show patterns of transmission that would be expected if mosquitoes were vectors. HIV is transmitted through specific routes: unprotected sexual contact, sharing needles, mother-to-child transmission during pregnancy/birth/breastfeeding, and direct blood-to-blood contact through transfusions or significant blood exposure. The scenario you've described, while understandably concerning, falls outside the realm of possible HIV transmission routes based on the virus's biology and extensive scientific evidence.

question: Suggest treatment for baby suffering from breathing difficulty and nose blockagemy baby is 6 weeks old, it has been 3 days he had difficulties breathing through his nose .his nose seems blocked .i used saline water to blow his nose but no mucus is coming out. shall i take him to the doctor or use nasal spray.can it affect the lungs later on?

When their nasal passages are blocked, it can significantly interfere with their ability to breathe properly, eat effectively, and sleep safely. The fact that you've tried saline drops without success and the symptoms have persisted for 3 days makes this situation urgent. You should take your baby to see a pediatrician or go to an urgent care center today rather than trying additional home treatments or over-the-counter nasal sprays. Never use adult nasal decongestant sprays on infants, as these can be dangerous and potentially toxic to babies. Even pediatric nasal sprays should only be used under direct medical supervision in babies this young. The blocked nose could be due to several causes including viral upper respiratory infection, bacterial infection, or even structural issues, and determining the underlying cause is crucial for appropriate treatment. The concern about lung involvement is valid - when babies can't breathe properly through their nose, they may develop feeding difficulties, sleep disruption, and in some cases, respiratory distress that could affect their overall oxygenation and breathing patterns. Additionally, upper respiratory infections in very young infants can sometimes progress to more serious conditions like bronchiolitis or pneumonia, which is why early medical intervention is so important. While waiting for your appointment, you can continue using the saline drops (just a drop or two in each nostril), try gently suctioning with a bulb syringe after the saline, ensure the room has adequate humidity, and keep your baby upright as much as possible during feeding. Monitor for signs of worsening such as difficulty feeding, changes in crying patterns, skin color changes (blue lips or face), unusually fast or labored breathing, or if your baby seems lethargic or unwell. If any of these symptoms develop, seek emergency medical care immediately. At 6 weeks old, respiratory issues should always be evaluated promptly by healthcare professionals rather than managed at home.

chatgpt_answers: The pain you're describing at the base of your penis during erection is not a normal part of aging or typical erectile dysfunction, and it definitely warrants medical evaluation to determine the underlying cause. Several conditions can cause this type of pain, and many are treatable once properly diagnosed. One possibility is Peyronie's disease, which involves the development of fibrous scar tissue inside the penis that can cause pain during erection, curvature, and sometimes a palpable lump or band of tissue. This condition can develop at any age but is more common in men over 40. Another potential cause is penile fracture or injury to the tunica albuginea (the fibrous covering of the erectile chambers), which can occur from trauma during intercourse or even minor injuries that might go unnoticed initially. Other possibilities include prostatitis (inflammation of the prostate gland) which can cause pain that radiates to the base of the penis, especially during arousal or ejaculation. Urethral stricture, infections, or even certain medications can sometimes cause similar symptoms. In some cases, the pain could be related to changes in the ligaments or muscles that support the penis, particularly if there's been any strain or minor injury. The pressure-like sensation you describe, as if someone were pressing down on an erect penis, is a specific type of pain that often indicates structural changes in the penile tissues or blood vessel problems. This is not something you should ignore or assume is normal aging. I'd strongly recommend scheduling an appointment with a urologist who specializes in men's sexual health. They can perform a physical examination, possibly including ultrasound imaging, and determine the exact cause of your symptoms. Early diagnosis and treatment of conditions like Peyronie's disease or other penile disorders often lead to better outcomes, so don't delay seeking medical evaluation. Many of these conditions have effective treatments available once the underlying cause is identified.

If your cycles are longer than 28 days, you may need to test for ovulation beyond day 19, potentially continuing until day 25-30 depending on your cycle length. They might suggest timed intercourse with ultrasound monitoring to pinpoint exact ovulation timing, or consider treatments like ovulation induction medications if ovulation irregularities are identified. Many couples in your situation go on to conceive successfully with proper diagnosis and treatment, so don't lose hope - you may just need more specialized evaluation to identify what's preventing conception.

Brain injuries in infants can be particularly dangerous because their skulls are still developing and their brains are more vulnerable to injury from impact and acceleration/deceleration forces. Signs of serious head injury in babies include changes in consciousness or alertness, unusual sleepiness or difficulty staying awake, persistent crying or irritability, vomiting, changes in eating or sleeping patterns, loss of balance or coordination, and seizures. The sedated behavior you're describing could potentially indicate altered consciousness, which is a red flag for head trauma. You should take your baby to the emergency room or contact your pediatrician immediately for urgent evaluation. Don't wait to see if symptoms develop further - early assessment is crucial for head injuries in infants. While waiting for medical care, monitor him closely for any changes in breathing, color, responsiveness, or if he becomes difficult to wake up. Try to keep him awake and alert if possible until he can be examined. Falls from furniture are one of the leading causes of head injuries in young children, and even seemingly minor falls can cause significant problems in babies due to their anatomy and physiology. It's always better to err on the side of caution with potential head injuries in infants.

The trigeminal nerve has three main branches, and the maxillary branch supplies feeling to the upper lip, nose, cheek, and upper teeth on each side of the face. Several conditions could cause this type of facial numbness. Trigeminal neuralgia or trigeminal nerve irritation can cause numbness, tingling, or pain in specific facial regions. Sinus infections or inflammation can sometimes compress nerves and cause numbness in the nose and lip area. Dental problems like infected teeth, recent dental work, or jaw issues can also affect the nerves that supply sensation to the upper lip and nose. Additionally, migraine headaches can sometimes cause temporary facial numbness as part of their neurological symptoms, even without severe head pain. More serious possibilities that need to be ruled out include multiple sclerosis (which can cause episodic numbness in various body parts), small strokes or transient ischemic attacks (TIAs), brain tumors affecting the trigeminal nerve pathway, or other neurological conditions. Bell's palsy typically affects facial muscle movement rather than just sensation, but some related conditions can cause sensory changes. Vitamin B12 deficiency can also cause nerve-related numbness, though this usually affects multiple areas of the body. Given that this symptom is recurring and today lasted more than five minutes without resolving, you should see a healthcare provider promptly for evaluation. If the numbness spreads to other parts of your face, you develop weakness in facial muscles, experience difficulty speaking or swallowing, or have other concerning neurological symptoms, seek immediate medical care as these could indicate more serious conditions like stroke. Your doctor may want to perform a neurological examination, possibly order imaging studies like an MRI, or refer you to a neurologist for specialized evaluation. While many causes of facial numbness are benign and treatable, the pattern and persistence of your symptoms warrant professional medical assessment to determine the underlying cause and appropriate treatment.

chatgpt_answers: The symptoms you're describing - chest pain and shortness of breath with evidence of poor heart wall thickening but normal coronary arteries - suggest a condition called heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) or possibly coronary microvascular dysfunction. When your angiogram shows perfect large coronary arteries but you still have symptoms and evidence of poor cardiac function, the problem often lies in the small blood vessels (microvasculature) that can't be seen on standard angiograms, or in the heart muscle's ability to relax and fill properly between beats. Coronary microvascular dysfunction affects the tiny blood vessels in the heart muscle that are too small to be visualized during angiography. These small vessels can become diseased due to diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, inflammation, or hormonal changes (particularly common in women after menopause). When these microscopic vessels don't function properly, they can't deliver adequate blood flow to the heart muscle during times of increased demand, causing chest pain and shortness of breath even though the major arteries look normal. This condition is sometimes called cardiac syndrome X and can be challenging to diagnose because standard tests may appear normal. Another possibility is diastolic dysfunction, where the heart muscle becomes stiff and doesn't relax properly between beats, making it difficult for the heart to fill with blood effectively. This can cause symptoms similar to traditional heart disease but with different underlying mechanisms. The walls not thickening that your cardiologist mentioned could indicate problems with the heart muscle's contractility or relaxation, which can occur even when blood supply through major arteries is adequate. I'd recommend asking your cardiologist about additional specialized testing such as stress echocardiography with Doppler studies to assess microvascular function, cardiac MRI to evaluate heart muscle structure and function in more detail, or possibly a nuclear stress test that can detect perfusion problems in small vessels. Treatment often involves medications that improve microvascular function (such as ACE inhibitors, calcium channel blockers, or ranolazine), aggressive management of risk factors like blood pressure and cholesterol, and lifestyle modifications including regular exercise and stress management. Some patients also benefit from medications specifically designed to improve diastolic function. Consider seeking a second opinion from a cardiologist who specializes in heart failure or microvascular disease, as this is a complex area that may require specialized expertise for optimal management.

question: Suggest treatment for azoospremiaHi,I m 37 yrs old (183cms/75kgs), got married 9 yrs ago, no kids, tested and found azoospermia(less semen counts), underwent varicocele surgey 18 months back, no improvement, wife(31 yrs old/58 kgs) is alright. What is the alternate solution to give birth to a child?

Since you've already undergone varicocele surgery without improvement after 18 months, it's important to determine whether you have obstructive azoospermia (where sperm are produced but blocked from reaching the ejaculate) or non-obstructive azoospermia (where sperm production itself is impaired in the testes). The next crucial step is comprehensive evaluation by a reproductive urologist or male fertility specialist who can perform detailed testing including hormone levels (FSH, LH, testosterone), genetic testing for conditions like Klinefelter syndrome or Y-chromosome microdeletions, and possibly testicular biopsy to determine if sperm production is occurring within the testicles. If sperm are being produced but not reaching the ejaculate due to blockages, procedures like vasoepididymostomy or vasovasostomy might help restore sperm to the ejaculate. However, if these surgical options aren't viable or successful, sperm retrieval techniques can be employed. For both obstructive and non-obstructive azoospermia, assisted reproductive techniques combined with surgical sperm retrieval offer excellent chances for biological parenthood. Procedures like testicular sperm extraction (TESE) or microdissection TESE (micro-TESE) can often retrieve sperm directly from the testicles, even when sperm counts appear to be zero in the ejaculate. The retrieved sperm can then be used with your wife's eggs through in vitro fertilization (IVF) with intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), where a single sperm is directly injected into each egg. Success rates for this combination can be quite good, with many couples achieving pregnancy even with very small numbers of retrieved sperm. If sperm retrieval is not successful or not possible, other options include using donor sperm with intrauterine insemination (IUI) or IVF, or considering adoption. I strongly recommend consulting with a reproductive endocrinologist and a male fertility specialist who can provide detailed evaluation and discuss all available options. Many couples with azoospermia do achieve biological parenthood through these advanced techniques, so don't lose hope. The key is working with specialists experienced in male infertility who can tailor the treatment approach to your specific situation and maximize your chances of success.

question: Is  2-3/hpf pus cells count normal in toddlers?For my 1.6 year son today urine test is done since it was yellow in color & the result is: the Pus cells count is 2-3/hpf & Epithelial cells is 2-3/hpf & RBC is 0-1/hpf. What does this mean, is it fine or something to worry about?? Since the hospitals are closed today I am seeking help thru web.Kindly help.

chatgpt_answers: The urine test results you've described for your 1.6-year-old son are generally within normal or borderline normal limits and don't indicate a serious immediate concern, though they warrant follow-up with your pediatrician. Pus cells (white blood cells) of 2-3 per high power field (hpf) in toddlers can be considered normal to slightly elevated, as young children, especially boys, can have slightly higher baseline levels due to factors like incomplete toilet training, diaper use, or minor contamination during urine collection. Epithelial cells at 2-3/hpf are normal and simply represent cells naturally shed from the urinary tract lining, while the RBC count of 0-1/hpf is completely normal. The yellow color of urine that prompted the test is usually related to concentration (dehydration) rather than infection - toddlers often have more concentrated urine, especially if they're not drinking enough fluids or are mildly dehydrated. A true urinary tract infection would typically show much higher pus cell counts (usually 10+/hpf), along with symptoms like fever, frequent urination, crying during urination, strong-smelling urine, or behavioral changes. Since your son's results are borderline and hospitals are closed, ensure he stays well-hydrated with plenty of fluids, monitor for any symptoms like fever, difficulty urinating, crying when urinating, or changes in behavior, and schedule a follow-up with your pediatrician within the next few days to discuss the results and determine if any additional testing or treatment is needed. If he develops fever, appears unwell, or shows signs of discomfort when urinating, seek medical attention sooner.

question: Is oral vaccination for Hep A and Typhoid B available?I am planning to travel to India from Canada for 3 weeks and want to know if A) I should take vaccination for Hep A and Typhoid B) If yes, is it possible to take oral medication when I arrive in India for the above 2. I was told that I can take Immunogolublin and Vivotif when I arrive in India.
human_answers: Hello, Oral vaccine for typhoid is available. However, it is not available for HAV. Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further. Regards,Dr. Loveleen Sharma, General & Family Physician
chatgpt_answers: Let me get more specific information about Hepatitis A vaccination options and recommendations for India travel.For travel to India from Canada, you should definitely get vaccinated for both Hepatitis A and typhoid fever before your trip. Regarding oral vaccination options: there is an oral typhoid vaccine available called Vivotif, which is an oral typhoid vaccine that contains live attenuated Salmonella typhi bacteria. However, there is no oral vaccine for Hepatitis A - this vaccine is only available as an injection. The oral typhoid vaccine (Vivotif) consists of 4 capsules taken every other day, with the last dose completed at least 1 week before travel. To get optimal protection, you should complete the full 4-dose schedule at least 1 week before traveling to typhoid-endemic areas. This means you cannot simply take it when you arrive in India - you need to start the series before departure. Regarding your mention of immunoglobulin and Vivotif upon arrival in India: this approach is not recommended. Immunoglobulin is used for Hepatitis A protection but provides only temporary immunity (about 3-6 months) and is typically given as a pre-travel injection, not after arrival. The standard Hepatitis A vaccine provides much better long-term protection. For typhoid, while Vivotif is indeed an oral option, the timing is critical - you cannot wait until arrival in India because the vaccine series takes time to provide immunity and must be completed before exposure risk begins. The recommended approach is to visit a travel medicine clinic in Canada at least 4-6 weeks before departure to receive the injectable Hepatitis A vaccine and either the injectable typhoid vaccine or start the oral Vivotif series. Both vaccines are strongly recommended for travel to India due to the significant risk of exposure to contaminated food and water. Waiting until arrival would leave you unprotected during the most vulnerable period of your trip when you're adjusting to local food and water sources.
