question: Suggest treatment for swelling in the entire scrotal sacI had hydrocele surgery 10 days ago. Now I have severe swelling in the entire scrotal sac which is the size of a softball. The urologist prescribed ibuprofen and cephalexin last friday, but the swelling remains the same. Note:I have had severe lymphedema in my right leg for several years . the urologist who did the operation is aware of this condition.
human_answers: Hi,A hydrocele is an accumulation of peritoneal fluid in the scrotum and surgical drainage of the fluid is done to treat the condition. If the hydrocele is uncomplicated, the doctor makes an incision directly into the scrotum. After the canal between the abdominal cavity and the scrotum is repaired, the hydrocele sac is removed, fluid is removed from the scrotum, and the incision is closed with sutures.10 days is a very short time for the surgical wound to heal completely. The hydrocele sac has been removed surgically and now the fluid is accumulating in the scrotum. This will be present for some time until it gets absorbed in to the body. There can be some swelling for the first 2 - 3 weeks after surgery and few people also experience bruising of scrotal skin. Please wear loose clothes and have a scrotal support as suggested by your surgeon.
chatgpt_answers: The severe swelling you're experiencing 10 days after hydrocele surgery, especially given your pre-existing lymphedema, is concerning and requires immediate medical attention. Post-operative scrotal swelling is normal to some degree, but swelling the size of a softball that hasn't improved after several days of anti-inflammatory and antibiotic treatment suggests potential complications. Your history of severe lymphedema in your right leg is particularly significant because lymphedema patients have compromised lymphatic drainage, which can lead to more severe and prolonged swelling after any surgical procedure, increased risk of infection, and delayed healing. The lack of improvement despite ibuprofen and cephalexin treatment could indicate several serious complications including hematoma (blood collection), seroma (fluid collection), infection despite antibiotic treatment, or lymphatic vessel damage during surgery that's exacerbating your existing lymphatic dysfunction. Given your lymphedema history, your lymphatic system may not be able to effectively drain the post-surgical fluid and inflammation, creating a cycle where swelling persists or worsens. Additionally, there's a risk that the swelling could indicate cellulitis or other soft tissue infections that may require different or stronger antibiotic treatment. You should contact your urologist immediately or go to the emergency room if the swelling continues to worsen, if you develop fever, if the skin becomes red or warm to touch, or if you experience severe pain. Don't wait for your next scheduled appointment - this level of swelling warrants urgent evaluation. Your urologist may need to perform imaging studies, drain any fluid collections, adjust your medications, or consider specialized lymphedema management techniques. Given your lymphatic condition, you may benefit from compression therapy, lymphatic massage, or other specialized treatments to help manage the swelling, but these should only be implemented under medical supervision after ruling out serious complications like infection or hematoma.

However, because these symptoms can sometimes indicate underlying neurological conditions, it's important to consult with a healthcare provider for proper evaluation. They may want to perform neurological testing, check for vitamin deficiencies, review any medications you're taking, and possibly refer you to a neurologist if symptoms persist or worsen. question: What could be the reason for having a round pink bump between my lower front bottom teeth?I have a perfectly small round pink bump between my lower front bottom teeth on my gum and my dentist wants to see me in 6 weeks to see if it is gone, I am fearing mouth cancer! I am only 22 years old and never smoked or drank alcohol. Please advise what this could be? Thank You, J
human_answers: Hello and welcome.Be sure it is not cancer.The lesion could be an abscess if pain is there.Painless lesions could be mucoceal or fibroma.Therfore do not worry wait and watch for Changes in lesion.Meanwhile maintain good oral hygiene.If required you can get the Histo pathological test done to determine the exact nature of lesion.Hope it helps.Thanks.Take care.
chatgpt_answers: A small, round pink bump on your gum between your lower front teeth is most commonly a benign condition rather than something serious like oral cancer, especially given your age and lack of risk factors like smoking or drinking. The most likely explanations include a pyogenic granuloma (a benign growth of tissue that can develop in response to irritation or minor trauma), a small fibroma (harmless fibrous tissue growth), or a mucocele (a small cyst filled with saliva that can form when a minor salivary gland is blocked). It could also be related to gum irritation from plaque buildup, aggressive brushing, or even minor trauma from eating. Your dentist's approach of monitoring it for six weeks is actually very appropriate and suggests they're not immediately concerned about malignancy - cancerous lesions in the mouth typically have different characteristics and are much more rare in young, healthy individuals without risk factors like tobacco use. The fact that your dentist wants to observe it rather than immediately biopsy or remove it indicates they suspect it's likely a reactive lesion that may resolve on its own with good oral hygiene. During this waiting period, maintain excellent oral care by gently brushing twice daily, flossing carefully around the area, and using an antimicrobial mouthwash. Avoid picking at or irritating the bump. While waiting can feel anxiety-provoking, oral cancer in someone your age without risk factors is extremely uncommon, and most small gum bumps in young adults turn out to be completely benign reactive tissue. If the bump changes significantly in size, color, or becomes painful before your follow-up appointment, don't hesitate to contact your dentist sooner, but try to reassure yourself that the most likely outcome is that this is a minor, treatable condition.

Have you undergone blood test,chest x ray and cultures to see if you have any infection or not.A endoscopic examination of head & neck and/or CT scan of neck can tell wether you have recurrence or not.In patient who have recurrence in neck they usually have swollen lymph node in neck. But getting fever and rash at recurrence is not common. Regards
chatgpt_answers: As a throat cancer survivor experiencing these concerning symptoms, it's understandable that you're worried about cancer recurrence, but the combination of fever, flu-like symptoms, and a spreading rash suggests this is more likely an acute infection or inflammatory condition rather than cancer returning. The rapid onset over two weeks with systemic symptoms like fever and the characteristic pattern of a rash spreading from your chest and back to your face are classic signs of an infectious process, possibly viral (such as shingles, which can cause severe throat pain and difficulty swallowing, or another viral infection) or even a drug reaction if you've started any new medications. Cancer recurrence typically doesn't present with acute fever and widespread rash, and usually develops more gradually with localized symptoms in the throat area. The fact that you're in the hospital and doctors are actively investigating is exactly the right approach - they can run comprehensive tests including blood work, imaging, cultures, and potentially throat examination to determine the exact cause. Your difficulty swallowing could be related to throat inflammation from the infection rather than tumor recurrence, especially given the other systemic symptoms. While it's natural to fear the worst given your cancer history, many throat cancer survivors experience unrelated medical issues, and the acute nature of your symptoms with fever and rash points toward a treatable infectious or inflammatory condition. Trust that the medical team is working to identify the cause, and remember that being 20 months cancer-free is an excellent milestone that suggests your treatment was successful and your body has been doing well in recovery.

question: Q. How to get rid of melasma?Hi doctor,I am a 28 year old male. I am having melasma over the last eight years. I am using Lookbrite cream at night and Melalite and Dermadew lotion in the morning with Suncros sunscreen SPF 26. But when I stop using it, the melasma increases. It becomes more darken on cheeks and nose. Please suggest any medicine to get rid of these ugly spots.
human_answers: Hi. I have read your question and understood your concern. Melasma can relapse. Therefore, you must continue with a maintenance regime once your melasma clears. I suggest you to use a higher SPF sunscreen like Sebamed sunscreen SPF 50+. In addition I would suggest you to use Aziderm 20% gel (Azelaic acid) twice daily for dark spots. In morning use Aziderm after washing face and after 30 minutes, apply sunscreen over it. At night apply Aziderm and leave it overnight. Aziderm is slower acting, but it is safe. It can also be used for maintenance therapy. Melalite (Hydroquinone) and Lookbrite (combination of Hydroquinone, Tretinoin and Mometasone furoate) are steroid based creams and cannot be used for more than a month as they can have side effects. For further information consult a dermatologist online --> https://www.icliniq.com/ask-a-doctor-online/dermatologist
chatgpt_answers: Melasma is a challenging condition that typically requires long-term management rather than a permanent cure, and what you're experiencing - improvement with treatment followed by darkening when you stop - is unfortunately very common with this condition. The products you're using (Lookbrite cream, Melalite, and sunscreen) contain appropriate ingredients for melasma treatment, likely including hydroquinone, tretinoin, or kojic acid, but melasma is a chronic condition where the underlying tendency for pigmentation remains even after the dark spots fade. This means that maintenance therapy is usually necessary to prevent recurrence, and stopping treatment often leads to the spots returning or darkening again. To achieve better long-term results, consider discussing with a dermatologist about upgrading your sunscreen to SPF 50 or higher with broad-spectrum protection (since UV exposure is the primary trigger for melasma recurrence), potentially adding oral tranexamic acid which has shown good results for melasma, or exploring procedures like chemical peels or laser treatments that might provide more lasting improvement. Some patients benefit from rotating between different topical agents to prevent skin tolerance, or using a maintenance regimen where treatments are gradually reduced rather than stopped completely. The key insight is that melasma management is typically a marathon rather than a sprint - consistent, long-term use of sun protection and periodic use of depigmenting agents is usually more effective than intensive short-term treatment followed by complete cessation. Don't be discouraged by needing ongoing treatment; this is the nature of melasma for most people, and with proper management, you can maintain clear skin and prevent the condition from worsening.

But chances of the infection to another person by air born rout depends on several things.1)It mainly depends on type of the infection ( Bacteria) because some are easily transferred by air route.2)The distace beween you and infected person small the distance changes of getting infected are more.3)Ventilation of room. if the room is closed having no open windows/ a/c room the chances of infection are more.4) last & most important factor is your status of immunity. To minimize your chances of getting sick during finals week, start taking protective measures immediately: wash your hands frequently, avoid touching your face, get adequate sleep, stay hydrated, consider taking vitamin C or zinc supplements, and monitor yourself closely for any early symptoms like scratchy throat or fatigue so you can rest immediately if they appear. question: What does elevated ESR and CRP indicate?My daughter has had a low grade fever for approximately two weeks.  She had a similar fever one month ago.  Her Ped ran some blood levels, and told me her ESR and CRP were elevated.  Her other symptoms include a mild cough, and nasal congestion, but she also suffers from seasonal allergies. What could this indicate?
human_answers: Hi,Thanks for asking.Based on your clinical history and query, my opinion is as follows:1. Presence of elevated ESR and CRP indicates inflammation.2. Cause appears to be allergic leading to nasal congestion.3. High elevated levels above more than 100 is serious.Hope it helps.Any further queries, happy to help again.
chatgpt_answers: Elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and CRP (C-reactive protein) are markers of inflammation in the body, indicating that your daughter's immune system is actively responding to something, whether it's an infection, autoimmune condition, or other inflammatory process. The fact that she's had recurrent low-grade fevers over the past month along with these elevated inflammatory markers suggests her body is fighting some type of ongoing infection or inflammatory condition rather than just seasonal allergies, since allergies typically don't cause sustained fever or significantly elevated ESR and CRP levels. While the mild cough and nasal congestion could be related to allergies, the persistent fever and inflammatory markers point toward something more systemic that needs further investigation. The combination of recurrent low-grade fever with elevated inflammatory markers in a child could indicate several possibilities including a lingering viral infection that hasn't fully resolved, a bacterial infection that may be developing slowly (such as sinusitis or pneumonia), or less commonly, an autoimmune condition or other inflammatory disorder. Your pediatrician will likely want to monitor these levels and may order additional tests such as a complete blood count, blood cultures, chest X-ray, or other specific tests to identify the underlying cause. It's encouraging that your daughter isn't severely ill, but the persistent nature of the symptoms and abnormal lab values warrant continued medical follow-up to ensure proper treatment and rule out conditions that might need specific intervention. Keep track of her symptoms, continue monitoring her temperature, and follow up with the pediatrician as recommended for further evaluation and possible treatment.

question: Vertigo reoccurring after a year. Taken meclizine. Advise?I had a bad case of Vertigo a year ago. I was prescribed 12.5mg Meclizine.  It worked along with physical therapy, but now it seems to be coming back.  It is not as bad, however, it seems to be constant causing me to worry about falling.It is the worst if I lay down on my back.  What advise do you have about this situation?
human_answers: Hi, thanks for writing to HCM.Apart from taking medicines, there are a few things that you should follow to prevent vertigo. They are as follows -* Change your position slowly, especially when going from a lying or sitting position to a standing position. When you get out of bed, sit on the side of the bed for a few seconds to gain your orientation and allow your circulatory system to adjust.* When walking, focus on distant objects. Do not look down at your feet. Avoid walking in dark areas or on unstable ground. * Use a cane, walking stick, or walker for support and to give additional pressure and touch (tactile) orientation.* Avoid activities that move the head up and down repetitively.* Try to avoid keeping the head tilted back for long periods of time, for example painting or dusting above your head.* Be cautious when using medications that may cause balance problems as a side effect.Hope this information is helpful. Good day
chatgpt_answers: The recurrence of your vertigo after a year, especially with the characteristic worsening when lying on your back, strongly suggests you may be experiencing another episode of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is one of the most common causes of vertigo and tends to recur in many people. BPPV occurs when tiny calcium crystals in your inner ear become displaced and move into the wrong canal, causing the spinning sensation particularly with position changes like lying down, rolling over in bed, or looking up. The fact that meclizine and physical therapy helped you previously indicates you likely had BPPV before, and since this condition has a tendency to return - sometimes months or years later - it's very possible you're experiencing the same issue again. While meclizine can help reduce the symptoms and your fear of falling, the most effective treatment for BPPV is actually specific repositioning maneuvers (like the Epley maneuver) that physically move the displaced crystals back to their proper location in your ear. I'd recommend contacting your doctor or the physical therapist who helped you before, as they can perform these maneuvers in their office and teach you how to do them at home if needed. Don't wait too long to seek treatment, as BPPV often resolves much more quickly with proper repositioning techniques than with medication alone, and the sooner you address it, the less likely you are to develop compensation patterns or chronic balance issues. In the meantime, move slowly when changing positions, avoid sudden head movements, and consider sleeping with your head slightly elevated until you can get proper treatment.

question: What causes pain in back side of the ribs after an injury?my lower left back around the back of my ribs has a sharp speratic pain. it has slightly eased since the first time it was hit and injured. i was wondering if it could be a cracked rib or what it may be as it still hurts when i sit or stretch in certain ways.

Rib injuries are common after trauma and typically cause sharp, localized pain that worsens with certain movements, deep breathing, coughing, sneezing, or specific positions like sitting or stretching, which matches what you're describing. The fact that your pain has slightly improved since the initial injury is encouraging and suggests it's more likely a muscle strain or minor rib injury rather than a significant fracture, but any persistent rib pain after trauma should be evaluated medically to rule out complications like a pneumothorax (collapsed lung) or internal injury. In the meantime, avoid activities that worsen the pain, use ice for 15-20 minutes several times daily for the first few days, consider over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medication if you can take it safely, and practice gentle breathing exercises to prevent stiffness, but seek medical attention if you experience any breathing difficulties or if the pain becomes severe.

question: Could pain in lower back and abdomen after unprotected sex mean pregnancy?I have been trying to get pregnant but we only just started trying about 2 weeks ago. human_answers: Hallow Dear,The cardinal and first symptom of pregnancy is missed period. Though it is not absolutely clear from your history whether you have missed your period or not, the impression I got is you have not missed period. Even if you have missed period, the other following symptoms start appearing after about 10 days or so after missed period. These symptoms are:1. Nausea & Vomiting and Pica2. Frequent urination3. Breast symptoms: Engorgement with tenderness, dark discolouration of nipples and areola with increase in areolar size, Montgomery's tubercles under areola and secretions from the nipples. Pain is not a feature of normal uneventful pregnancy without any risk. Appearance of pain anytime during pregnancy is indicative of some risk to the pregnancy. If you have missed your period, you can confirm the diagnosis of pregnancy by performing pregnancy test on overnight first early morning urine sample 8-10 days after missed period. Earlier these tests may give false negative results. Alternatively, you may opt for Beta hCG test which gives reliable results even few days before missing period. question: Cellular and deep penetrating fibrous histiocytoma, CD43 positive in blood vessels. human_answers: Fibrous histiocytoma is a type of tumor that does not spread to other parts of the body. However it is a locally aggressive tumor and recurs locally even after adequate surgery. So, recurrence at the same site after inadequate surgery is almost sure shot. Thus, a wide excision of the area is mandatory. The cellular and deep penetrating characteristics indicate that this particular fibrous histiocytoma has more aggressive features than typical superficial ones - it extends deeper into tissue and has increased cellularity, which is why your doctor is recommending wider excision to ensure complete removal with clear margins around the tumor. The CD43 positivity in blood vessels is a technical finding that helps pathologists classify the tumor but doesn't necessarily indicate malignancy - CD43 is a marker that can be found in various types of tissue and helps distinguish this lesion from other similar-appearing tumors. Your doctor's recommendation for wider excision is standard and appropriate management for this type of lesion because incomplete removal significantly increases the risk of local recurrence, and while these tumors rarely become malignant, ensuring complete removal is the best way to prevent future problems. The fact that your doctor is confident about the outcome suggests they believe complete removal will be curative, but they're being appropriately cautious given the tumor's characteristics. This isn't cancer in the traditional sense, but it's a lesion that requires thorough treatment due to its potential for local aggressive behavior if not completely removed. Following through with the recommended wider excision and subsequent monitoring is important for the best long-term outcome and peace of mind.

question: Are Paternia and Wysolone helpfull in Infertility ?I am 34 yrs old. I have low (13.5 million) sperm count with nil motility. My scan report says light Varicocele on the left testis. I was prescribed with Paternia & Wysolone tablet. In what way Paternia and Wysolone helps in my case?

chatgpt_answers: Paternia (pentoxifylline) and Wysolone (prednisolone) are being prescribed to address different aspects of your male infertility - the pentoxifylline is primarily aimed at improving sperm motility (movement), while the prednisolone is likely being used to reduce inflammation that may be affecting sperm production and function. Pentoxifylline works by improving blood flow and microcirculation, and some studies suggest it may help improve sperm motility by enhancing blood flow to the testes and reducing oxidative stress that can damage sperm, though the evidence for its effectiveness is mixed and results vary between patients. Prednisolone, a corticosteroid, is sometimes used in male infertility when there's suspected inflammation affecting sperm production, autoimmune factors, or when trying to improve the testicular environment for sperm development, particularly in cases where varicocele or other factors may be causing inflammatory damage. Your varicocele (enlarged veins in the scrotum) is likely contributing to both your low sperm count and complete lack of motility, as varicoceles can increase testicular temperature and create oxidative stress that damages sperm production and function. While these medications may provide some improvement, varicocele repair surgery often offers more significant and lasting benefits for sperm parameters, especially in cases like yours with severe motility issues. The medications are worth trying for 3-6 months as recommended by your doctor, but you should also discuss with a urologist or reproductive specialist about whether varicocele repair might be beneficial in your case, as addressing the underlying vascular problem often provides better long-term improvement in sperm quality than medication alone. Additionally, lifestyle modifications like avoiding heat exposure, maintaining healthy weight, taking antioxidant supplements, and reducing stress can complement the medical treatment.

question: What does questionable infiltrates upper left lobe mean?Hi. I had a medical examinations last month and the result was QUESTIONABLE INFILTRATES UPPER LEFT LOBE and I retake the xray test, the result was APICOLORDIC VIEW SUGGESTED FOR FURTHER EVALUATION . What does this mean? I hope you could find an answer to this problem. Please give me suggestions for what I can do with this! Thanks Doctor!
human_answers: Thanks for your question on HCM.Routinely chest x ray is taken in PA (PosteroAnterior) view. So in this view the apices of both lungs are not clearly visualised. The bony structures like firat two ribs and clavicle can obstruct the view and so upper lobes can not be visualised properly and hence reporting is not accurate. So to overcome this, apicolordotic view is taken. In this chest x ray is not taken in PA view. It is taken in such a way that bony structures are not hindering apices and clear view of apices (upper lobes) is possible. So it is modification of PA view to get better and accurate view of upper lobes.So get it done.
chatgpt_answers: Questionable infiltrates upper left lobe on a chest X-ray means that the radiologist observed some abnormal shadowing or opacity in the upper portion of your left lung that could potentially represent infiltrates (areas where the air spaces in the lung are filled with fluid, pus, blood, or other material instead of air), but the findings weren't clear enough to make a definitive diagnosis. The term questionable indicates uncertainty about whether what they're seeing is truly abnormal or could be due to normal anatomical variations, overlapping structures, or technical factors in the X-ray. When you retook the X-ray and received the result apicolordic view suggested for further evaluation, this means the radiologist is recommending additional specialized X-ray views (apical and lordotic views) that provide better visualization of the upper lung areas, which can be difficult to see clearly on standard chest X-rays due to overlapping ribs and other structures. These specialized views help distinguish between actual lung pathology and normal anatomical shadows. This progression suggests that your doctors are being thorough in ruling out any significant lung abnormalities, which could range from infections like pneumonia or tuberculosis, to other conditions, though many cases turn out to be normal variants or resolved minor issues. You should follow up with your doctor promptly to get the recommended additional imaging and discuss the results, as they will be able to interpret the findings in the context of your symptoms, medical history, and physical examination to determine if any treatment is needed.

question: Is it dangerous to breastfeed a baby while on Metronidazole?im a lactating mother to a 6month old child. i have been diagnosed w/ amoebiasis and was prescribed with Metronidazole. However, the actual risk level and recommendations can vary depending on factors like the dosage, duration of treatment, and your baby's age and health status. Some medical organizations consider short-term use of metronidazole compatible with breastfeeding when the benefits outweigh the risks, while others recommend a temporary interruption of breastfeeding. If you must continue taking metronidazole, you could consider pumping and discarding your breast milk during treatment (and for 12-24 hours after your last dose) while maintaining your milk supply, though this may be challenging if your baby refuses bottles. Alternative medications for amoebiasis that may be safer during breastfeeding include paromomycin, which is poorly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and has minimal transfer into breast milk, though its effectiveness may differ from metronidazole. It's crucial that you contact your prescribing doctor immediately to discuss your breastfeeding situation, as they may be able to adjust your treatment plan, prescribe an alternative medication, or provide specific guidance on timing your doses to minimize your baby's exposure. Don't stop your treatment without medical supervision, as untreated amoebiasis can become serious, but your doctor needs to help you find the safest approach for both you and your baby.

While rectoceles are more common in older women who have had children, they can occur in younger women, especially those with chronic constipation, frequent straining, or connective tissue disorders. The thick, white, stringy mucus you're seeing after bowel movements is also consistent with constipation and straining, as this can irritate the rectal lining and cause increased mucus production. The key is to address your constipation promptly to prevent worsening of the condition and potential complications.

However, the heart palpitations you mentioned are a separate concern that should not be ignored, especially in combination with being overweight, as this could indicate cardiovascular issues, anxiety, caffeine sensitivity, thyroid problems, or other conditions that warrant medical evaluation. You should see a healthcare provider to properly evaluate both issues - they can perform nerve conduction studies to confirm carpal tunnel syndrome and assess treatment options ranging from conservative management to potentially surgical intervention if conservative measures fail, while also evaluating your heart palpitations with appropriate testing like an EKG and blood work to ensure there are no underlying cardiac or metabolic issues that need attention.

question: How to overcome the pain caused by a misplaced wisdom tooth?respected sir ,my wisdom tooth is producing not in correct place doctor suggest me to remove it. i m suffering from throbbing in my head and ears , and too much heaviness in my head also. so is this because of wisdom teeth or is there any another problem..

When wisdom teeth don't have enough space to erupt properly or grow at incorrect angles, they can create pressure against adjacent teeth, jaw bone, and surrounding tissues, leading to inflammation and pain that extends beyond just the tooth itself. The trigeminal nerve, which supplies sensation to your teeth, jaw, and much of your head and face, can transmit pain signals from an impacted wisdom tooth to areas like your temples, ears, and even cause tension-type headaches and that heavy feeling in your head. For immediate pain relief while you prepare for the extraction your doctor recommended, you can take over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications like ibuprofen as directed on the package (which is particularly effective for dental pain), apply cold compresses to the outside of your cheek for 15-20 minutes several times a day, rinse gently with warm salt water, avoid chewing on that side, and try sleeping with your head slightly elevated to reduce pressure. However, you should schedule the wisdom tooth extraction as soon as possible, as delaying removal of a problematic wisdom tooth can lead to worsening pain, infection, damage to adjacent teeth, cysts, or other complications. While your symptoms are most likely from the wisdom tooth, if the pain persists or worsens after the extraction, or if you experience additional symptoms like fever, facial swelling, or severe headaches, you should follow up with your dentist or doctor to ensure there are no other underlying issues contributing to your discomfort.

question: How can teeth be aligned without the gums being cut?I have invisalign. When the frenum is too thick, too low, or too tight, it can create what's called a diastema (gap between front teeth) and prevent proper tooth alignment, which may be why the middle and top portions of your front teeth aren't touching despite the bottoms being aligned. While a frenectomy (surgical removal or reshaping of the frenum tissue) is the most definitive treatment for this issue and is a relatively minor outpatient procedure, there are some alternative approaches you could discuss with your orthodontist first. These might include extended Invisalign treatment with specific attachments or pressure points designed to overcome the tissue resistance, the use of specialized elastics or other orthodontic appliances that can apply targeted pressure to bring the teeth together, or in some cases, minor reshaping of the tooth itself if the issue is primarily with tooth angulation rather than tissue interference. However, it's important to understand that if the frenum is truly the problem, non-surgical approaches may have limited success and could potentially cause other issues like root resorption or gum recession if too much force is applied to overcome the tissue resistance. You should schedule a consultation with your orthodontist to evaluate the specific anatomy and determine whether additional Invisalign treatment, other orthodontic approaches, or ultimately a simple frenectomy would be the best solution for achieving the final result you're looking for.

question: Can an acid reflux event cause a rapid heart rate?Can an acid reflux event cause a rapid heart rate? My resting rate is in the high 50's. This can be a cardiac arrhythmia like psvt or atrial fibrillation, in which heart rate suddenly goes up. Blood pressure may fall during these episodes and one has dizziness, fainting, blackouts, sometimes syncope. Usually ecg is normal as it is usually done in between the episodes. ECG done during episodes will show abnormality. You will need 24 hour holter monitoring or get ecg done during high heart rate. Also, hemoglobin and thyroid test should be done. ln order to abort such episodes you should try to cough hard. Is there any stress or anxiety associated.    Till the time your evaluation is complete, you can ask your local doctor for tab ciplar LA 20 mg once a day. Hope this helps you and get back if you have any doubts.

Acid reflux can trigger rapid heart rate through vagal nerve stimulation (the vagus nerve connects the digestive system to the heart), the release of stress hormones like adrenaline in response to discomfort, direct irritation of the esophagus which shares nerve pathways with the heart, and anxiety or panic responses to the uncomfortable sensation of reflux, all of which can cause tachycardia. However, while acid reflux can cause temporary increases in heart rate, sustaining a rate of 155 for 7 hours is extremely unusual and potentially dangerous, as this represents significant cardiac stress that could indicate a more serious underlying heart rhythm disorder that may have been coincidentally triggered around the time of your reflux episode. Given that your normal resting heart rate is in the high 50s (which suggests you may be physically fit), jumping to 155 and staying there for such an extended period is particularly concerning and could indicate conditions like atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, supraventricular tachycardia, or other arrhythmias that require immediate medical attention. You should go to the emergency room or contact your doctor immediately, as prolonged rapid heart rates can lead to complications like heart failure, stroke (especially if you're in atrial fibrillation), or other serious cardiac events. Don't assume this was simply due to acid reflux - while reflux may have been a contributing factor or coincidental timing, a heart rate that high for that long needs urgent cardiac evaluation including an EKG, blood work, and possibly cardiac monitoring to determine the cause and ensure your safety.

The condition involves abnormal keratinization that leads to thick, scaly skin that often has a porcupine-like appearance, and treatment typically focuses on reducing the hyperkeratosis, maintaining skin hydration, preventing infections, and improving overall skin function and appearance. While topical treatments like urea-containing creams, lactic acid preparations, and keratolytic agents (such as salicylic acid) are indeed the mainstay of therapy, more aggressive treatments may be considered for severe cases, including oral retinoids like acitretin or isotretinoin, which can significantly reduce hyperkeratosis but require careful monitoring for side effects, especially in children. Physical treatments such as careful mechanical debridement, specialized baths with additives like oatmeal or salt solutions, and in some cases, laser therapy or surgical intervention for particularly problematic areas may also be beneficial. Given that your daughter's condition affects only the left side of her body (which suggests it may be a form of nevoid ichthyosis), it's crucial to work with a pediatric dermatologist who specializes in rare skin conditions, as they can develop a comprehensive treatment plan that may include combinations of topical therapies, possibly oral medications when appropriate, and guidance on long-term management strategies. Don't lose hope - while the doctors are correct that this is a chronic condition requiring lifelong management, many patients see significant improvement with proper treatment, and new therapies are continually being developed, so maintaining regular follow-up with specialists and staying informed about emerging treatments is important for optimizing her care and quality of life.

question: What are the chances of pregnany post intercourse without penetration?Hi my name is Tiffany and I had unprotected sex twice with 2 different guys one on the 4 and the other on 11 but none of them nutted in me they both pulled out so the question is there a possibility that I can still get pregnant cause my calendar says I'm 4 days late but I always had a irregular menstrual

question: Suggest treatment for a dog bitemy neighbor was bitten by a dog 15days ago,the dog received complete immunization but the doctor adviced her to have anti rabies vaccine, she have 2 shots of rabipur and 2 more scheduled on june 24 and july 16, and besides the rabipur the doctor advised passive immunization but our veterinarian advised that rabipur is enough as the dog don't have rabies, what she will do?
human_answers: Welcome to H.C.M. I am Dr Krishna Dubey.Your doctor was correct and your neighbor might be needed for passive immunization because passive immunization depends on size of wound (That your treating doctor better observed during first visit) and category of Rabies.Complete Rabipur course and follow  that dog that dog is still live or not.Thanx for query.
chatgpt_answers: Your neighbor should absolutely complete the full rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) series including both the active immunization (Rabipur vaccine) and passive immunization (rabies immunoglobulin/RIG) as recommended by her doctor, despite the veterinarian's opinion, because rabies prevention is a life-or-death medical decision that cannot be reversed once symptoms appear. Even though the biting dog received complete immunization, several factors make the full PEP protocol the safest approach: vaccine failures can occasionally occur in animals, the dog's vaccination history may not be completely reliable or up-to-date, rabies has a nearly 100% fatality rate once clinical symptoms develop, and medical guidelines universally recommend complete PEP for unprovoked bites from dogs whose rabies status cannot be absolutely confirmed through laboratory testing. The passive immunization (rabies immunoglobulin) is particularly important because it provides immediate antibodies while the vaccine series builds up her own immune response over the following weeks, and this combination therapy is the gold standard for rabies prevention worldwide. While veterinarians are knowledgeable about animal health, human post-exposure rabies treatment is a specialized area of human medicine where the consequences of inadequate treatment are fatal, so the human physician's recommendations should take precedence in this situation. Your neighbor should continue with her scheduled vaccine appointments on June 24 and July 16, receive the passive immunization if she hasn't already, and not skip any doses, because even if the risk seems low, the catastrophic outcome of rabies infection makes complete prophylaxis the only reasonable choice. The small inconvenience and cost of completing the full treatment is negligible compared to the absolute certainty of death if rabies develops, and there are no reliable ways to definitively rule out rabies risk without laboratory testing of the animal's brain tissue, which is not practical in this situation.

question: What causes a large growth around C1 cervical spine?My son-in-law has a golf ball size mass wrapped around C1 and his doctor informed him that it is an unknown mass and assembled a group of doctors but they do not know what to do because they have never seen anything like it and it is rare where it is located. My concern is the brain stem. The doctor said that the brain stem is not damaged but how close is the brain stem to the C1 area.
human_answers: Hello and Welcome to ‘Ask A Doctor’ service. I have reviewed your query and here is my advice. The brainstem and the C1 levels are pretty close, the C1 is the last spinal cord level before it joins the brainstem. However you seem to speak of the mass being around the C1 vertebrae not the spinal cord, in that case it is separated by the spinal cord (and the brainstem naturally) by the vertebral body and ligaments, doesn't seem to originate from the brainstem tissue or represent any imminent threat to compress the brainstem if that's what you mean. Of course it is still a delicate matter since the doctors haven't identified the nature, I suppose they might want to take biopsy material from it to create a better idea. Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further.
chatgpt_answers: A golf ball-sized mass wrapped around the C1 vertebra (atlas) is indeed extremely concerning given its proximity to critical neurological structures, and your worry about the brainstem is well-founded since the C1 vertebra is located immediately below the skull base where the brainstem transitions into the spinal cord through the foramen magnum. The brainstem is very close to the C1 area - only separated by the spinal canal space - and any mass in this location has the potential to compress the brainstem, upper spinal cord, vertebral arteries that supply blood to the brainstem, or the cranial nerves that exit at this level. Possible causes of such a mass could include benign tumors like meningiomas, schwannomas, or neurofibromas, malignant tumors either primary (like chordomas or sarcomas) or metastatic from other locations, infectious processes like abscesses or granulomatous diseases, inflammatory conditions, or vascular malformations, though the location and description suggest this is likely a tumor of some type. Given the rarity and critical location, your son-in-law should seek evaluation at a major academic medical center with specialized neurosurgeons who have experience with complex spine and skull base tumors, as this type of case requires expertise in both neurosurgery and potentially otolaryngology or other specialties. Advanced imaging like high-resolution MRI with contrast, CT angiography to evaluate blood vessel involvement, and possibly specialized studies will be needed to fully characterize the mass before any treatment decisions can be made. While the current doctors say the brainstem isn't damaged, continuous monitoring is essential as any growth or changes in the mass could rapidly affect these critical structures, and getting multiple expert opinions from specialized centers is crucial for developing the safest and most effective treatment plan for such a rare and potentially dangerous condition.

question: Sore stomach with Cerebral Palsy of a 17 years old girlMy sister who is 17 and has Cerebral Palsy has had a sore stomach for a little over a week. It seems to be in her upper left side and possibly accompanied by a headach. I think it s sometimes worse at night, but all in all it s been CONSTANT. She losing alot of sleep over this. She does seem to be eating normally though.
human_answers: Hi well come to Hcm. Give details what do you mean by sore stomach.If she is eating normally, if there are no associated vomiting, fever etc, if she is passing her stool normally than we have to think of some other system involvement as well. so please  give some more details as she is having associated headach as well. Thanks
chatgpt_answers: Your 17-year-old sister's constant upper left abdominal pain lasting over a week, especially when accompanied by headaches and severe enough to disrupt her sleep, requires immediate medical evaluation, as individuals with cerebral palsy face unique risks and complications that can make abdominal pain more serious than in typical teenagers. Cerebral palsy patients often have gastrointestinal issues including gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), constipation, delayed gastric emptying, and increased risk of gastritis or peptic ulcers due to medications they may take for muscle spasticity or seizures, and the upper left location could suggest problems with the stomach, spleen, pancreas, or left kidney. The persistent nature of the pain, especially lasting over a week with associated headaches and sleep disruption, raises concern for conditions like gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, splenic issues, or even more serious conditions that could be life-threatening if not properly diagnosed and treated. Cerebral palsy patients may also have difficulty communicating the exact nature or severity of their pain, making it crucial to have medical professionals evaluate her thoroughly rather than waiting to see if symptoms improve. You should take her to her primary care physician immediately, or to the emergency room if you cannot get a prompt appointment, as she needs a physical examination, blood work to check for signs of infection or inflammation, and possibly imaging studies like ultrasound or CT scan to identify the cause of her pain. Don't delay seeking medical care because she's still eating normally - serious abdominal conditions can still be present even when appetite is maintained, and individuals with cerebral palsy may mask or minimize symptoms due to their neurological condition, making professional medical evaluation essential for her safety and to get her the relief she desperately needs.

question: Q. Food gets stuck while entering my stomach. Why is it happening?Hi doctor,Whenever I eat, the food gets stuck while entering the stomach. I have to drink water to flush it down. Sometimes, I am not able to swallow the water also. I have to throw up to breathe. Why is it happening? Please help.
human_answers: Hi. Revert back with the x-ray to a medical gastroenterologist online -->  https://www.icliniq.com/ask-a-doctor-online/medical-gastroenterologist
chatgpt_answers: Your symptoms of food getting stuck while trying to enter your stomach, needing water to help it pass, and sometimes being unable to swallow water to the point where you have to vomit to breathe are very concerning and indicate a serious problem with your esophagus that requires immediate medical evaluation. This condition is called dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), and the progression from solid food getting stuck to liquids also becoming difficult to swallow suggests a mechanical obstruction or severe narrowing of your esophagus that could be due to several serious conditions. Possible causes include esophageal stricture (narrowing from scar tissue), esophageal tumors or cancer, achalasia (a condition where the lower esophageal sphincter doesn't relax properly), severe gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) that has caused scarring, esophageal rings or webs, or other structural abnormalities that are blocking the normal passage of food into your stomach. The fact that you sometimes cannot swallow water and have to vomit to breathe is particularly alarming, as this suggests the obstruction may be severe and could potentially lead to aspiration (food or liquid entering your lungs) or complete blockage that could be life-threatening. You need to see a gastroenterologist immediately or go to the emergency room, as you will likely need urgent testing such as a barium swallow study, upper endoscopy (EGD), or CT scan to identify the cause of the obstruction and determine appropriate treatment. Don't delay seeking medical care or try to manage this with diet modifications alone, as progressive dysphagia that affects both solids and liquids can indicate serious underlying conditions that may worsen rapidly without proper medical intervention, and early diagnosis and treatment are crucial for the best possible outcomes.

question: How to treat the pain caused in the sternum for a person having bilateral mastectomy?I was diagnosed with Stage 2A breast cancer in February 2011.  I have had a bilateral mastectomy and chemotherapy and now have saline breast implants.  For the past few days, I have been experiencing pain between the 5th and 6th ribs to the left of my sternum.  The pain is worse when I breathe.  Is this costochondritis?  A problem with the implants?  Metastasis?  Please give me your thoughts.  Thank you.
human_answers: Hi,Thanks for writing in.The pain in costochondritis is typically in the front of chest next to the sternum and might cause lot of distress. It is a sharp pain.Breast implants can cause irritation of the nerves in the anterior chest wall causing pain perception. This pain is more localized to the area where implants are present and usually does not radiate to other places.Metastasis is pain due to bone destruction. This is diffuse pain which increases on palpation and focused on the area overlying the bone.It is suggested that you get a chest X ray or CT scan done to evaluate in detail the cause and nature of problem leading to the pain.
chatgpt_answers: Your concern about chest pain between the 5th and 6th ribs to the left of your sternum, especially as a breast cancer survivor, is completely understandable and requires prompt medical evaluation to rule out several possibilities including metastasis, which is always a concern for cancer patients experiencing new chest pain. While costochondritis (inflammation of the cartilage connecting ribs to the sternum) is a possibility and can cause sharp, localized chest pain that worsens with breathing or movement, your history of Stage 2A breast cancer makes it essential to first rule out more serious causes such as bone metastases to the ribs or sternum, lung metastases, or other cancer recurrence that could present as chest pain. The pain worsening with breathing could indicate several conditions including costochondritis, rib fractures (which can occur more easily after chemotherapy due to bone weakening), pleural irritation, muscle strain from the physical changes after bilateral mastectomy and reconstruction, or potentially more serious issues like pulmonary embolism or cardiac problems that can sometimes develop after cancer treatment. While implant-related complications are possible, they typically cause different types of pain and are less likely to cause the specific rib pain you're describing, though capsular contracture or implant displacement could potentially contribute to chest wall discomfort. You should contact your oncologist immediately rather than waiting, as they will want to evaluate this symptom promptly given your cancer history, and they may recommend imaging studies like CT scans, bone scans, or chest X-rays to rule out metastatic disease before considering more benign causes. Early evaluation is crucial because if this is related to cancer recurrence, prompt treatment leads to better outcomes, while if it's a benign condition like costochondritis, you can get appropriate pain management and peace of mind.

question: Suggest treatments for pain in stomach due to hepatomegaly and fatty liverhie my dad had a liver scan and the impression says that he has hepatomegaly and fatty liver. he is in excruciating pain that feels like someone gave him a hard blow to the stomach and he feels very nauseated. they keep telling him its gas or acid but I am worried that it may be more than just that. what should I do please please help
human_answers: HiThanks for choosing HCM for your query.For acidity related stomach problems he can use PPI along with Domperidone once daily for about 4-6 weeks followed by re evaluation by a doctor.He must avoid NSAID pain killers, hot spicy and oily foods, caffeine, smoking and alcohol ( if smoker or alcoholic).I hope your query has been explained.Your feedback will be of great help,
chatgpt_answers: Your father's excruciating abdominal pain described as feeling like a hard blow to the stomach along with severe nausea, combined with his recent diagnosis of hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) and fatty liver disease, is extremely concerning and requires immediate emergency medical attention rather than being dismissed as just gas or acid. Severe abdominal pain in someone with known liver disease can indicate serious complications such as acute liver inflammation (hepatitis), liver failure, portal hypertension with complications, gallbladder disease (which commonly occurs with fatty liver), pancreatitis, or even more dangerous conditions like liver rupture or bleeding that can be life-threatening if not treated promptly. Fatty liver disease, especially when it progresses to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), can cause significant inflammation and pain, and hepatomegaly itself can cause stretching of the liver capsule that results in severe, constant abdominal pain that's often described exactly as your father is experiencing it. The combination of severe pain with nausea in the context of liver disease is particularly worrying and should never be dismissed as simple gastric issues, as this could indicate acute liver complications or associated conditions that require urgent medical intervention. You should take your father to the emergency room immediately or call 911, as he needs comprehensive evaluation including blood tests to check liver function, bilirubin levels, and other markers that could indicate acute liver problems, imaging studies to assess for complications, and potentially immediate treatment to prevent serious outcomes. Don't accept reassurances about gas or acid when dealing with this level of pain in someone with known liver disease - trust your instincts that this is more serious, advocate strongly for your father, and insist on thorough evaluation by emergency physicians who can properly assess whether this represents a liver emergency requiring immediate intervention.

question: Is there any side effects for metpure xl 25?hi a m 44 years old male, i have been taking metpure xl 25 every morning for past 5 years to control hypertension. please advise if any side effect is there or how can i discontinue the medecine since i don t have nay other problem and my BP is at 130/80 always for last number of years. tnx sanjeev
human_answers: Hello, Yes, there are. Drowsiness, dizziness, tiredness, diarrhea, and slow heartbeat may occur. Decreased sexual ability has been reported infrequently. Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further. Take care Regards,Dr. AJEET SINGH, General & Family Physician
chatgpt_answers: Metpure XL 25 (metoprolol extended-release) is generally well-tolerated, but like all beta-blockers, it can have side effects including fatigue, dizziness, slow heart rate (bradycardia), cold hands and feet, shortness of breath, depression, vivid dreams or sleep disturbances, decreased exercise tolerance, potential sexual dysfunction, and in some cases, weight gain or masking of low blood sugar symptoms if you're diabetic. However, the fact that you've been taking it successfully for 5 years without apparent problems suggests you're tolerating it well, and your consistent blood pressure reading of 130/80 indicates the medication is effectively controlling your hypertension. Your blood pressure of 130/80, while improved from what it likely was before treatment, is still considered Stage 1 hypertension according to current guidelines (normal is less than 120/80), which means you still have hypertension that benefits from treatment to reduce your risk of heart attack, stroke, kidney disease, and other cardiovascular complications. You should never discontinue blood pressure medication on your own, as this can cause dangerous rebound hypertension where your blood pressure spikes to potentially life-threatening levels, and the decision to reduce or stop antihypertensive medication should always be made with your doctor based on comprehensive evaluation of your cardiovascular risk factors, lifestyle changes, and overall health status. Instead of stopping the medication, consider discussing with your physician whether lifestyle modifications like weight loss (if needed), regular exercise, reduced sodium intake, stress management, and dietary improvements might allow for dose reduction over time, but this should be done gradually under medical supervision with careful blood pressure monitoring to ensure your cardiovascular health remains protected.

question: Is numbness in the left leg an early sign of heart disease?Hi. At times I feel a strange sensation, like a numbing vibration that goes down my left leg. Sometimes these are constant and lasts a while and other times I feel this only a few times and always when relaxing. Since it is on my left side I m worried it may have something to do with my heart. Have you heard of this before? It is not painful, just very strange.
human_answers: Hello and Welcome to ‘Ask A Doctor’ service. I have reviewed your query and here is my advice. I would explain that the numbness on your left leg does not seem to be related to any cardiac disorders. It could be related to a pinched nerve or partial epilepsy seizures. For this reason, I would recommend consulting with a neurologist for a physical exam and some tests:- a resting ECG- a lumbar spine X-ray study for possible bulging disc in this region- nerve conduction studies. If suspicions of seizures are raised, an EEG may be needed. You should discuss with your doctor on the above tests. Hope to have been helpful! Kind regards, Dr. Iliri
chatgpt_answers: While it's understandable to be concerned about left-sided symptoms potentially relating to heart problems, the numbness and vibrating sensation in your left leg that you're describing is more likely related to nerve compression, circulation issues, or musculoskeletal problems rather than heart disease. Heart-related symptoms typically present as chest pain, shortness of breath, arm pain (usually left arm and shoulder), jaw pain, or upper back pain, but isolated leg numbness or tingling is not a common or typical sign of cardiac problems. The symptoms you're experiencing - particularly the fact that they occur when relaxing and have a vibrating quality - sound more consistent with nerve compression issues such as sciatica (compression of the sciatic nerve), piriformis syndrome, lumbar spine problems that affect nerve roots, or even restless leg syndrome, which can cause unusual sensations in the legs especially when at rest. Other possibilities include circulation problems like peripheral artery disease, vitamin deficiencies (particularly B12), diabetes-related neuropathy if you have diabetes, or even simple positional compression from sitting or lying in certain positions that compress nerves or blood vessels. However, given your concern and the persistent nature of these symptoms, you should see your primary care physician for proper evaluation, as they can perform a physical examination, check your circulation, assess your reflexes and sensation, and potentially order tests like blood work or nerve conduction studies if indicated. While this is unlikely to be heart-related, any new or persistent neurological symptoms deserve medical attention to identify the cause and ensure appropriate treatment, and your doctor can also provide reassurance about your cardiovascular health if that remains a concern.

question: Suggest remedy for abscess in tooth followed by lump on jaw lineI have had an abcess on tooth two lots of antibiotics did not work waiting for a dental hospital appointment .waited months heard nothing went to my doctors who sent me to hospital because I now have a lump on my jaw line and he wants a biopsy ,feel it has gone from something very treatable to really worrying
human_answers: A dental abscess is an infection . These infection caused due to poor dental health and can result from lack of proper and timely dental care. The cause of these infection is direct growth of bacteria from an existing tooth cavity into the soft tissue .Visit your dentist and follow up the complete treatment. If you cannot reach a dentist, go to your physician for the evaluation, especially if you feel sick. Dentist may decide to open that abscess and allow the pus to drain or try therapy with antibiotics. People with dental abscesses are typically prescribed pain reliever s, at the discretion of dentist , antibiotics to fight infection.
chatgpt_answers: Your progression from a tooth abscess that didn't respond to two courses of antibiotics to now having a lump on your jaw line is indeed concerning and requires urgent attention, but try not to panic as there are several possible explanations ranging from treatable dental complications to more serious conditions that still have good outcomes when caught early. When a dental abscess doesn't respond to antibiotics, it can develop into more serious complications including osteomyelitis (bone infection), cellulitis (spreading soft tissue infection), or the formation of a deeper abscess or fistula that creates a palpable lump along the jaw line, and in some cases, chronic untreated dental infections can rarely lead to more serious conditions that your doctor wants to rule out with the biopsy. The lump could represent several things including a reactive lymph node responding to the chronic infection, a dental cyst or granuloma, chronic osteomyelitis of the jawbone, or less commonly, other growths that need to be properly identified through biopsy and appropriate treatment. While waiting for your biopsy results, you should continue to monitor for signs of serious infection such as fever, rapidly increasing swelling, difficulty swallowing or breathing, or severe pain, and seek immediate emergency care if any of these develop. You should also contact the dental hospital again to expedite your appointment, explaining that your condition has worsened and you now have a jaw mass requiring urgent evaluation, as the source dental infection needs to be addressed even while the investigation of the lump is ongoing. Remember that many jaw lumps turn out to be benign, treatable conditions, and even if something more serious is found, early detection and treatment generally lead to much better outcomes, so while your concern is understandable, focus on getting the proper medical care you need rather than assuming the worst-case scenario.

question: What could cause sharp pain in the thigh and burning sensation in the lower leg?I keep getting a quick sharp pain in my left outer upper thigh above knee that comes and goes. After pain goes away I will develop burning sensation in my lower leg and foot. I did have a fall about a month ago with a lot of bruising in that leg. I also have a history of multiple sclerosis. What could this pain be? It does become debilitating when it hits but goes away after a few seconds.
human_answers: Hello and Welcome to ‘Ask A Doctor’ service. I have reviewed your query and here is my advice. You have got radicular pain on your left lower limb. It is sharp pain that arises in lower limb due to nerve root compression in lower lumbar spine. Usual cause Is disc herniation which compresses nerve roots. Diagnosis needs to be confirmed by doing MRI of the lumbo sacral spine. Meanwhile start tab Pregalin x 75 mg one at bedtime to get relief from pain. You need to consult orthopedic spine surgeon with report. Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further.
chatgpt_answers: Your symptoms of sharp pain in the left outer upper thigh followed by burning sensations in the lower leg and foot, especially given your history of multiple sclerosis and recent fall, suggest several possible causes that warrant medical evaluation. The pattern you're describing - sharp, shooting pain followed by burning sensations - could indicate nerve compression or irritation, possibly from your fall, such as lateral femoral cutaneous nerve entrapment (meralgia paresthetica), sciatica from lumbar spine issues, or piriformis syndrome where the piriformis muscle compresses the sciatic nerve. However, given your multiple sclerosis history, this could also represent an MS flare-up or new lesion affecting nerve pathways, as MS can cause exactly these types of sharp, shooting pains followed by altered sensations, and the pattern of pain moving from thigh to lower leg could indicate demyelination affecting specific nerve pathways. The fall you experienced a month ago could have triggered nerve compression, worsened existing MS-related nerve damage, or caused structural changes that are now manifesting as these neurological symptoms. MS patients are also at higher risk for developing secondary conditions like nerve entrapments due to altered movement patterns, muscle weakness, or inflammation. You should contact your neurologist promptly to discuss these symptoms, as they may need to evaluate whether this represents MS disease activity requiring treatment (possibly with steroids or disease-modifying therapy adjustments) or a secondary condition like nerve compression that might need different interventions such as physical therapy, anti-inflammatory medications, or other targeted treatments. Don't ignore these symptoms, especially with your MS history, as early intervention for either MS flares or secondary complications generally leads to better outcomes and can prevent the symptoms from becoming more persistent or debilitating.

question: Is there any better medication for metathesized kidney cancer?My husband has been in Axitinib for about 1 year and more for Kidney cancer.  He had some blood clotsin his lung and we were told it was caused by axitinib please confirm.  thanksDo you know a better medication for metathesized kidney cancer .  Axitinib was helping him but notit is stopped for the lung probem
human_answers: This is called the targetted therapy. It is used in advanced stage of cancer. the clotting problem is a rare cause with this drug but it is the malignancy itself which is responsible for the clotting phenomenon in the body. take advice from your doctor for  use of blood thinners.Dr. J. ticku
chatgpt_answers: Yes, your concerns about blood clots being caused by axitinib are valid, as axitinib can cause blood clots in veins or arteries which can be serious and sometimes lead to death, and this is a known side effect that requires immediate medical attention when it occurs. The fact that your husband's doctors stopped the axitinib due to blood clots in his lungs was the correct decision, as pulmonary embolism (blood clots in the lungs) is a potentially life-threatening complication that requires discontinuation of the causative medication. Fortunately, there are several newer and effective treatment options for metastatic kidney cancer that your husband's oncologist can consider now that axitinib has been discontinued. Current treatment approaches include immunotherapy combinations such as pembrolizumab (Keytruda) with other agents, nivolumab (Opdivo), or other immune checkpoint inhibitors that have shown excellent results in metastatic renal cell carcinoma, alternative targeted therapies like sunitinib (Sutent), pazopanib, cabozantinib, or newer agents like belzutifan which was recently approved for certain types of kidney cancer. The choice of next treatment will depend on your husband's specific cancer characteristics, previous treatments, overall health status, and the molecular features of his tumor, which his oncologist can evaluate through additional testing if needed. Many patients with metastatic kidney cancer continue to have good responses and quality of life with these alternative treatments, so while it's concerning that the axitinib had to be stopped, there are still many effective options available. You should discuss with his oncologist about the best next treatment option, whether he needs anticoagulation therapy for the blood clots, and what monitoring will be needed to ensure his safety with whatever new treatment is chosen.

question: What causes nose bleeds with nausea and dizziness?my husband is deployed in Afghanistan, and he is getting severe nose bleeds for weeks, he is nauseous, dizzy, sensitive to light and sound.. His father passed away from lukemia, i am afraid he might  be at risk as well.. question: I have thyroid and my husband has less count motility. Can we have children?hi we dont have childrens ihave tyriod and my husband have less count motality is less my freind say to take glycomet to get pragnency what i should do

question: What are the benefits of having a pace maker?I have a 95 year old mother that is suffering from congestive heart failure and atrial defiberation she takes medicine for high blood pressure. question: What causes an anteroseptal infarct on ECG?if an ecg states that you have had an anteroseptal infart on several different occasions and an echocardiogram shows a thickened septal area and it is nearly a year since the incident that makes you think that you have had an mi, what is the likelihood that the anteroseptal event actually happened and was not just something like indigestion
human_answers: Hello, Welcome to HCM.Anteroseptal infarct seen on ECG or EKG = electrokardiogram means that you did have a heart attack = the heart muscle was damaged by a clogged coronary artery and this is what causes the changes seen by the doctors on the ECG recording. These changes are quite specific and characteristic and it is not likely that other medical conditions like indigestion would have produced them. Also, since these changes were seen on several different occasions, this makes an anteroseptal infarct  quite certain.After an infarct the damaged area of the heart muscle undergoes scarring and it may also result in thickening of that area as seen on the Echocardiogram.Some patients, especially diabetics, do not have symptoms like chest pain when they are having their heart attacks, so it is possible to just see the EKG changes of an "old MI" old myocarial infarction on an EKG while the patient does not even know that they had a heart attack.Typically an acute heart attack causes severe chest pain, Shortness of breath and makes one very ill and treatment in the hospital is required , where blood tests are done to confirm a diagnosis of so called acute MI.Hope this helps you understand this issue.Wishing you best of health.

Anteroseptal infarcts involve damage to the front and septal (dividing wall) portions of the heart, typically caused by blockage in the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery, which is often called the widow maker because of its critical importance in supplying blood to a large portion of the heart muscle. The fact that this ECG pattern has persisted across multiple readings over an extended period indicates permanent scarring of the heart tissue, as acute conditions like indigestion, anxiety, or temporary cardiac issues would not leave lasting electrical changes visible on repeat ECGs months later. The echocardiogram findings of septal wall thickening further support that a true myocardial infarction occurred, as this thickening represents the heart's attempt to compensate for damaged tissue by increasing the muscle mass in surrounding areas, or it could represent scar tissue formation where the heart muscle died and was replaced with fibrous tissue. This structural change on imaging studies provides objective evidence of heart damage that cannot be explained by temporary conditions like indigestion, stress, or other non-cardiac causes. The combination of persistent ECG changes and structural abnormalities on echocardiogram creates a very high likelihood - essentially near certainty - that you experienced a genuine heart attack, even if you may not have recognized the symptoms at the time or attributed them to something else. Many people, particularly women and older adults, can experience silent heart attacks with atypical symptoms that might be mistaken for indigestion, heartburn, or other conditions, but this doesn't make the heart attack any less real or dangerous. The fact that you're questioning whether it really happened suggests you may have had minimal or atypical symptoms during the actual event, which occurs in approximately 25% of heart attacks. Given these findings, it's crucial that you work closely with a cardiologist to assess your current cardiac function, evaluate for ongoing coronary artery disease, optimize medications to prevent future events, and implement lifestyle changes to reduce your risk of additional heart problems. The evidence strongly supports that you've had a real heart attack, and appropriate ongoing cardiac care is essential for your long-term health.

The fact that these behaviors are causing you distress and seem to be taking up significant time and mental energy suggests this goes beyond simply being neat or organized, and has crossed into the realm of a clinical condition that would benefit from professional treatment. The most effective treatment for OCD is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), specifically a type called exposure and response prevention (ERP), which involves gradually exposing yourself to situations that trigger your obsessions (like leaving something slightly out of place) while resisting the urge to perform your compulsions (like immediately fixing it). This therapy helps break the cycle of obsession-compulsion-temporary relief that maintains OCD symptoms. Many people also benefit from selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) medications, which can help reduce the intensity of obsessive thoughts and make it easier to resist compulsive behaviors. The combination of ERP therapy and medication is often the most effective approach for moderate to severe OCD. You should consider scheduling an appointment with a mental health professional who specializes in anxiety disorders and OCD for a proper evaluation and diagnosis. Look specifically for therapists trained in ERP, as this specialized approach is crucial for OCD treatment success. In the meantime, you might try small experiments like deliberately leaving one item slightly out of place for increasing periods of time to practice tolerating the anxiety without acting on the compulsion. Remember that OCD is a very treatable condition, and with proper therapy and possibly medication, most people experience significant improvement in their symptoms and quality of life. The sooner you seek treatment, the easier it typically is to break these patterns before they become more entrenched.

If you meant you're supposed to take it until February 17th, then your period would come within a week after that date. However, if you've had any unprotected intercourse since November 17th that you haven't mentioned, there could be a possibility of pregnancy from those more recent encounters, in which case the Duphaston could potentially delay detection. If you've been sexually active since November, you should discuss this with your OB and consider another pregnancy test if your period doesn't arrive as expected after the Duphaston course. It's also worth noting that if you don't get your period within 10 days of finishing the Duphaston, you should follow up with your doctor, as this might indicate the need for further evaluation of your irregular cycles or consideration of other underlying causes for your missed periods.
