question: What causes weakness in legs in an 8 year old?Hi doctor, my nephew who is 8 years old seems to have weak legs. His muscles seem weak and lately seems to be moving by crawling on all fours. I suspect that there s something not quite right but am not really certain of the problem. Please advise. Is he having some muscle disease?
human_answers: Hi...keeping in mind his age and insidious onset of symptoms and normalcy till now, I feel that it could be type of muscular dystrophy. I suggest you consult your pediatrician or pediatric neurologist as soon as possible and get your kid evaluated.Regards - Dr. Sumanth
chatgpt_answers: Weakness in the legs of an 8-year-old child that has progressed to the point where they're crawling on all fours instead of walking normally is a serious neurological or muscular symptom that requires immediate medical evaluation. This pattern of progressive muscle weakness could indicate several conditions, including muscular dystrophy (particularly Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which typically affects boys and often becomes apparent around this age), spinal muscular atrophy, inflammatory muscle diseases like juvenile dermatomyositis, neurological conditions affecting the spinal cord or peripheral nerves, or metabolic muscle disorders. The fact that the child has resorted to crawling suggests significant weakness in the leg muscles and possibly the pelvic girdle muscles, which is concerning for a degenerative muscle or nerve condition. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is particularly worrying in this scenario, as it's the most common childhood muscular dystrophy, primarily affects boys, and typically presents with progressive leg weakness that begins in early childhood. Children with this condition often develop a characteristic way of getting up from the floor (called Gower's sign) where they use their hands to walk up their legs due to weakness in the hip and thigh muscles, and they may eventually lose the ability to walk independently. Other possibilities include spinal muscular atrophy, which affects the motor neurons controlling muscle movement, or acquired conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome, though the chronic progressive nature you're describing makes genetic muscle diseases more likely. This child needs urgent pediatric evaluation, preferably by a pediatric neurologist or at a children's hospital, as progressive muscle weakness at this age is never normal and could indicate a serious underlying condition. The medical team will likely perform a thorough neurological examination, blood tests including creatine kinase levels (which are often elevated in muscle diseases), and possibly electromyography (EMG), nerve conduction studies, or muscle biopsy to determine the exact diagnosis. Early diagnosis is crucial because while some of these conditions don't have cures, there are treatments, supportive care measures, and interventions that can significantly improve quality of life and potentially slow disease progression. Please encourage the parents to seek immediate medical attention rather than waiting, as prompt evaluation and diagnosis are essential for the best possible outcomes.

question: What causes pain in the flank region?I have dull flank pain, both sides of my back just under rib cage. Went to emergency room the other night and Urine sample and bloodwork turned out  good and xrays were clear.  made doctors appointment  and just trying to do some research ahead of visit.
human_answers: Hi,This may be caused by tiny urinary / renal calculi.You need to get ultrasound abdomen done.Drink plenty of water and liquids.Thank you.
chatgpt_answers: Bilateral flank pain (pain on both sides of your back just under the ribcage) can have several causes, and while it's reassuring that your emergency room evaluation showed normal urine, blood work, and X-rays, this doesn't rule out all possible conditions. The flank area contains your kidneys, adrenal glands, and portions of your colon, and pain in this region can also be referred from other organs or result from musculoskeletal issues. Common causes of bilateral flank pain include kidney-related conditions such as early kidney infections that haven't yet shown up in standard urine tests, kidney stones that are too small to see on regular X-rays, polycystic kidney disease, or early stages of other kidney disorders. Musculoskeletal causes are also very common and include muscle strain from lifting, poor posture, sleeping in an awkward position, or inflammation of the muscles and fascia in the back. Other potential causes of bilateral flank pain include gastrointestinal issues such as colitis or irritation of the portions of the colon that lie near the flanks, pancreatic conditions (though these typically cause more central abdominal pain), or referred pain from gallbladder or liver issues. Sometimes conditions like fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome, or systemic inflammatory conditions can cause widespread pain that includes the flank areas. Dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, or certain medications can also sometimes cause kidney-area discomfort, and stress or anxiety can manifest as physical tension and pain in various parts of the body, including the back and flank regions. For your upcoming doctor's appointment, it would be helpful to note specific details about your pain: when it started, what makes it better or worse, whether it radiates anywhere else, if it's constant or comes and goes, and any associated symptoms like changes in urination, bowel movements, or appetite. Your doctor may want to perform additional tests that weren't done in the emergency room, such as a more detailed urinalysis, kidney function tests, inflammatory markers, or advanced imaging like a CT scan or ultrasound if kidney stones or other structural issues are suspected. They'll also perform a thorough physical examination to check for muscle tenderness, kidney enlargement, or other signs that might point toward a specific diagnosis.

question: Is ovex safe for thread worm in stomach?My 4 year old son woke on Thursday night with terrible itching in his bottom. He's had threadworm before and as the symptoms were the same I assumed it was threadworm again (despite not seeing any worms or eggs). He had a dose of Ovex on Thursday night but woke up again last night at the same time with itching again. How long does it take for the Ovex to work usually? Should I give him another dose?
human_answers: HI,   The Ovex has Mebendazol-which acts by disturbing glucose absorption by the worms-so their energy source is depleted ,they get weak & die within few days & excreted through stools.    Thus complete action of drug takes 4-5 days & the drug need not be repeated for itching in between.     Actually recurrence is common in thread worm infestation ,so the dose is repeated after 15 days gap twice-to have complete cure.     Thanks.
chatgpt_answers: Ovex (mebendazole) is safe and effective for treating threadworms (pinworms) in children, and it's the standard first-line treatment for this common childhood parasitic infection. However, it's important to understand that Ovex works by preventing the worms from absorbing glucose, which gradually kills them over several days, so you won't see immediate relief from itching. The medication typically takes 2-3 days to start showing effects, and complete elimination of the worms can take up to a week. The continued itching your son is experiencing just one day after treatment is normal and expected, as the adult worms are still alive and active, and the itching may actually temporarily worsen as dying worms become more active before they're eliminated. You should not give him another dose yet, as the standard treatment protocol is typically a single dose followed by a second dose two weeks later to catch any worms that may have hatched from eggs after the initial treatment. Giving multiple doses too close together is not recommended and won't speed up the process. The itching can persist for several days even after the worms begin dying, and this is one of the most frustrating aspects of threadworm treatment for parents. To help manage the itching while waiting for the medication to work, you can apply a barrier cream or petroleum jelly around the anal area before bedtime, keep his fingernails very short, ensure he wears close-fitting underwear or pajama bottoms to minimize scratching, and consider giving him an antihistamine like children's Benadryl before bed to reduce itching and help him sleep. It's also crucial to implement strict hygiene measures for the entire household, as threadworms are highly contagious and other family members may be infected even without showing symptoms. This includes washing hands frequently (especially before eating and after using the bathroom), washing all bedding and clothing in hot water, vacuuming carpets and upholstery, and ensuring everyone in the household is treated simultaneously. If the itching persists beyond a week or worsens significantly, or if you see no improvement in symptoms after 7-10 days, contact your pediatrician, as sometimes a second treatment course is needed or there may be reinfection occurring within the household.

question: Q. Will anxiety and depression get worse if I stop taking Ashwagandha?Hello doctor,I have started using Ashwagandha as a natural supplement for depression and anxiety. I have been feeling much better even after my doctor has reduced my sleeping medicines and antidepressant. My concern is if I stop using the Ashwagandha, will the depression anxiety return or get worse?
human_answers: Hello. I understand your concern regarding getting the depression back once you stop Ashwagandha. I would advise you to continue taking Ashwagandha till you feel a good amount of improvement in your depression. Also, start doing meditation, and some yoga poses for getting rid of depression problems. Then gradually reduce the dose of Ashwagandha so that your body gets used to the reduced doses of Ashwagandha. Do not stop using it immediately. Make sure you do it gradually. This will help to maintain your health, and most likely, you will not get back with the previous symptoms. I hope I have answered your questions.
chatgpt_answers: Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera) has shown promise in clinical studies for reducing anxiety and stress levels, with research suggesting it can help lower cortisol levels and provide mild anxiolytic effects, which may explain why you're feeling better since starting it. However, it's important to understand that ashwagandha works differently than prescription antidepressants and anti-anxiety medications - it's an adaptogen that helps your body manage stress responses rather than directly altering neurotransmitter systems like serotonin or GABA that are typically involved in depression and anxiety disorders. While some people do experience withdrawal-like symptoms when stopping herbal supplements, ashwagandha is generally not associated with significant physical dependence or rebound anxiety the way prescription medications can be. That said, if ashwagandha has been providing genuine therapeutic benefit for your mental health symptoms, stopping it could potentially lead to a return of your baseline anxiety and depression levels, especially if the underlying causes or triggers for these conditions haven't been addressed. This wouldn't necessarily be withdrawal in the medical sense, but rather a return to your pre-treatment symptom level. The risk may be higher if you stop the ashwagandha at the same time your doctor is reducing your prescription medications, as you'd be removing multiple sources of support simultaneously. Your body and brain may have adapted to having both the herbal and pharmaceutical support, so removing one component could potentially destabilize your current improved state. The most important factor here is that you're making these changes under medical supervision, which is excellent. Before stopping ashwagandha, you should discuss this concern with your doctor who has been managing your medication reductions. They can help you create a plan that might involve gradually tapering the ashwagandha rather than stopping abruptly, timing the discontinuation appropriately in relation to your other medication changes, or monitoring you closely for any return of symptoms. Since you've found a combination that's working well (reduced prescription medications plus ashwagandha), it may be worth continuing the ashwagandha for now while your brain adjusts to the lower levels of prescription medications, and then reassessing whether you need to continue it long-term once your medication regimen is stable.

question: Constant pain for thornwald't cystI have a Thornwalt cyst 7m and I have had it since 2004. I am in constant pain, my spine is very sensitive and my neck also. I have not been able to work at all. They have not found anything wrong with my back?? Could this be cause by the Cyst??
human_answers: hi, welcome to hcm  thanks for the query  there may be pain due to the cyst   but you have to rule out also other causes of spine pain  it needs full examination by a doctor  there is also need of some investigations like er,crp,hla b27, cbc ,xray ,mri etc  so its better to consult your nearest physician   take care
chatgpt_answers: A Thornwaldt cyst (also called Tornwaldt cyst) is a benign fluid-filled sac that develops in the nasopharynx (upper throat area behind the nose), and while these cysts are usually small and asymptomatic, a 7mm cyst that's been present since 2004 could potentially cause the symptoms you're describing, especially if it's located in a position where it's creating pressure or inflammation in the surrounding tissues. The nasopharynx is anatomically connected to important structures including the base of the skull, cervical spine, and various nerve pathways, so chronic inflammation or pressure from a persistent cyst could theoretically cause referred pain to your neck and spine. Additionally, chronic pain conditions can sometimes create a cycle where ongoing discomfort leads to muscle tension, poor posture, and compensatory movement patterns that can cause secondary neck and back pain even when imaging studies don't show structural problems. The constant pain and neck/spine sensitivity you've experienced for nearly two decades, combined with the inability to work, suggests this may indeed be related to your Thornwaldt cyst, particularly if the timing of your symptoms coincides with when the cyst was first discovered. Sometimes these cysts can cause chronic post-nasal drip, throat irritation, or deep-seated head and neck pain that's difficult to pinpoint and may not show up on standard spinal imaging. The fact that doctors haven't found anything wrong with your back despite your severe symptoms could support the theory that the pain is being referred from the nasopharyngeal area rather than originating from spinal structures themselves. You should consider seeking evaluation from an ENT (ear, nose, and throat) specialist who has experience with Thornwaldt cysts, as they may be able to assess whether your cyst has grown, changed position, or is causing more symptoms than initially recognized. Treatment options for symptomatic Thornwaldt cysts can include endoscopic drainage or marsupialization (creating a permanent opening), which might provide relief if the cyst is indeed the source of your chronic pain. Additionally, consulting with a pain management specialist who can evaluate the connection between your cyst and your systemic pain symptoms might help develop a comprehensive treatment approach that addresses both the potential source (the cyst) and the chronic pain patterns that have developed over the years.

question: Q. What causes severe toothache at night?Hello doctor,I am facing a toothache problem, especially at night times. There is higher pain from the last three days. Please suggest me a solution for toothache problem.
human_answers: Hello. As you are describing it as night pain it looks like the infection in your tooth has reached pulp and now requires root canal treatment. Please get an X-ray done and send the photo of the X-ray as soon as possible. For now, you may take the following medications for three days: Amoxicillin clavulanate 625 mg, twice a day, Paracetamol 500 mg thrice a day, only when pain is there, otherwise take only Amoxicillin clavulanate tablets. Revert back with X-ray. Follow up after two days. Follow up after two days.
chatgpt_answers: Severe toothache that worsens at night is a common dental complaint and typically occurs due to several factors that make dental pain more noticeable and intense during nighttime hours. When you lie down, blood flow to your head increases, which can increase pressure in inflamed dental tissues and intensify pain from conditions like tooth decay, abscessed teeth, or infected dental pulp. Additionally, at night there are fewer distractions and your pain threshold may be lower due to fatigue, making you more aware of discomfort. The most common causes of severe nighttime toothache include deep cavities that have reached the tooth's nerve, dental abscesses (bacterial infections at the tooth root), cracked or fractured teeth, severe gum disease, or impacted wisdom teeth. The fact that your pain has been worsening over three days suggests an active infection or inflammation that requires professional dental treatment rather than just home remedies. Dental infections can spread quickly and become dangerous if left untreated, potentially leading to facial swelling, fever, or more serious complications. For immediate temporary relief while waiting to see a dentist, you can take over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen (which also reduces inflammation) or acetaminophen according to package directions, rinse with warm salt water to help reduce bacteria and inflammation, apply a cold compress to the outside of your cheek for 15-20 minutes at a time, and try sleeping with your head elevated to reduce blood flow to the affected area. However, severe toothache that persists for multiple days requires urgent dental evaluation and treatment, as the underlying cause likely won't resolve on its own and may worsen without professional intervention. You should see a dentist as soon as possible, and if you develop fever, facial swelling, difficulty swallowing, or severe pain that doesn't respond to pain medication, you should seek emergency dental care or visit an emergency room. The dentist will likely need to perform X-rays to identify the source of your pain and may require treatments such as root canal therapy, tooth extraction, antibiotic therapy for infection, or other procedures depending on the underlying cause of your severe nighttime toothache.

question: Diagnosed with anemia. Swollen face and eyes, throat congestion, headache and heart flutters. Are these symptoms of anemia?I HAVE RECENTLY BEEN DIAGNOSED WITH ANEMIA. I HAVE A 'VERY' SWOLLEN FACE AND EYES. MY THROAT FEELS LIKE THERE IS A LUMP IN IT, FRONTAL HEADACHE AND HEART FLUTTERS,  MY APPOINTMENT TO MEET WITH MY PHYSICIAN ISN'T UNTIL JUNE 4TH. IS THIS ALL ASSOCIATED WITH ANEMIA? WWW.WWWW.WW
human_answers: Hi,Thanks for using healthcare magic.I have gone through your history.All your symptoms can be explained by anemia. You should go for blood investigations like hemogram, ferritin level or vitamin b12 level. You may get prescription form your doctor.Your doctor may also advise to have investigations to find out the cause of anemia , whether is nutritional or hemolytic o else.Thanks.
chatgpt_answers: While some of your symptoms could be related to anemia, the combination of severe facial and eye swelling along with throat congestion and heart palpitations is concerning and may indicate additional medical issues that require more urgent attention than your scheduled June appointment. Anemia can indeed cause fatigue, headaches, and heart palpitations (flutters) as your heart works harder to pump oxygen-depleted blood throughout your body, and severe anemia can sometimes contribute to fluid retention. However, the significant facial and eye swelling you're describing is not a typical primary symptom of anemia alone and could suggest other serious conditions such as kidney problems, heart failure, severe allergic reactions, thyroid disorders, or other systemic conditions that can also cause or coexist with anemia. The lump in throat sensation combined with facial swelling could indicate several possibilities including thyroid enlargement (which can also cause anemia), allergic reactions, or other conditions affecting your upper respiratory tract or cardiovascular system. Heart flutters combined with facial swelling might suggest fluid retention or cardiovascular issues that could be related to the underlying cause of your anemia rather than the anemia itself. Some types of anemia are caused by chronic kidney disease, autoimmune conditions, or other systemic illnesses that can also cause the swelling and throat symptoms you're experiencing. Given the severity of your facial swelling, throat symptoms, and heart palpitations, you should contact your doctor's office immediately to see if you can be seen sooner, or consider seeking urgent medical care at an emergency room or urgent care facility. Significant facial swelling combined with heart symptoms and throat congestion can sometimes indicate serious conditions that shouldn't wait several weeks for evaluation. These symptoms together suggest you may need immediate assessment to rule out conditions like severe allergic reactions, kidney problems, heart failure, or other serious medical issues that require prompt treatment beyond just managing your anemia.

question: Suggest me some claritin and cold flu medicinei started taking claritin 24 hr yesterday at noon, about 1 in the morning i woke up hackin up yellow junk but my temp is stayin around 97.0 even though my chest feels like its on fire. Can i still take my claritin with flu meds?
human_answers: hi rick,  welcome to hcmthanks for the query  if your flu medications contain any antihistaminics then you can avoid claritin take care.wish you a good day
chatgpt_answers: The yellow phlegm you're coughing up and the burning chest sensation suggest you may be developing a bacterial chest infection or bronchitis rather than just allergies, which means you likely need more than just Claritin to address your symptoms. While Claritin (loratadine) can be safely taken with most over-the-counter cold and flu medications, the specific combination depends on which flu medications you're considering, as some multi-symptom cold/flu products already contain antihistamines and combining them could lead to double-dosing. It's generally safe to take Claritin with single-ingredient medications like acetaminophen or ibuprofen for pain and fever, dextromethorphan for cough suppression, or guaifenesin for loosening mucus, but you should avoid taking it with multi-symptom products that list antihistamines as ingredients. However, your symptoms - particularly the yellow, productive cough and chest burning sensation - suggest this may be beyond what over-the-counter medications can effectively treat. Yellow or green phlegm often indicates a bacterial infection that may require antibiotic treatment, and the chest burning could suggest bronchitis or even early pneumonia. The fact that your temperature is staying normal (97.0°F is actually slightly below normal) doesn't rule out a bacterial infection, as not all respiratory infections cause fever, especially in the early stages or in some individuals whose immune systems respond differently. Given that you're coughing up colored mucus and experiencing chest discomfort, you should consider seeing a healthcare provider or visiting an urgent care facility rather than just trying to manage this with over-the-counter medications. They can listen to your lungs, possibly order a chest X-ray if needed, and determine whether you need antibiotics or other prescription treatments. In the meantime, if you do take any cold/flu medications with your Claritin, carefully read all ingredient labels to avoid duplication, stay well-hydrated to help thin mucus secretions, and consider using a humidifier or breathing steam to help with chest congestion.

question: What causes tender lump under chin?I have a lump under my chin (base of tongue), too high for thyroid and too medial for lymph glands that I am familiar with. It comes and goes but when it is large (size of walnut) it is sore to the touch and hurts if I yawn. I was recently exposed to strong chemicals and also wonder if it could be from an abscessed tooth although I am not aware of any dental problems.
human_answers: Hi,It is nothing but enlarged lymph node giving this problem.Any infection in the oral cavity like decayed or carious teeth, tarter ed teeth or ulcer in the mouth can give this problem.Consult dentist and get examined.Keep oral hygiene proper.Ok and take care.
chatgpt_answers: A tender lump at the base of your tongue that fluctuates in size and causes pain when yawning or touching is most likely related to a blocked salivary gland, specifically the submandibular salivary glands which are located under the chin and can become enlarged when their ducts become blocked by stones, thick saliva, or inflammation. Salivary gland blockages commonly cause intermittent swelling that worsens with eating (especially sour foods that stimulate saliva production), can reach the size of a walnut as you described, and are tender to touch because the trapped saliva creates pressure within the gland. The pain with yawning occurs because jaw movement and stretching can put additional pressure on the already swollen gland. Your suspicion about a dental abscess is also valid, as infections from teeth (even asymptomatic ones) can cause swelling in the floor of the mouth and submandibular area, and dental abscesses don't always cause obvious tooth pain initially. The recent exposure to strong chemicals could potentially contribute to inflammation or irritation of the salivary glands or oral tissues, though this is less common than the other causes. Sometimes the submandibular lymph nodes, which are actually located in this area contrary to your assumption, can also become enlarged due to oral infections, dental problems, or irritation from chemical exposure, and these nodes can indeed become quite large and tender when fighting infection. You should see a healthcare provider or dentist for evaluation, as several of these conditions require specific treatment. A doctor can perform a physical examination to determine whether this is a salivary gland issue, lymph node enlargement, or potentially a dental-related problem. They may recommend imaging like an ultrasound or CT scan if needed, and a dentist can evaluate for any hidden dental infections that might be causing the swelling. Treatment varies depending on the cause - salivary stones may need removal, infections require antibiotics, and dental abscesses need specific dental treatment. Don't wait too long to seek evaluation, especially if the lump continues to grow, becomes increasingly painful, or if you develop fever or difficulty swallowing.

question: PCOD, had miscarriage, taken follicular test. Can i conceive again?am 37 yr . i have lost my baby for 8 month 23 days during pregnancy i have pod. can i conceive again . now i am taking follicular test and result is my follicle is MSF the day of 12 ND 15. plz ans me
human_answers: Hi,The cause of your pregnancy loss is not PCOD as conception is the main problem with PCOD and also early maintenance of the pregnancy, but not a pregnancy loss in the late trimester. chatgpt_answers: I'm very sorry for the loss of your baby at such an advanced stage of pregnancy - losing a pregnancy at 8 months and 23 days must have been incredibly difficult and heartbreaking. Having PCOD (polycystic ovarian disease) can make conception more challenging, but many women with PCOD do successfully conceive and have healthy pregnancies, even after pregnancy loss. The fact that you're undergoing follicular monitoring suggests your doctor is actively working to help you conceive again, which is encouraging. Your follicular study showing MSF (mature small follicle) on days 12 and 15 indicates that your ovaries are producing follicles, though the specific interpretation depends on the exact measurements and your complete hormonal profile that your doctor would need to evaluate. At 37 years old with PCOD and a history of late pregnancy loss, conception may require more careful monitoring and possibly fertility treatments, but it's definitely possible. PCOD can cause irregular ovulation, but with proper medical management including ovulation induction medications, lifestyle modifications, and careful monitoring through follicular studies like you're having done, many women successfully conceive. Your doctor may need to address the PCOD with medications like metformin or ovulation-inducing drugs like clomiphene or letrozole, and they'll likely want to investigate the cause of your previous pregnancy loss to prevent recurrence and ensure a healthier pregnancy next time. It's important to work closely with both a reproductive endocrinologist or fertility specialist and a high-risk pregnancy specialist (maternal-fetal medicine doctor) given your history of late pregnancy loss. They can investigate potential causes of your previous loss such as genetic factors, blood clotting disorders, cervical issues, or other medical conditions, and develop a comprehensive plan for future pregnancies including early monitoring, progesterone support if needed, and other interventions to improve your chances of a successful pregnancy. While your journey may require patience and medical support, many women with PCOD and previous pregnancy losses do go on to have successful pregnancies with appropriate care and monitoring.

question: Q. My pregnancy test showed two faint lines. Should I go to the doctor or wait for a week?Hello doctor I have history of Thyroid and PCOS, i am taking 50mg of eltroxin. my period is delayed by 6 days .when I tested preganacy test after 4 days of period days two lines are showing but not clearly. please suggest me can I go to doctor for a checkup or wait for 1 week for clear result. or what type of precaution I should take during pregnancy?
human_answers: Hello, Welcome to Icliniq. I see than you haven't mentioned the date of your last menstrual period. Ideally, if you have had a regular 28days cycles, the urine pregnancy test is usually positive by the time you skip your periods. Delayed ovulation can be common in PCOS, So, I would suggest you to recheck your home pregancy test with an early morning urine sample tomorrow, and exactly at the time interval at which the result has to be read as mentioned on the kit. Sometimes if seen very late , the evaporation line also may seem as faintly positive which is actually a false positive. Early morning urine sample is supposed to be having concentrated levels of the Beta HCG hormone which is detected on the pregnancy kit. So recheck again tomorrow with a morning sample of urine. If you donot have any pain or spotting, you can visit your Gynaecologist at ease, may be in a week, and get an ultrasound done for pregnancy viability and localisation. Meanwhile continue taking folic acid & Eltroxin Medications & recheck your thyroid levels as during the pregnancy the dose may have to be changed due to increased requirements in pregnancy. chatgpt_answers: Two faint lines on a pregnancy test typically indicate a positive result, even if they're not very dark, as pregnancy tests are designed to detect the hormone hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) which is only produced during pregnancy. Given your history of thyroid issues and PCOS, along with a 6-day delayed period, the faint positive lines suggest you are likely pregnant, though the hormone levels are still relatively low since you tested early. With your medical history, particularly thyroid disease and PCOS, it would be wise to see your doctor sooner rather than waiting another week, as both conditions require careful management during early pregnancy to ensure optimal outcomes for both you and the baby. Your thyroid condition is especially important to address early in pregnancy, as thyroid hormone requirements typically increase during pregnancy, and proper thyroid function is crucial for fetal brain development, particularly in the first trimester. Since you're already taking 50mg of eltroxin (levothyroxine), your doctor will likely want to check your thyroid levels and may need to adjust your dosage. PCOS can also affect early pregnancy and may require monitoring for complications like gestational diabetes or pregnancy-induced hypertension, so early prenatal care is particularly beneficial for women with your medical history. You should schedule an appointment with your doctor within the next few days rather than waiting a full week, and they can confirm the pregnancy with a blood test that measures exact hCG levels and check your thyroid function. question: Q. What should I do to manage the fear of death?Hello doctor,Recently after watching a video of a young person dying of heart attack, I have developed a fear of death. Although I am young and have no heart problems, I tend to think about it all the time. Please help me to get rid of this.
human_answers: Hello. Here are two kinds of fears or phobias. 1) Temporary. 2) Permanent. Temporary lasts for few days after you suffer or witness some traumatic thing. Permanent ones would slightly fall under some psychiatric issues worth paying attention. I would recommend you to wait for some time. Keep yourself busy with positive and productive things and try to be in the company of family or friends. Try deep breathing, meditation and running. Everything should be settled by two weeks. If it does not, then consult a psychiatrist for proper evaluation and treatment.
chatgpt_answers: Your fear of death after watching that video is completely understandable - witnessing unexpected tragedy, especially involving someone young, can trigger what psychologists call mortality salience where we become hyperaware of our own mortality. This type of reaction is actually quite normal and shows that your mind is processing the reality that life can be fragile and unpredictable. When we see someone similar to us (young, presumably healthy) experience something frightening like sudden cardiac death, our brains naturally make the connection this could happen to me, which activates our survival instincts and creates anxiety as a protective mechanism, even when the actual risk to us personally may be very low. The persistent thoughts you're experiencing are a form of intrusive thinking that often occurs with anxiety, where your mind gets stuck in a loop trying to solve the unsolvable problem of mortality. This can create a cycle where the more you try not to think about death, the more prominent these thoughts become. Understanding that this is a normal psychological response to witnessing trauma can help reduce some of the distress - your reaction doesn't mean you're developing a serious mental health condition, but rather that you're having a very human response to confronting the reality of death unexpectedly. Several strategies can help you manage these fears and intrusive thoughts. Grounding techniques like the 5-4-3-2-1 method (identifying 5 things you can see, 4 you can hear, 3 you can touch, 2 you can smell, 1 you can taste) can help redirect your focus when death-related thoughts arise. Regular exercise, meditation, or deep breathing exercises can help reduce overall anxiety levels and give your mind healthier outlets. Limiting exposure to similar content online or in media can prevent reinforcing these fears. If these thoughts continue to interfere significantly with your daily life, sleep, or functioning after a few weeks, consider speaking with a counselor or therapist who can provide cognitive-behavioral techniques specifically designed to help process death anxiety and intrusive thoughts.

question: Should I be concerned for trace amounts of free fluid in pelvis?After some abdominal discomfort, my gastro ordered an abdominal/Pelvic CT Scan with contrast. Free pelvic fluid can occur from several normal physiological processes including residual fluid from normal bodily functions, minor inflammation from various causes, or even fluid that can accumulate from normal metabolic processes. Since you had a complete hysterectomy in 2008, some of the more common gynecological causes of pelvic fluid (like ovarian cysts or menstrual-related fluid) are ruled out, which actually makes this finding even less concerning. The fact that the CT scan showed no acute abnormality of the abdomen or pelvis is the most important finding here, and the radiologist would have mentioned any concerning features if they were present. Trace pelvic fluid can result from many benign causes including recent physical activity, mild dehydration followed by rehydration, minor gastrointestinal inflammation, or simply normal variation in how much fluid is present in the peritoneal cavity at any given time. Sometimes even the CT contrast material itself can cause minor temporary inflammation that results in small amounts of fluid accumulation. Given your age, surgical history, and the reassuring overall CT findings, this trace amount of pelvic fluid is most likely insignificant and not the cause of your abdominal discomfort. However, your gastroenterologist is the best person to interpret these findings in the context of your specific symptoms and medical history. If they felt it warranted concern, they would likely recommend follow-up imaging or additional testing. Since you mention ongoing abdominal discomfort, it would be worth discussing with your doctor whether further evaluation for other gastrointestinal causes might be appropriate, but the trace pelvic fluid itself is probably not something to worry about based on the information you've provided.

chatgpt_answers: Truvada is a prescription medication that contains two HIV medications (tenofovir and emtricitabine) and is approved for pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) to prevent HIV infection, not other sexually transmitted diseases. Truvada can provide protection against HIV exposure through various routes including anal sex, vaginal sex, and oral sex, though the level of protection varies by activity - it's most effective for receptive anal sex and less necessary for lower-risk activities like oral sex, where HIV transmission rates are much lower. However, it's crucial to understand that Truvada only protects against HIV infection and does not prevent other sexually transmitted infections such as syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydia, herpes, hepatitis B or C, or human papillomavirus (HPV). When taken consistently and correctly, Truvada is highly effective at preventing HIV - studies show it reduces HIV risk by about 99% for sexual transmission when taken daily as prescribed. But this protection is specific to HIV only, and people taking PrEP still need to use other prevention methods like condoms to protect against other STDs and should undergo regular STD testing as recommended by their healthcare provider. Truvada does not ensure complete protection from HIV or any STDs - no preventive measure is 100% effective, and protection requires consistent daily use, regular medical monitoring, and adherence to the prescribed regimen. People considering PrEP should discuss their individual risk factors with a healthcare provider who can assess whether Truvada is appropriate for them, monitor for side effects, and provide comprehensive sexual health counseling that includes protection strategies for all STDs, not just HIV. Regular testing for HIV and other STDs remains important even for people taking PrEP, as comprehensive sexual health involves protection against all sexually transmitted infections, not just HIV.

This type of injury is quite common from the mechanism you described - falling and hitting the outer edge of your foot on a hard surface. The continued pain you're experiencing is normal for this type of injury, as bone bruises can actually be more painful and take longer to heal than some minor fractures. Your recovery will likely take anywhere from 2-6 weeks depending on the severity of the bruising, and during this time you should focus on protecting the foot from further injury, using appropriate footwear with good support, and following your doctor's recommendations for activity modification. If your pain significantly worsens, if you develop new symptoms like severe swelling, numbness, or inability to bear weight, or if you're not seeing gradual improvement over the next couple of weeks, return to your doctor for re-evaluation. However, based on your doctor's assessment of a bruised rather than fractured 5th metatarsal, you should expect a full recovery without the need for surgery.

question: What causes high heart rate while race walking?I am a healthy 58 yrs old woman. I race walk competively. I have been going faster lately. A heart rate of 230 on exertion definitely requires evaluation. however first of all we need to evaluate whether you really reach that 230 reading. while running the heart rate detector may mistake your body vibrations and movements for heart beats and count them  accordingly. hence the heart rate may erroneously show a high reading. So you have to check whethrr it happens with you only or with everyone. Another thing that can be done is a treadmill test. It requires you to run on a treadmill, the speed of which increases gradually to a point till your heart rate reaches a target rate. this TMT test will continuously record your EKG while you are running so all aberrations and errors can be rules out. chatgpt_answers: A heart rate of 230 beats per minute during intense race walking at age 58 is concerning and warrants medical evaluation, even though you're otherwise healthy and competitive. The traditional maximum heart rate formula (220 minus your age) would suggest your theoretical maximum should be around 162 bpm, making 230 significantly higher than expected even during peak exertion. While very fit athletes can sometimes exceed these predicted maximums, reaching 230 bpm suggests you may be experiencing episodes of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) or another arrhythmia rather than normal exercise-induced sinus tachycardia. SVT can be triggered by intense exercise and often presents as sudden episodes of very rapid heart rate that last for seconds to minutes before resolving, which matches your description. The fact that your heart rate drops quickly after exercise is reassuring and suggests good cardiovascular fitness and recovery capacity, but it doesn't rule out underlying rhythm abnormalities that could be triggered specifically during peak exertion. Even in healthy, well-conditioned athletes, heart rates consistently reaching 230 bpm can indicate electrical conduction issues in the heart that may not cause symptoms at rest or during moderate exercise. While some competitive athletes do achieve very high heart rates during peak performance, episodes reaching 230 bpm at your age could potentially lead to decreased cardiac output, reduced oxygen delivery to vital organs, or in rare cases, could trigger more dangerous arrhythmias. You should consult with a cardiologist or sports medicine physician who can perform appropriate testing, including an electrocardiogram (ECG), exercise stress testing, and possibly a Holter monitor to capture your heart rhythm during training sessions. They can determine whether these episodes represent normal athletic response, benign arrhythmias, or something that requires intervention. In the meantime, consider monitoring these episodes more closely - noting exactly when they occur, how long they last, and whether you experience any symptoms like dizziness, chest pain, or shortness of breath. While it's encouraging that you're performing well competitively and recovering normally, heart rates of 230 bpm are high enough to warrant professional evaluation to ensure your continued safety during training and competition.

chatgpt_answers: The dark spots you're describing are likely post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH), which is a common occurrence after facial injuries where skin cells have been damaged or ruptured. The good news is that PIH is generally treatable, though it requires patience and consistent care since the healing process for pigmentation issues is typically slow. For treating these dark spots, start with gentle, consistent skincare that includes daily broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30 or higher), as sun exposure will darken the spots and prevent healing. Over-the-counter treatments that can help include products containing vitamin C, niacinamide, kojic acid, or alpha hydroxy acids like glycolic acid, which can help accelerate cell turnover and gradually lighten hyperpigmentation. Retinoids, available both over-the-counter (retinol) and by prescription (tretinoin), are also very effective for promoting skin renewal and reducing dark spots, though they should be introduced gradually to avoid irritation. It's crucial to be gentle with your skin during treatment, as further irritation or picking at the spots can worsen the pigmentation. However, for facial injuries that have resulted in significant dark spots, it's advisable to consult with a dermatologist who can assess the specific type and depth of pigmentation and recommend appropriate treatments. Professional options may include chemical peels, laser treatments, microneedling, or prescription-strength hydroquinone or tretinoin, which are typically more effective than over-the-counter options. A dermatologist can also rule out other causes of dark spots and ensure that what you're seeing is indeed post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation rather than scarring or other skin changes. Be patient with the process, as most pigmentation treatments require 3-6 months of consistent use to see significant improvement, and avoid the temptation to try multiple aggressive treatments at once, which can actually worsen the pigmentation.

Some blood lab tests may be needed to exclude other possible causes of blood pressure fluctuations: - complete blood count- blood electrolytes for possible imbalance- thyroid hormone levels for possible thyroid dysfunction- inflammation tests (PCR, sedimentation rate). Hope you will find this answer helpful!Kind regards, Dr. Iliri

Lipomas are particularly common in the shoulder and upper arm area and typically feel soft, movable, and painless, while sebaceous cysts might feel more firm and could have a small central opening. The occasional slight muscle pain you're experiencing could be related to the lump pressing on surrounding muscle fibers or could be coincidental muscle tension from normal activities. The characteristics you describe are generally reassuring - the absence of redness, warmth, and significant pain, along with its stable size over a week, suggests this is less likely to be an infection or rapidly growing malignant tumor. However, any new lump that persists for more than a few weeks should be evaluated by a healthcare provider to ensure proper diagnosis and rule out more serious conditions. You should schedule an appointment with your primary care physician for evaluation of this lump, especially since it has persisted for over a week and you're experiencing some associated discomfort. Your doctor can perform a physical examination to assess the lump's characteristics (mobility, texture, size), review your medical history, and determine whether additional testing such as ultrasound or biopsy is needed. While most lumps of this type turn out to be benign, it's important to get a proper medical assessment for peace of mind and to establish a baseline for monitoring any future changes. In the meantime, avoid repeatedly touching or manipulating the lump, as this could cause irritation or make it more difficult for your doctor to assess its natural characteristics.

question: Are BP of 119/65 and pulse of 35 causes for concern?Yesterday I was very dizzy, short of breath, heart rate around 35,BP 119/65. I am 51,female, overweight and have RA and Fibermyalgia. Do you know what might have caused this episode yesterday? I figure I would not feel okay today if it had been a heart attack.
human_answers: Welcome and thank you for asking on HCM! I have gone through your question. firstly an ECG is required and if itshows complete heart block (more likely) a pacemaker may beneeded.Hope to have been helpful!Wishing good health, Dr D Sunil Reddy
chatgpt_answers: A heart rate of 35 beats per minute (bradycardia) combined with dizziness and shortness of breath is definitely concerning and requires immediate medical attention, regardless of how you're feeling today. A normal resting heart rate for adults is typically 60-100 beats per minute, so 35 bpm represents significant bradycardia that can cause inadequate blood flow to your brain and other vital organs, which would explain your dizziness and shortness of breath. This dangerously slow heart rate could be caused by several factors including problems with your heart's electrical conduction system, medication side effects, electrolyte imbalances, thyroid disorders, or other cardiac conditions. Your assumption that you would still feel bad today if it were a heart attack isn't necessarily correct, as some cardiac events can have delayed or intermittent symptoms, and bradycardia itself can be a sign of underlying heart problems. Your medical history of rheumatoid arthritis and fibromyalgia adds additional complexity to your situation. Some medications used to treat RA, particularly certain disease-modifying drugs or if you're on any heart medications, can affect heart rhythm. Additionally, RA is an inflammatory condition that can increase your risk of cardiovascular disease, including heart rhythm abnormalities. The combination of being overweight and having RA puts you at higher baseline risk for cardiac issues. While your blood pressure reading of 119/65 appears normal, the heart rate of 35 is so abnormally low that it could indicate a serious problem with your heart's electrical system, such as heart block, sick sinus syndrome, or other conduction disorders. You should seek immediate medical evaluation, ideally at an emergency room or urgent care facility, even though you're feeling better today. Heart rhythm problems can be intermittent, and the fact that you experienced such severe bradycardia with symptoms yesterday means this could happen again and potentially be life-threatening. You need an EKG, blood work to check electrolyte levels and thyroid function, and cardiac monitoring to determine the cause of your bradycardia. Don't wait to see if symptoms return - this type of heart rate with associated symptoms represents a medical emergency that requires prompt evaluation to prevent more serious complications. Bring a list of all your current medications, as some drugs can cause bradycardia as a side effect.

question: Suggest treatment for back pain after walking for some timeI am 18 and I get terrible back ache after standing up or walking around for only a few hours. It is in the middle of my back and it gets better once I have rested it. Should I be getting pain this bad at my age? I am 5ft 3 and 8 stone so not overweight. What could it be?
human_answers: Hi,Having this type of back pain at this age indicates lack of physical exercise.go for daily physical exercise like running, jogging, swimming etc daily for 30-35 minutes a day for 5days in a week.Develop some interest in sports.Take high protein diet.Ok and take care.
chatgpt_answers: Back pain that develops after only a few hours of standing or walking in an 18-year-old is not normal and suggests there may be an underlying issue with your posture, spinal alignment, or muscle imbalances that needs attention. At your age and healthy weight, you should be able to stand and walk for extended periods without developing significant back pain. The fact that your pain is in the middle of your back (thoracic region) and improves with rest suggests it could be related to postural strain, where your spinal muscles are working overtime to maintain your posture, possibly due to muscle weakness, poor ergonomics, or structural issues like scoliosis (curvature of the spine). Other possibilities include muscle imbalances between your core, back, and hip muscles, or you might have a condition like Scheuermann's disease, which affects spinal development and can cause back pain in young people. Several factors could be contributing to your symptoms even at your young age. Poor posture from prolonged sitting (especially during school or computer use), carrying heavy backpacks, lack of core strength, or even wearing improper footwear can all lead to the type of back pain you're describing. Additionally, some people have subtle spinal abnormalities or muscle development issues that become apparent when the spine is stressed during prolonged upright activities. The middle back area is particularly susceptible to postural strain because it has to work to counteract forward head posture and rounded shoulders that are common in today's technology-heavy lifestyle. You should definitely see your doctor or a physiotherapist for proper evaluation, as this level of pain in someone your age warrants investigation. They can assess your posture, check for spinal curvature, evaluate your muscle strength and flexibility, and determine if imaging studies are needed. Treatment typically focuses on strengthening your core and back muscles, improving posture, and addressing any biomechanical issues. In the meantime, you can try gentle back exercises, ensure good posture when sitting, take frequent breaks from prolonged positions, and use supportive footwear. Don't dismiss this as something you have to live with - addressing back problems early in life can prevent more serious issues from developing as you get older, and there are usually effective treatments available once the underlying cause is identified.
